Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Public Safety Code
===================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 1 - Administration
***********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This title is known as the "Public Safety Code."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1): 63O-1-101; 53-1-107; 53-1-103; 53-13-103; 36-11-102; 53B-3-102 As used in this title:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(a): 63O-1-101 "Capitol hill complex" means capitol hill, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(b): 53-1-107 "Commissioner" means the commissioner of public safety appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(c): 53-1-103 "Department" means the Department of Public Safety created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(d): "Governor-elect" means an individual whom the board of canvassers determines to be the successful candidate for governor after a general election for the office of governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(e): "Law enforcement agency" means an entity or division of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(e)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(e)(i)(A): the federal government, a state, or a political subdivision of a state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(e)(i)(B): a state institution of higher education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(e)(i)(C): a private institution of higher education, if the entity or division is certified by the commissioner under Title 53, Chapter 19, Certification of Private Law Enforcement Agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(e)(ii): that exists primarily to prevent and detect crime and enforce criminal laws, statutes, and ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(f): 53-13-103 "Law enforcement officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(g): "Motor vehicle" means every self-propelled vehicle and every vehicle propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except motorized wheel chairs and vehicles moved solely by human power.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(h): "Peace officer" means any officer certified in accordance with Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(i): 36-11-102 "Public official" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(j): 53B-3-102 "State institution of higher education" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(1)(k): "Vehicle" means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-102(2): The definitions provided in Subsection (1) are to be applied throughout this title in addition to definitions that are applicable to specific chapters or parts.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-103 Creation of department.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-103(1): There is created within state government the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-103(2): The department has all of the policymaking functions, regulatory and enforcement powers, rights, duties, and responsibilities specified in this title.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner and the department and its boards, councils, divisions, and offices shall comply with the procedures and requirements of:Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-105(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-105(2): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-105(3): Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106 Department duties -- Powers.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1): 41-6a-1406; 41-6a-1304; 31A-19a-211; 63M-7-505; 53-2a-702; 53-2a-402; 63G-22-102; 53G-8-702; 53E-3-516; 53G-8-211; 77-36-2.1; 78B-7-120; 63L-13-201 In addition to the responsibilities contained in this title, the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(a): 41-6a-1406; 41-6a-1304 make rules and perform the functions specified in Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(a)(i): 41-6a-1406 setting performance standards for towing companies to be used by the department, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(a)(ii): 41-6a-1304 advising the Department of Transportation regarding the safe design and operation of school buses, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(b): 31A-19a-211 make rules to establish and clarify standards pertaining to the curriculum and teaching methods of a motor vehicle accident prevention course under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(c): aid in enforcement efforts to combat drug trafficking;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(d): meet with the Division of Technology Services to formulate contracts, establish priorities, and develop funding mechanisms for dispatch and telecommunications operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(e): 63M-7-505 provide assistance to the Crime Victim Reparations Board and the Utah Office for Victims of Crime in conducting research or monitoring victims' programs, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(f): develop sexual assault exam protocol standards in conjunction with the Utah Hospital Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(g): 53-2a-702 engage in emergency planning activities, including preparation of policy and procedure and rulemaking necessary for implementation of the federal Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act of 1986, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(h): 53-2a-402 implement the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(i): 63G-22-102 ensure that any training or certification required of a public official or public employee, as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(i)(i): under this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(i)(ii): by the department; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(i)(iii): by an agency or division within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(j): 53G-8-702; 53E-3-516; 53G-8-211 employ a law enforcement officer as a public safety liaison to be housed at the State Board of Education who shall work with the State Board of Education to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(j)(i): 53G-8-702 support training with relevant state agencies for school resource officers as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(j)(ii): coordinate the creation of model policies and memorandums of understanding for a local education agency and a local law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(j)(iii): 53E-3-516; 53G-8-211 ensure cooperation between relevant state agencies, a local education agency, and a local law enforcement agency to foster compliance with disciplinary related statutory provisions, including Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(k): provide for the security and protection of public officials, public officials' staff, and the capitol hill complex in accordance with the provisions of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(l): 77-36-2.1; 78B-7-120 fulfill the duties described in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(1)(m): 63L-13-201 fulfill the duties described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(2): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(2)(a): The department shall establish a schedule of fees as required or allowed in this title for services provided by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(2)(b): 63J-1-504 All fees not established in statute shall be established in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106(3): 26B-8-319 The department may establish or contract for the establishment of an Organ Procurement Donor Registry in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2 Towing dispatch program.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2(1): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act An interlocal agency established pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2(2): (1) The product or technology described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2(2)(a): decreasing delays associated with requesting and dispatching a tow truck motor carrier from an established tow rotation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2(2)(b): increasing information, transparency, and data collection associated with tow rotation operations, including dispatching, response time, completion, clearance, and storage; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2(2)(c): increasing responder and traffic safety by reducing secondary crashes, responder time on scene, and the impacts of traffic accidents on traffic flow and safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.2(3): A vendor selected to provide towing dispatch management services as described in this section may not also provide towing, storage, impounding, or other services related to the operation of a towing provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.5 Utah Medical Cannabis Act -- Department duties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to the duties described in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.5(1): provide standards for training peace officers and law enforcement agencies in the use of the state electronic verification system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-106.5(2): collaborate with the Department of Health and the Department of Agriculture and Food to provide standards for training peace officers and law enforcement agencies in medical cannabis law.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107 Commissioner of public safety -- Appointment -- Qualifications -- Salary.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(1): The chief executive officer of the department is the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(2)(a): Every fourth year after the year 1989, the governor shall appoint a commissioner with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(2)(b): The commissioner shall serve for a period of four years from July 1 of the year of the commissioner's appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(3): The commissioner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(3)(a): be an individual of recognized executive and administrative capacity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(3)(b): be selected solely with regard to the commissioner's qualifications and fitness to discharge the duties of the commissioner's office;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(3)(c): be of high moral character;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(3)(d): be of good standing in the community in which the commissioner lives; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(3)(e): have been a resident of this state for a period of at least five years immediately prior to appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(4): The commissioner shall devote full time to the duties of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-107(5): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation The governor shall establish the commissioner's salary within the salary range fixed by the Legislature in


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108 Commissioner's powers and duties.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1): 41-6a-310; 41-6a-1803; 53-2a-105; 41-6a-102 In addition to the responsibilities contained in this title, the commissioner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(a): administer and enforce this title and Title 41, Chapter 12a, Financial Responsibility of Motor Vehicle Owners and Operators Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(b): appoint deputies, inspectors, examiners, clerical workers, and other employees as required to properly discharge the duties of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(c): 41-6a-310 make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(c)(i): governing emergency use of signal lights on private vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(c)(ii): 41-6a-310 allowing privately owned vehicles to be designated for part-time emergency use, as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(d): 41-6a-1803 set standards for safety belt systems, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(e): 53-2a-105 serve as the cochair of the Emergency Management Administration Council, as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(f): 41-6a-102 designate vehicles as "authorized emergency vehicles," as required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(1)(g): on or before January 1, 2003, adopt a written policy that prohibits the stopping, detention, or search of any person when the action is solely motivated by considerations of race, color, ethnicity, age, or gender.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2): 56-1-21.5; 53-22-102 The commissioner may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(a): subject to the approval of the governor, establish division headquarters at various places in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(b): 56-1-21.5 issue to a special agent a certificate of authority to act as a peace officer and revoke that authority for cause, as authorized in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(c): create specialized units within the commissioner's office for conducting internal affairs and aircraft operations as necessary to protect the public safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(d): cooperate with any recognized agency in the education of the public in safety and crime prevention and participate in public or private partnerships, subject to Subsection (3);
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(e): cooperate in applying for and distributing highway safety program funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(f): receive and distribute federal funding to further the objectives of highway safety in compliance with Title 63J, Chapter 5, Federal Funds Procedures Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(g): authorize off-duty personal use of Department of Public Safety emergency vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(2)(h): 53-22-102 deny or revoke a public or private school's occupancy permit based on the recommendations of the state security chief as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(3)(a): Money may not be expended under Subsection (2)(d) for public safety education unless it is specifically appropriated by the Legislature for that purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-108(3)(b): Any recognized agency receiving state money for public safety shall file with the auditor of the state an itemized statement of all its receipts and expenditures.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109 Security for capitol complex -- Traffic and parking rules enforcement for division -- Security personnel as law enforcement officers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(1)(a): The commissioner, under the direction of the State Capitol Preservation Board, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(1)(a)(i): provide for the security of capitol hill; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(1)(a)(ii): enforce traffic provisions under Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code, and parking rules, as adopted by the State Capitol Preservation Board, for capitol hill.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(1)(b): The commissioner, in cooperation with the director of the Division of Facilities Construction and Management shall provide for the security of all grounds and buildings under the jurisdiction of the Division of Facilities Construction and Management.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(2): 53-13-103 Security personnel required in Subsection (1) shall be law enforcement officers as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(3): 53-13-105 Security personnel who were actively employed and had five or more years of active service with Protective Services within the Utah Highway Patrol Division as special function officers, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(3)(a): without a requirement of any additional training or examinations, if they have completed the entire law enforcement officer training of the Peace Officers Standards and Training Division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(3)(b): upon completing only the academic portion of the law enforcement officer training of the Peace Officers Standards and Training Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-109(4): An officer in a supervisory position with Protective Services within the Utah Highway Patrol Division shall be allowed to transfer the job title that the officer held on April 28, 1996, into a comparable supervisory position of employment as a peace officer for as long as the officer remains with Protective Services within the Utah Highway Patrol Division.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110 Compilation of highway, traffic, and driver licensing laws -- Printing and distribution -- Fees.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110(1)(a): The commissioner shall compile an edition of the general highway, traffic, and driver licensing laws of the state as soon as practicable after each regular session of the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110(1)(b): The edition shall include laws  enacted or amended by the most recent session of the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110(2): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110(2)(a): The Division of Finance shall print a sufficient quantity of the compiled highway, traffic, and driver licensing laws  to distribute copies to all state, county, and local enforcement agencies, courts, legislators, and other agencies as necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-110(2)(b): 63J-1-504 A fee may be assessed for each copy of the compilation issued by the Division of Finance. The fee shall be established by the Division of Finance in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-111 Crime prevention month -- Department of Public Safety to coordinate.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-111(1): The month of October is designated as "Crime Prevention Month."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-111(2): The department shall coordinate all activities, special programs, and promotional information to heighten public awareness and involvement in the prevention of crime in each community.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-112 Office of Executive Protection -- Creation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
There is created within the department the Office of Executive Protection.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-113 Office of Executive Protection -- Personnel.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-113(1): The commissioner shall select personnel for the Office of Executive Protection primarily from the ranks of the  Highway Patrol without competitive examination.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-113(2): Selection of personnel from other than these ranks may be made at the commissioner's discretion, provided the persons selected are peace officers.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114 Office of Executive Protection -- Security and protection for governor and family -- Protection for other officials and staff -- Training -- Equipment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(1): The Office of Executive Protection shall provide all necessary security and protection for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(1)(a): the governor and the governor's immediate family;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(1)(b): a governor-elect and the governor-elect's immediate family; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(1)(c): the capitol hill complex.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2): 20A-4-306; (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(b)(ii); (2)(c)

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(a)(i): other public officials;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(a)(ii): a public official's staff member;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(a)(iii): 20A-4-306 a candidate for an elected state office and the candidate's immediate family during the time beginning on the date of the general election and ending on the date of the meeting of the board of canvassers under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(a)(iv): an outgoing elected state official and the outgoing elected state official's immediate family.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(b): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(b)(i): (2)(a) Protection provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(b)(ii): Review and approval by the commissioner is required at the end of each 15-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(c): (2)(a) When protection is provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(2)(d): (2)(b)(ii); (2)(c) The requirement for review and approval described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(3): The Office of Executive Protection shall assess, monitor, and address any threat to a public official, a public official's staff member, or any part of the capitol hill complex.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(4): (1); (2) The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall provide weekly public protection training to members of the Office of Executive Protection who are assigned to provide security and protection to an individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(5): The commissioner or the commissioner's designee shall provide regular training to all members of the Office of Executive Protection on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(5)(a): personal protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(5)(b): special tactics;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(5)(c): facility defense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(5)(d): any other topic that, in the determination of the commissioner or the commissioner's designee, is relevant to providing for the security and protection of public officials, public officials' staff, and the capitol hill complex.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(6):

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-114(6)(b): The Office of Executive Protection shall make personal security equipment, that the commissioner determines to be reasonable, available to the public officials and public officials' staff members who work at the capitol hill complex.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115 Office of Executive Protection -- Closure of property to protect governor -- Violation of order of closure.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1)(a): "Office" includes the governor's official office and any other location not generally open to the public in which the governor is conducting the business of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1)(b): "Parking space" includes any space occupied or to be occupied by the governor's vehicle when parked, regardless of whether it is the regular parking space of the governor's vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1)(c): "Premises" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1)(c)(i): the governor's official residence, private residence, and any temporary residence owned by the governor or the governor's family; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1)(c)(ii): any temporary lodging or residence where the governor is staying or intends to stay, regardless of whether the stay is for official or other purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(1)(d): "Vehicle" includes an automobile, airplane, or other mode of conveyance in which the governor is traveling or intends to travel.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(2): A member of the Office of Executive Protection may order the closure of or restriction of access to the governor's premises or office when in the member's discretion that action is necessary to insure the safety of the governor, the governor's immediate family, or other persons within the premises or office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(3): A member of the Office of Executive Protection may order restriction of access to the governor's vehicle by ordering closure of or restriction of access to areas surrounding the vehicle, the vehicle's parking space, or the vehicle's routes of ingress or egress, when in the member's discretion that action is necessary to ensure the safety of the governor, the governor's immediate family, other persons within the vehicle, or the safe passage of persons in or out of or to or from the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(4): 53-1-114 A member of the Office of Executive Protection may order closure or restriction of access to any public property when in the member's discretion that action is necessary in the discharge of the duty to protect the governor, the governor's immediate family, or other persons for whom protection may be provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(5)(a): A member of the Office of Executive Protection may order closure of or restriction of access to privately owned property to the same extent and for the same purposes as for publicly owned property with the consent of the owner, tenant, or occupant of the private property.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(5)(b): The owner, tenant, or occupant may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(5)(b)(i): expressly ratify consent that was previously implicit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(5)(b)(ii): withdraw consent by informing a member of the Office of Executive Protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(6): An order of closure or restriction remains in effect for up to three consecutive days and may be extended beyond three days:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(6)(a): with the commissioner's approval; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(6)(b): without the commissioner's approval if immediate circumstances warrant the extension.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(7): (7)(a); (7)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(7)(a): An order closing or restricting access to property shall be posted by placing a copy of it at the primary entrance to the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(7)(b): An order restricting access to a vehicle shall be posted by placing a copy of it in the area to be closed or restricted, including the area surrounding the vehicle, the vehicle's parking space, or the vehicle's routes of ingress or egress.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(7)(c): (7)(a); (7)(b) An order is not invalidated for failure to comply with the procedures of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(8): An order shall specify the extent of the closure or restriction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(9): A person who intentionally or knowingly enters or remains within public property in violation of an order of closure or restricted access is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-115(10): This section does not restrict or limit a member of the Office of Executive Protection in exercising any other power available to the member as an officer of the law to provide for the security of the governor or the safety of the public.

A violation of this title, except for a violation under

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117 Alcohol or drug enforcement funding -- Rulemaking -- Legislative findings.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117(1): From money appropriated by the Legislature and any other funds made available for the purposes described under this section, the department shall assist the law enforcement agencies of the state and its political subdivisions in the enforcement of alcohol or drug-related offenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117(2)(a): providing equipment, including drug and alcohol testing equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117(2)(b): funding the training and overtime of peace officers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117(2)(c): managing driving under the influence related abandoned vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-117(3): The Legislature finds that the money is for a general and statewide public purpose.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121 Technology and equipment for officer-involved critical incident investigation -- Rulemaking -- Legislative findings -- Revenue fund created.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(1): The department shall assist the law enforcement agencies of the state and the state's political subdivisions to obtain technology and equipment to assist in the investigation of officer-involved critical incidents in which a firearm is used.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(2): To be eligible, the technology or equipment shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(2)(a): capable of recording actual shots fired, including the date and time, from a specific weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(2)(b): able to distinguish between actual shots fired and other, unrelated but contemporaneous, events; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(2)(c): tamper-proof and unable to be removed or manipulated by the officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(3): The department shall create a program to assist law enforcement agencies through monetary grants to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(3)(a): purchase technology and equipment to assist in the investigation of officer-involved critical incidents involving a firearm; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(3)(b): train law enforcement officers in the proper use and handling of any technology and equipment purchased in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(4)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (2) In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(4)(b): The rules shall require that funding provided to purchase technology or equipment under this section shall be matched by the requesting law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(5): The Legislature finds that the money is for a general and statewide public purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(6): Expenses accrued by the department in carrying out this section shall be provided from this appropriation, but may not exceed $40,000 annually.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(7): The Legislature shall appropriate funds to the department to use for matching grants to local law enforcement agencies to carry out the purpose of this program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(8): The department shall report annually to the Executive Offices and Criminal Justice Appropriations Subcommittee on the program. The report shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(8)(a): the total amount of appropriations received by the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(8)(b): amounts granted from the program to local law enforcement agencies, including an accounting of technology purchased by the local law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(8)(c): an accounting of any administrative expenses for the program paid out of the funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(8)(d): requests for funding that were not granted and the reason for denial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-121(8)(e): the total amount of remaining funds.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-122 Road Rage Awareness and Prevention Restricted Account.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-122(1): There is created a restricted account within the General Fund known as the Road Rage Awareness and Prevention Restricted Account.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-122(2): The account is funded by money appropriated by the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-122(3): Upon appropriation, the department shall expend funds from the restricted account to pay for an education and media campaign on road rage awareness and prevention.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-203 Creation of Administrative Services Division -- Appointment of director -- Qualifications -- Term -- Compensation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-203(1): There is created within the department the Administrative Services Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-203(2): The division shall be administered by a director appointed by the commissioner with the approval of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-203(3): The director is the executive and administrative head of the division and shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-203(4): The director acts under the supervision and control of the commissioner and may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-203(5): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act The director shall receive compensation as provided by


Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204 Division duties.
-----------------------------------------------
The division shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(1): provide administrative and staff support to the commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(2): ensure that all departmental administrative processes are in compliance with state law, rules, and procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(3): make deposits, pay all claims and obligations of the department, and conduct all treasury transactions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(4): prepare the department budget, review department expenditures, prepare financial reports, and offer general assistance with financial matters to the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(5): coordinate and review department purchases and monitor department purchasing practices to ensure compliance with state procurement rules;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(6): coordinate the purchase, operation, maintenance, records, and final disposal of the department's vehicle fleet;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(7): make capital facility plans for the department, maintain a capital equipment inventory system, coordinate risk management records, and organize waste paper recycling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-1-204(8): make rules for the department authorized by this title.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 2a - Emergency Management Act
**********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Emergency Management Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(1): "Alerting authority" means a political subdivision that has received access to send alerts through the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(2): "Attack" means a nuclear, cyber, conventional, biological, act of terrorism, or chemical warfare action against the United States of America or this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(3): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of the Department of Public Safety or the commissioner's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(4): 53-2a-103 "Director" means the division director appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(5): "Disaster" means an event that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(5)(a): causes, or threatens to cause, loss of life, human suffering, public or private property damage, or economic or social disruption resulting from attack, internal disturbance, natural phenomena, or technological hazard; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(5)(b): requires resources that are beyond the scope of local agencies in routine responses to emergencies and accidents and may be of a magnitude or involve unusual circumstances that require response by government, not-for-profit, or private entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(6): 53-2a-103 "Division" means the Division of Emergency Management created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(7): 53-2a-1402 "Emergency manager" means an individual designated as the emergency manager for a political subdivision as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(8): "Energy" includes the energy resources defined in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(9): "Expenses" means actual labor costs of government and volunteer personnel, and materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(10): "Hazardous materials emergency" means a sudden and unexpected release of any substance that because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics presents a direct and immediate threat to public safety or the environment and requires immediate action to mitigate the threat.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(11): "Internal disturbance" means a riot, prison break, terrorism, or strike.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(12): "IPAWS" means the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System administered by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(13): 10-1-104 "Municipality" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(14): "Natural phenomena" means any earthquake, tornado, storm, flood, landslide, avalanche, forest or range fire, or drought.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(15): "Officer" means a person who is elected or appointed to an office or position within a political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(16): 11-61-102 "Political subdivision" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(17): "State of emergency" means a condition in any part of this state that requires state government emergency assistance to supplement the local efforts of the affected political subdivision to save lives and to protect property, public health, welfare, or safety in the event of a disaster, or to avoid or reduce the threat of a disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(18): "Technological hazard" means any hazardous materials accident, mine accident, train derailment, air crash, radiation incident, pollution, structural fire, or explosion.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19): "Terrorism" means activities or the threat of activities that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19)(a): involve acts dangerous to human life;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19)(b): are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19)(c): to a reasonable person, would appear to be intended to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19)(c)(i): intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19)(c)(ii): influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(19)(c)(iii): affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-102(20): "Urban search and rescue" means the location, extrication, and initial medical stabilization of victims trapped in a confined space as the result of a structural collapse, transportation accident, mining accident, or collapsed trench.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-103(4): The director acts under the supervision and control of the commissioner and may be removed from the position at the will of the commissioner.

----------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(b): 53-2a-402; 53-2a-221 perform functions relating to emergency management as directed by the governor or by the commissioner, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(b)(i): 53-2a-402 coordinating with state agencies and local governments the use of personnel and other resources of these governmental entities as agents of the state during an interstate disaster in accordance with the Emergency Management Assistance Compact described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(b)(v): appointing a state recovery officer who is the governor's representative and who shall work with a federal recovery officer during a federally declared disaster;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(c)(i): prevention and minimization of injury and damage caused by disasters;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(c)(v): assistance to local officials, state agencies, and the business and public sectors, in developing emergency action plans;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(c)(x): other measures necessary, incidental, or appropriate to this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(1)(d): 53-2a-902 coordinate with local officials, state agencies, and the business and public sectors in developing, implementing, and maintaining a state energy emergency plan in accordance with Section

Chapter 50, Subchapter I, as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(2): Every three years, organizations that have the ability to send IPAWS messages, including emergency service agencies, public safety answering points, and emergency managers shall send verification of Federal Emergency Management Agency training to the Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-104(3): (3)(a); 53-2a-208

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105 Emergency Management Administration Council created -- Function -- Composition -- Expenses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(1): There is created the Emergency Management Administration Council to provide advice and coordination for state and local government agencies on government emergency prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery actions and activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(2): The council shall meet at the call of the chair, but at least semiannually.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3): The council shall be made up of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(a): lieutenant governor, or the lieutenant governor's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(b): attorney general, or the attorney general's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c): heads of the following state agencies, or their designees:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(i): Department of Public Safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(ii): Division of Emergency Management;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(iii): Department of Transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(iv): Department of Health;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(v): Department of Environmental Quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(vi): Department of Workforce Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(vii): Department of Natural Resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(viii): Department of Agriculture and Food;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(ix): Division of Technology Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(c)(x): Division of Indian Affairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(d): adjutant general of the National Guard or the adjutant general's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(e): statewide interoperability coordinator of the Utah Communications Authority or the coordinator's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(f): two representatives with expertise in emergency management appointed by the Utah League of Cities and Towns;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(g): two representatives with expertise in emergency management appointed by the Utah Association of Counties;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(h): up to four additional members with expertise in emergency management, critical infrastructure, or key resources as these terms are defined under 6 U.S. Code Section 101 appointed from the private sector, by the co-chairs of the council;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(i): two representatives appointed by the Utah Emergency Management Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(j): one representative from the Urban Area Working Group, appointed by the council co-chairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(k): one representative from education, appointed by the council co-chairs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(3)(l): one representative from a volunteer or faith-based organization, appointed by the council co-chairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(4): The commissioner and the lieutenant governor shall serve as co-chairs of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(5): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(5)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(5)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(5)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(6): 53-2a-303; 53-2a-703 The council shall coordinate with existing emergency management related entities including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(6)(a): the Emergency Management Regional Committees established by the Department of Public Safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(6)(b): 53-2a-303 the Statewide Mutual Aid Committee established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(6)(c): 53-2a-703 the Hazardous Chemical Emergency Response Commission designated under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-105(7): The council may appoint additional members or establish other committees and task forces as determined necessary by the council to carry out the duties of the council.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-106 Coordination for state development in a flood plain.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any state agency that plans to develop or construct a building within a flood plain shall consult and coordinate with the division to ensure compliance with minimum standards of the National Flood Insurance Program, 42 U.S.C. Chapter 50, Subchapter I.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-201 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Disaster Response and Recovery Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-202 Legislative findings -- Purpose.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-202(1): The Legislature finds that existing and increasing threats of the occurrence of destructive disasters resulting from attack, internal disturbance, natural phenomenon or technological hazard could greatly affect the health, safety, and welfare of the people of this state, and it is therefore necessary to grant to the governor of this state and its political subdivisions special emergency disaster authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-202(2): It is the purpose of this act to assist the governor of this state and its political subdivisions to effectively provide emergency disaster response and recovery assistance in order to protect the lives and property of the people.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301; 17B-1-309 "Chief executive officer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(a): for a municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(a)(i): the mayor for a municipality operating under all forms of municipal government except the council-manager form of government; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(a)(ii): the city manager for a municipality operating under the council-manager form of government;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(b): for a county:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(b)(i): the chair of the county commission for a county operating under the county commission or expanded county commission form of government;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(b)(ii): the county executive officer for a county operating under the county-executive council form of government; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(b)(iii): the county manager for a county operating under the council-manager form of government;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(c): 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301; 17D-1-301 for a special service district:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(c)(i): 17D-1-301 the chief executive officer of the county or municipality that created the special service district if authority has not been delegated to an administrative control board as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(c)(ii): 17D-1-301 the chair of the administrative control board to which authority has been delegated as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(c)(iii): 17D-1-301 the general manager or other officer or employee to whom authority has been delegated by the governing body of the special service district as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(d): 17B-1-309 for a special district:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(d)(i): 17B-1-309 the chair of the board of trustees selected as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(1)(d)(ii): the general manager or other officer or employee to whom authority has been delegated by the board of trustees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(2): 53-2a-209; 53-2a-204(1)(j); 53-2a-209(4) "Executive action" means any of the following actions by the governor during a state of emergency:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(2)(a): 53-2a-209 an order, a rule, or a regulation made by the governor as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(2)(b): 53-2a-204(1)(j) an action by the governor to suspend or modify a statute as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(2)(c): 53-2a-209(4) an action by the governor to suspend the enforcement of a statute as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(3): "Exigent circumstances" means a significant change in circumstances following the expiration of a state of emergency declared in accordance with this chapter that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(3)(a): substantially increases the threat to public safety or health relative to the circumstances in existence when the state of emergency expired;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(3)(b): poses an imminent threat to public safety or health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(3)(c): was not known or foreseen and could not have been known or foreseen at the time the state of emergency expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(4): 53-2a-218 "Legislative emergency response committee" means the Legislative Emergency Response Committee created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(5): "Local emergency" means a condition in any municipality or county of the state which requires that emergency assistance be provided by the affected municipality or county or another political subdivision to save lives and protect property within its jurisdiction in response to a disaster, or to avoid or reduce the threat of a disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(6): 53-2a-206(3) "Long-term state of emergency" means a state of emergency:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(6)(a): that lasts longer than 30 days; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(6)(b): 53-2a-206(3) declared to respond to exigent circumstances as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-203(7): "Political subdivision" means a municipality, county, special service district, or special district.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204 Authority of governor -- Federal assistance -- Fraud or willful misstatement in application for financial assistance -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1): 53-2a-206(5); (1)(h)(i); (1)(h)(i); 53-2a-209; 53-2a-214; (1)(h)(i); 10-8-6 In addition to any other authorities conferred upon the governor, if the governor issues an executive order declaring a state of emergency, subject to limitation by the Legislature as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(a): utilize all available resources of state government as reasonably necessary to cope with a state of emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(b): employ measures and give direction to state and local officers and agencies that are reasonable and necessary for the purpose of securing compliance with the provisions of this part and with orders, rules, and regulations made pursuant to this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(c): recommend and advise the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area within the state if necessary for the preservation of life;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(d): recommend routes, modes of transportation, and destination in connection with evacuation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(e): in connection with evacuation, suspend or limit the sale, dispensing, or transportation of alcoholic beverages, explosives, and combustibles, not to include the lawful bearing of arms;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(f): control ingress and egress to and from a disaster area, the movement of persons within the area, and recommend the occupancy or evacuation of premises in a disaster area;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(g): clear or remove from publicly or privately owned land or water debris or wreckage that is an immediate threat to public health, public safety, or private property, including allowing an employee of a state department or agency designated by the governor to enter upon private land or waters and perform any tasks necessary for the removal or clearance operation if the political subdivision, corporation, organization, or individual that is affected by the removal of the debris or wreckage:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(g)(i): presents an unconditional authorization for removal of the debris or wreckage from private property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(g)(ii): agrees to indemnify the state against any claim arising from the removal of the debris or wreckage;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(h): (1)(h)(i) enter into agreement with any agency of the United States:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(h)(i): for temporary housing units to be occupied by victims of a state of emergency or persons who assist victims of a state of emergency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(h)(ii): (1)(h)(i) to make the housing units described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(i): (1)(h)(i) assist any political subdivision of this state to acquire sites and utilities necessary for temporary housing units described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(j): 53-2a-209; 53-2a-214; (1)(h)(i) subject to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(k): 10-8-6 upon determination that a political subdivision of the state will suffer a substantial loss of tax and other revenues because of a state of emergency and the political subdivision so affected has demonstrated a need for financial assistance to perform its governmental functions, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(k)(i): apply to the federal government for a loan on behalf of the political subdivision if the amount of the loan that the governor applies for does not exceed 25% of the annual operating budget of the political subdivision for the fiscal year in which the state of emergency occurs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(k)(ii): receive and disburse the amount of the loan to the political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(l): accept funds from the federal government and make grants to any political subdivision for the purpose of removing debris or wreckage from publicly owned land or water;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(m): upon determination that financial assistance is essential to meet expenses related to a state of emergency of individuals or families adversely affected by the state of emergency that cannot be sufficiently met from other means of assistance, apply for, accept, and expend a grant by the federal government to fund the financial assistance, subject to the terms and conditions imposed upon the grant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(n): recommend to the Legislature other actions the governor considers to be necessary to address a state of emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(1)(o): authorize the use of all water sources as necessary for fire suppression.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-204(2): A person who fraudulently or willfully makes a misstatement of fact in connection with an application for financial assistance under this section shall, upon conviction of each offense, be subject to a fine of not more than $5,000 or imprisonment for not more than one year, or both.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206 State of emergency -- Declaration -- Termination -- Commander in chief of military forces.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(1): A state of emergency may be declared by executive order of the governor if the governor finds a disaster has occurred or the occurrence or threat of a disaster is imminent in any area of the state in which state government assistance is required to supplement the response and recovery efforts of the affected political subdivision or political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), a state of emergency described in Subsection (1) expires at the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(a)(i): the day on which the governor finds that the threat or danger has passed or the disaster reduced to the extent that emergency conditions no longer exist;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(a)(ii): 30 days after the date on which the governor declared the state of emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(a)(iii): the day on which the Legislature terminates the state of emergency by joint resolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(b)(i): The Legislature may, by joint resolution, extend a state of emergency for a time period designated in the joint resolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(b)(ii): If the Legislature extends a state of emergency in accordance with this subsection, the state of emergency expires on the date designated in the joint resolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(2)(c): Except as provided in Subsection (3), if a state of emergency expires as described in Subsection (2), the governor may not declare a new state of emergency for the same disaster or occurrence as the expired state of emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(3)(a): After a state of emergency expires in accordance with Subsection (2), and subject to Subsection (4), the governor may declare a new state of emergency in response to the same disaster or occurrence as the expired state of emergency, if the governor finds that exigent circumstances exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(3)(b): A state of emergency declared in accordance with Subsection (3)(a) expires in accordance with Subsections (2)(a) and (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(3)(c): After a state of emergency declared in accordance with Subsection (3)(a) expires, the governor may not declare a new state of emergency in response to the same disaster or occurrence as the expired state of emergency, regardless of whether exigent circumstances exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4): 53-2a-104; 53-2a-204; 53-2a-205
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(a)(i): If the Legislature finds that emergency conditions warrant the extension of a state of emergency beyond 30 days as described in Subsection (2)(b), the Legislature may extend the state of emergency and specify which emergency powers described in this part are necessary to respond to the emergency conditions present at the time of the extension of the state of emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(a)(ii): Circumstances that may warrant the extension of a state of emergency with limited emergency powers include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(a)(ii)(A): the imminent threat of the emergency has passed, but continued fiscal response remains necessary; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(a)(ii)(B): emergency conditions warrant certain executive actions, but certain emergency powers such as suspension of enforcement of statute are not necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b): 53-2a-104; 53-2a-204; 53-2a-205 For any state of emergency extended by the Legislature beyond 30 days as described in Subsection (2)(b), the Legislature may, by joint resolution:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b)(i): extend the state of emergency and maintain all of the emergency powers described in this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b)(ii): 53-2a-104; 53-2a-204; 53-2a-205 limit or restrict certain emergency powers of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b)(ii)(A): 53-2a-104 the division as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b)(ii)(B): 53-2a-204 the governor as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b)(ii)(C): 53-2a-205 a chief executive officer of a political subdivision as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(b)(ii)(D): other executive emergency powers described in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(c): If the Legislature limits emergency powers as described in Subsection (4)(b), the Legislature shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(c)(i): include in the joint resolution findings describing the nature and current conditions of the emergency that warrant the continuation or limitation of certain emergency powers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(c)(ii): clearly enumerate and describe in the joint resolution which powers:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(c)(ii)(A): are being limited or restricted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(4)(c)(ii)(B): shall remain in force.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(5): If the Legislature terminates a state of emergency by joint resolution, the governor shall issue an executive order ending the state of emergency on receipt of the Legislature's resolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(6): An executive order described in this section to declare a state of emergency shall state:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(6)(a): the nature of the state of emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(6)(b): the area or areas threatened; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(6)(c): the conditions creating such an emergency or those conditions allowing termination of the state of emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-206(7): During the continuance of any state of emergency the governor is commander in chief of the military forces of the state in accordance with Utah Constitution Article VII, Section 4, and Title 39A, National Guard and Militia Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208 Local emergency -- Declarations -- Termination of a local emergency.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), a chief executive officer of a municipality or county may declare by proclamation a state of emergency if the chief executive officer finds:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(1)(a)(i): a disaster has occurred or the occurrence or threat of a disaster is imminent in an area of the municipality or county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(1)(a)(ii): the municipality or county requires additional assistance to supplement the response and recovery efforts of the municipality or county.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(1)(b): A chief executive officer of a municipality may not declare by proclamation a state of emergency in response to an epidemic or a pandemic.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(2): A declaration of a local emergency:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(2)(a): constitutes an official recognition that a disaster situation exists within the affected municipality or county;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(2)(b): provides a legal basis for requesting and obtaining mutual aid or disaster assistance from other political subdivisions or from the state or federal government;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(2)(c): activates the response and recovery aspects of any and all applicable local disaster emergency plans; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(2)(d): authorizes the furnishing of aid and assistance in relation to the proclamation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(3): A local emergency proclamation issued under this section shall state:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(3)(a): the nature of the local emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(3)(b): the area or areas that are affected or threatened; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(3)(c): the conditions which caused the emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(4): 23A-1-202 The emergency declaration process within the state shall be as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(4)(a): a city or town, shall declare to the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(4)(b): a county shall declare to the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(4)(c): the state shall declare to the federal government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(4)(d): 23A-1-202 a tribe, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(5): 53-2a-206 Nothing in this part affects:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(5)(a): 53-2a-206 the governor's authority to declare a state of emergency under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(5)(b): the duties, requests, reimbursements, or other actions taken by a political subdivision participating in the state-wide mutual aid system pursuant to Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 3, Statewide Mutual Aid Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (6)(b), a state of emergency described in Subsection (1) expires the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a)(i): the day on which the chief executive officer finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a)(i)(A): the threat or danger has passed;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a)(i)(B): the disaster reduced to the extent that emergency conditions no longer exist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a)(i)(C): the municipality or county no longer requires state government assistance to supplement the response and recovery efforts of the municipality or county;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a)(ii): 30 days after the day on which the chief executive officer declares the state of emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(a)(iii): the day on which the legislative body of the municipality or county terminates the state of emergency by majority vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b)(i)(A): The legislative body of a municipality may at any time terminate by majority vote a state of emergency declared by the chief executive officer of the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b)(i)(B): The legislative body of a county may at any time terminate by majority vote a state of emergency declared by the chief executive officer of the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b)(ii): The legislative body of a municipality or county may by majority vote extend a state of emergency for a time period stated in the motion.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b)(iii): If the legislative body of a municipality or county extends a state of emergency in accordance with this subsection, the state of emergency expires on the date designated by the legislative body in the motion.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(b)(iv): An action by a legislative body of a municipality or county to terminate a state of emergency as described in this Subsection (6)(b) is not subject to veto by the relevant chief executive officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(6)(c): Except as provided in Subsection (7), after a state of emergency expires in accordance with this Subsection (6), the chief executive officer may not declare a new state of emergency in response to the same disaster or occurrence as the expired state of emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(7)(a): After a state of emergency expires in accordance with Subsection (6), the chief executive officer may declare a new state of emergency in response to the same disaster or occurrence as the expired state of emergency, if the chief executive officer finds that exigent circumstances exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(7)(b): A state of emergency declared in accordance with Subsection (7)(a) expires in accordance with Subsections (6)(a) and (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-208(7)(c): After a state of emergency declared in accordance with Subsection (7)(a) expires, the chief executive officer may not declare a new state of emergency in response to the same disaster or occurrence as the expired state of emergency, regardless of whether exigent circumstances exist.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211 Acquisition of property for public use -- Compensation of owners.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1)(a): Upon proclamation of a state of emergency, the governor may purchase or lease public or private property for public use including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1)(a)(i): food and medical supplies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1)(a)(ii): clothing;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1)(a)(vi): oils; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1)(a)(vii): buildings or lands.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(1)(b): The governor may not purchase private home storage nor privately owned arms.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(2)(a): The governor may use property purchased under authority of this section for any purpose to meet the needs of an emergency, including its use to relieve want, distress, and disease.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(2)(b): Any property used by the governor to meet the needs of an emergency is a public use.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(3): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 5, Eminent Domain; Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 6, Disaster Recovery Funding Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(3)(a): Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 5, Eminent Domain The governor shall compensate the owner of property taken or used under authority of this section by complying with the procedures established in
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(3)(b): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 6, Disaster Recovery Funding Act The governor shall pay for those purchases or leases from the funds available to the Division of Emergency Management under:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(3)(b)(i): this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(3)(b)(ii): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 6, Disaster Recovery Funding Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-211(4): Nothing in this section applies to or authorizes compensation for the destruction or damage of standing timber or other property in order to provide a fire break or to the release of waters or the breach of impoundments in order to reduce pressure or other danger from actual or threatened flood.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-212 Interstate agreements authorized -- Termination -- Mutual-aid compacts between subdivisions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-212(1): The governor is authorized to execute an interstate agreement or compact on behalf of this state with any other state or states only consistent with the powers herein granted concerning matters relating to a disaster affecting or likely to affect this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-212(2): The agreement or compact shall continue in force and remain binding on each party state until the Legislature or the governor of a party state takes action to withdraw.  The action is not effective until 30 days after notice thereof has been sent by the governor of such party state desiring to withdraw to the governors of all other party states.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-212(3): Political subdivisions are authorized to enter into mutual-aid compacts with other political subdivisions within the state of Utah concerning matters involving cooperative disaster response and recovery assistance support, consistent with this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-213 Authority additional to other emergency authority.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-213(1): The special disaster emergency authority vested in the governor and political subdivisions of the state pursuant to this part shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other emergency authority otherwise constitutionally or statutorily vested in the governor and political subdivisions of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-213(2): The provisions of this chapter supersede and preempt any provision of law of a political subdivision of the state pertaining to disaster and emergency response.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218 Legislative Emergency Response Committee.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(1): There is created an ad hoc committee known as the Legislative Emergency Response Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2): (2)(a)(ii); (iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a): The committee membership includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(i): the same membership as the Executive Appropriations Committee as constituted at the time the committee is convened;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(ii): between four and six additional members designated by the speaker of the House of Representatives, chosen from the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(ii)(A): one or more members of the House of Representatives that serve as chair or vice-chair of a legislative committee with a subject matter focus relevant to the current emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(ii)(B): one or more members of the House of Representatives with relevant expertise or experience relevant to the current emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(ii)(C): one or more members of the House of Representatives from a minority party that serves on a relevant legislative committee or that has expertise and experience relevant to the current emergency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(iii): between four and six additional members designated by the president of the Senate, chosen from the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(iii)(A): one or more members of the Senate that serve as chair or vice-chair of a legislative committee with a subject matter focus relevant to the current emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(iii)(B): one or more members of the Senate with relevant expertise or experience relevant to the current emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(a)(iii)(C): one or more members of the Senate from a minority party that serves on a relevant legislative committee or that has expertise and experience relevant to the current emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(2)(b): (2)(a)(ii); (iii) The speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate shall coordinate to ensure they each appoint the same number of legislators as described under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(3): The speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate shall serve as chairs of the committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(4): The Office of Legislative Research and General Counsel shall provide staff support to the committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(5)(a): 53-2a-206 If the governor declares a state of emergency as described in this chapter, and the governor finds that the emergency conditions warrant an extension of the state of emergency beyond the 30-day term or another date designated by the Legislature as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(5)(b): (5)(a); 26B-7-317; 26A-1-121 If the speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate receive notice as described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-218(5)(b)(ii): may jointly convene the committee.
