Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219 Religious practice during a state of emergency.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(1): During a state of emergency declared as described in this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(1)(a): the governor or chief executive officer of a political subdivision may not impose a restriction on a religious gathering that is more restrictive than a restriction on any other relevantly similar gathering; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(1)(b): an individual, while acting or purporting to act within the course and scope of the individual's official government capacity, may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(1)(b)(i): prevent a religious gathering that is held in a manner consistent with any order or restriction issued pursuant to this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(1)(b)(ii): impose a penalty for a previous religious gathering that was held in a manner consistent with any order or restriction issued pursuant to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(2): Upon proper grounds, a court of competent jurisdiction may grant an injunction to prevent the violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(3): During a state of emergency declared as described in this title, the governor or the chief executive of a political subdivision shall not issue an executive order or impose or implement a regulation that substantially burdens an individual's exercise of religion unless the governor or chief executive officer of the political subdivision demonstrates that the application of the burden to the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(3)(a): is in furtherance of a compelling government interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(3)(b): is the least restrictive means of furthering that compelling government interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-219(4): (1); (3) Notwithstanding Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221 State and local disaster response personnel.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(1)(a): "Local disaster response personnel" means a local government employee who, in accordance with this section, is reassigned duties in order to respond to a disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(1)(b): "Local government" means a municipality or county.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(1)(c): "State agency" means any department or unit of Utah state government with authority to employ personnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(1)(d): "State disaster response personnel" means an employee of a state agency or local government who, in accordance with this section, is reassigned duties in order to respond to a disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(2): 53-2a-206; (6); 53-2a-208; (6)

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(3): 53-2a-104; 53-2a-1403
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(3)(a): 53-2a-104 During a state emergency, a state disaster response personnel shall perform duties as assigned in accordance with an emergency operations plan adopted by the division under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(3)(b): 53-2a-1403 During a local emergency, a local disaster response personnel shall perform duties as assigned in accordance with an emergency operations plan adopted by a county or municipality under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(4): (2)(a); (2)(b) After a declaration of emergency as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(5): (4); (3)(a); (3)(b); (5)(b)(i); (5)(b)(ii)

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(5)(b)(ii): the employee's health precludes the employee from performing the duties otherwise assigned to that employee in accordance with the plan.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(6): An employee shall perform his or her assigned state or local disaster response personnel duties only for the duration of the declared state or local emergency, respectively, or until the disaster response duties are no longer needed, whichever occurs first.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(7): A state or local disaster response personnel may not be assigned to perform duties:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(7)(a): that are technical in nature unless the state or local disaster response personnel is trained to perform those duties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(7)(b): that the state or local disaster response personnel is physically not capable of performing.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(9): A state agency or local government:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(9)(a): may not decrease a state or local disaster response personnel's pay only because the state or local disaster response personnel is performing duties as assigned during the emergency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(9)(b): at the state agency's or local government's discretion, may increase a state or local disaster response personnel's pay; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-221(9)(c): shall reimburse a state or local disaster response personnel for incidentals incurred, including any relocation expenses, while the employee is performing his or her duties as a state or local disaster response personnel.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Statewide Mutual Aid Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1): "Emergency responder":
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(a): means a person in the public or private sector:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(a)(i): who has special skills, qualification, training, knowledge, or experience, whether or not possessing a license, certificate, permit, or other official recognition for the skills, qualification, training, knowledge, or experience, that would benefit a participating political subdivision in responding to a locally declared emergency or in an authorized drill or exercise; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(a)(ii): whom a participating political subdivision requests or authorizes to assist in responding to a locally declared emergency or in an authorized drill or exercise; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b): includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(i): a law enforcement officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(ii): a firefighter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(iii): an emergency medical services worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(iv): a physician, physician assistant, nurse, or other public health worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(v): an emergency management official;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(vi): a public works worker;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(vii): a building inspector;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(viii): an architect, engineer, or other design professional; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(1)(b)(ix): a person with specialized equipment operations skills or training or with any other skills needed to provide aid in a declared emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(2): 53-2a-306 "Participating political subdivision" means each county, municipality, public safety district, and public safety interlocal entity that has not adopted a resolution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(3): Title 17B, Limited Purpose Local Government Entities - Special Districts; Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act "Public safety district" means a special district under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(4): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act "Public safety interlocal entity" means an interlocal entity under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(5): "Public safety service" means a service provided to the public to protect life and property and includes fire protection, police protection, emergency medical service, and hazardous material response service.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(6): 53-2a-207 "Requesting political subdivision" means a participating political subdivision that requests emergency assistance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(7): 53-2a-307 "Responding political subdivision" means a participating political subdivision that responds to a request under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(8): "State" means the state of Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-302(9): "Statewide mutual aid system" or "system" means the aggregate of all participating political subdivisions and the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303 Statewide mutual aid committee.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1): (1)(a)(ii); (v)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(a): There is established a statewide mutual aid committee consisting of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(a)(i): the director, who shall chair the committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(a)(ii): one or more representatives from state agencies that provide public safety service, appointed by the director;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(a)(iii): one or more representatives of counties, appointed by the director after considering recommendations from the Utah Association of Counties;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(a)(iv): one or more representatives of municipalities, appointed by the director after considering recommendations from the Utah League of Cities and Towns; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(a)(v): one or more representatives of public safety districts and public safety interlocal entities, appointed by the director after considering recommendations from the Utah Association of Special Districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(b): (1)(a)(ii); (v) The term of each member appointed under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(1)(c): A committee member may not receive compensation for service on the committee in addition to any compensation received as an employee or official of a state agency or participating political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(2): The committee shall meet at least annually to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(2)(a): review the progress and status of the statewide mutual aid system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(2)(b): assist in developing methods to track and evaluate activation of the system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(2)(c): examine issues facing participating political subdivisions regarding implementation of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(3): The committee shall develop comprehensive guidelines and procedures that address the operation of the system, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(3)(a): projected or anticipated costs of responding to emergencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(3)(b): checklists for requesting and providing assistance;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(3)(c): record keeping for participating political subdivisions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(3)(d): reimbursement procedures and other necessary implementation elements and necessary forms for requests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(3)(e): other records documenting deployment and return of assets.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-303(4): The committee may prepare an annual report on the condition and effectiveness of the statewide mutual aid system, make recommendations for correcting any deficiencies, and submit the report to an appropriate legislative committee.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-304 Withdrawal from the statewide mutual aid system.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A county, municipality, public safety district, or public safety interlocal entity may withdraw from the statewide mutual aid system by:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-304(1): enacting a resolution declaring that it elects not to participate in the system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-304(2): delivering a copy of the resolution to the director.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-305 Agreements not affected by this part.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part may be construed:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-305(1): to limit the state, a county, municipality, special district, special service district, or interlocal entity from entering into an agreement allowed by law for public safety and related purposes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-305(2): to affect an agreement to which the state, a county, municipality, special district, special service district, or interlocal entity is a party.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-306(1): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 4, Emergency Management Assistance Compact; Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 4, Emergency Management Assistance Compact The division shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-306(2): Each participating political subdivision in the Statewide Mutual Aid Act shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-306(2)(a): identify potential hazards that could affect the participating political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-306(2)(b): conduct joint planning, intelligence sharing, and threat assessment development with contiguous participating political subdivisions and conduct joint training with them at least biennially;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-306(2)(c): identify and inventory the services, equipment, supplies, personnel, and other resources related to participating political subdivision's planning, prevention, mitigation, response, and recovery activities; and

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307 Requests for disaster assistance or assistance with an authorized drill or exercise.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(1): The state or a participating political subdivision may request another participating political subdivision to assist:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(1)(a): in preventing, mitigating, responding to, or recovering from a disaster, if the requesting political subdivision declares a local emergency or the state has declared a state of emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(1)(b): with a drill or exercise that the state or requesting political subdivision has authorized.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(2): (1) Each request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(2)(a): made by the chief executive officer of the state or participating political subdivision or the officer's designee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(2)(b): reported as soon as practical to the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(3): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(3)(a): (1) A request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(3)(b): Each request communicated orally shall be reduced to writing and delivered to the other participating political subdivision:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(3)(b)(i): as soon as practical; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(3)(b)(ii): within the number of days specified by the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(4): (1) In responding to a request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(4)(a): donate assets of any kind to a requesting political subdivision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(4)(b): withhold its resources to the extent necessary to provide reasonable protection and services for its own residents.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-307(5): The emergency response personnel, equipment, and other assets of a responding political subdivision or the state shall be under the operational control of the incident management system of the state or requesting political subdivision, except to the extent that the exercise of operational control would result in a violation of a policy, standard, procedure, or protocol of the responding political subdivision or of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309 Personnel responding to requests for assistance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(1): Each person or entity holding a license, certificate, or other permit evidencing qualification in a professional, mechanical, or other skill and responding to a request from a requesting political subdivision shall, while providing assistance during a declared emergency or during an authorized drill or exercise, be considered to be licensed, certified, or permitted in the requesting political subdivision, except as limited by the chief executive officer of the requesting political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(2): Each law enforcement officer rendering aid as provided in this part under the authority of a state of emergency declared by the governor, whether inside or outside the officer's jurisdiction, has all law enforcement powers and the same privileges and immunities that the officer has in the officer's own jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(3): Each employee of a responding political subdivision responding to a request by or giving assistance to a requesting political subdivision or the state as provided in this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(3)(a): is entitled to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(3)(a)(i): all applicable workers compensation benefits for injury or death occurring as a result of the employee's participation in the response or assistance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(3)(a)(ii): any additional state or federal benefits available for line of duty injury or death; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(3)(b): is, for purposes of liability, considered to be an employee of the requesting political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-309(4): 63G-7-201 Each responding political subdivision and its employees are immune from liability arising out of their actions in responding to a request from a requesting political subdivision to the extent provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-310 Severability.
---------------------------------------------
A court order declaring any provision of this part unconstitutional or invalid may not be construed to affect the validity of any other provision of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-501 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Interstate Emergency Responder Mutual Aid Agreement."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(1): 63G-7-102 "Claim" has the same definition as in the following sections, as applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(1)(a): Section 6-902, Idaho Code; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(1)(b): 63G-7-102 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(2): "Emergency":
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(2)(a): means a situation where it reasonably appears that the life or safety of a person is at peril or real or personal property is at risk of destruction or loss;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(2)(b): includes disasters, fires, persons who are lost or missing, boats that are sinking or are in danger of sinking, medical situations where care is needed, and transportation of persons by ambulance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(2)(c): is not limited in duration to a discrete period of time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(a): "Emergency responder" means a person whose duties include providing services to protect property or the life or safety of any person and who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(a)(i): employed by a governmental entity of another state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(a)(ii): temporarily employed by a governmental entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(a)(iii): a volunteer who is serving at the request of a governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(b): "Emergency responder" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(b)(i): law enforcement officers, fire fighters, search and rescue personnel, emergency medical technicians, ambulance personnel, Department of Natural Resources employees, park rangers, public utilities workers, and volunteers participating in search and rescue and other emergency management operations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(3)(b)(ii): persons and parties identified in the interstate mutual aid agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(4): "Interstate mutual aid agreement" means an agreement that establishes procedures for claims against an out-of-state emergency responder, and that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(4)(a): is established reciprocally between the Utah Highway Patrol and the Idaho State Police;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(4)(b): is on file with the Utah Highway Patrol; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-502(4)(c): has a duration of one year from the time the agreement is entered into by Utah and Idaho.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-503 Notice of claim requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-503(1): Any claim against an emergency responder or the responder's employer shall be treated for the purpose of a notice of claim as a claim against the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-503(2): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah The person making the claim shall comply with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-503(2)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-503(2)(b): any notice of claim requirements of the state where the emergency responder resides or is employed as an emergency responder.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-503(3): The person filing the claim shall provide a copy of the notice of claim with the Idaho secretary of state if the claim is filed in Utah, or with the Utah attorney general if the claim is filed in Idaho.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-504 Emergency responder entering Utah to respond to an emergency.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An emergency responder who enters into Utah in response to a request for assistance by an official or emergency responder of Utah or pursuant to an agreement providing for interstate mutual aid is considered to be responding to an emergency.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-505 Privileges and immunities of law enforcement officers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any law enforcement officer of another state and the officer's employer are specifically entitled to the application of this part if the law enforcement officer is empowered to act under Section 19-701, Idaho Code, or an interstate mutual aid agreement.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-506 Privileges and immunities of emergency responders.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-506(1): An emergency responder from another state who enters into this state has the same authority to act as an emergency responder of this state while:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-506(1)(a): responding to an emergency, including providing care; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-506(1)(b): providing aid or assistance at the request of a public agency in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-506(2): All privileges and immunities from liability, exemption from law, ordinances, and rules, and any other benefits, which apply to an emergency responder while performing duties in the responder's state of residence or state of employment as a responder, apply when the emergency responder is acting as an emergency responder in this state.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-507(1): (1)(a) The Legislature finds, with regard to emergency responders, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-507(1)(a): Title 6, Chapter 9, of the Idaho Code, regarding the governmental immunity laws of Idaho, is consistent with the public policy of Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-507(1)(b): (1)(a) based on the legislative finding under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-507(2): 63G-7-604 The Legislature finds:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-507(2)(a): 63G-7-604 the damage caps in the governmental immunity laws of Idaho, although not identical to the damage caps under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-507(2)(b): the damage caps of Idaho apply to any claim, including any lawsuit, brought against an emergency responder, who resides in or is employed as an emergency responder in Idaho, and the emergency responder's employer, based on the emergency responder's actions in Utah when acting as an emergency responder.

This part is known as the "Disaster Recovery Funding Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-602(1): Part 1, Emergency Management Act Unless otherwise defined in this section, the terms that are used in this part mean the same as those terms are defined in

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-602(2)(b)(iv): that are sudden in nature and generally occur less frequently than every three years; and

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605 Local government disaster funds.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1): 51-7-11; 51-7-3
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(a): Subject to this section and notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in Title 10, Utah Municipal Code, or Title 17, Counties, Title 17B, Limited Purpose Local Government Entities - Special Districts, or Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act, the governing body of a local government may create and maintain by ordinance a special fund known as a local government disaster fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(b): The local fund shall consist of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(b)(i): subject to the limitations of this section, money transferred to it in accordance with Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(b)(ii): any other public or private money received by the local government that is:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(b)(ii)(B)(I): the governing body of the local government; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(b)(ii)(B)(II): the person giving the money; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(b)(iii): interest or income realized from the local fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(c): Interest or income realized from the local fund shall be deposited into the local fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(d): 51-7-11; 51-7-3 Money in a local fund may be:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(d)(i): 51-7-11 deposited or invested as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(d)(ii): 51-7-3 transferred by the local government treasurer to the Public Treasurers' Investment Fund as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(e)(i): The money in a local fund may accumulate from year to year until the local government governing body determines to spend any money in the local fund for one or more of the purposes specified in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(e)(ii): Money in a local fund at the end of a fiscal year:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(e)(ii)(A): shall remain in the local fund for future use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(1)(e)(ii)(B): may not be transferred to any other fund or used for any other purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(2): The amounts transferred to a local fund may not exceed 10% of the total estimated revenues of the local government for the current fiscal period that are not restricted or otherwise obligated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(3): Money in the fund may only be used to fund the services and activities of the local government creating the local fund in response to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-605(3)(a): a declared disaster within the boundaries of the local government;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-801 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Emergency Interim Succession Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(1)(a): "Absent" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(1)(a)(i): not physically present or not able to be communicated with for 48 hours; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(1)(a)(ii): for local government officers, as defined by local ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(1)(b): "Absent" does not include a person who can be communicated with via telephone, radio, or telecommunications.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(2): "Department" means the Department of Government Operations, the Department of Agriculture and Food, the Alcoholic Beverage Services Commission, the Department of Commerce, the Department of Cultural and Community Engagement, the Department of Corrections, the Department of Environmental Quality, the Department of Financial Institutions, the Department of Health and Human Services, the Department of Workforce Services, the Labor Commission, the National Guard, the Department of Insurance, the Department of Natural Resources, the Department of Public Safety, the Public Service Commission, the State Tax Commission, the Department of Transportation, any other major administrative subdivisions of state government, the State Board of Education, the Utah Board of Higher Education, the Utah Housing Corporation, the State Retirement Board, and each institution of higher education within the system of higher education.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(3): "Division" means the Division of Emergency Management established in Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 1, Emergency Management Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(4): "Emergency interim successor" means a person designated by this part to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of an office when the person legally exercising the powers and duties of the office is unavailable.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(5): "Executive director" means the person with ultimate responsibility for managing and overseeing the operations of each department, however denominated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(6)(a): "Office" includes all state and local offices, the powers and duties of which are defined by constitution, statutes, charters, optional plans, ordinances, articles, or by-laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(6)(b): "Office" does not include the office of governor or the legislative or judicial offices.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(7): "Place of governance" means the physical location where the powers of an office are being exercised.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(8): "Political subdivision" includes counties, cities, towns, districts, authorities, and other public corporations and entities whether organized and existing under charter or general law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(9): "Political subdivision officer" means a person holding an office in a political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(10): "State officer" means the attorney general, the state treasurer, the state auditor, and the executive director of each department.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(11): "Unavailable" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(11)(a): absent from the place of governance during a disaster that seriously disrupts normal governmental operations, whether or not that absence or inability would give rise to a vacancy under existing constitutional or statutory provisions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-802(11)(b): as otherwise defined by local ordinance.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-803 Emergency interim successor to office of governor.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-803(1): If the governor is unavailable, and if the lieutenant governor, president of the Senate, and the speaker of the House of Representatives are unavailable to exercise the powers and duties of the office of governor, the attorney general, state auditor, or state treasurer shall, in the order named, exercise the powers and duties of the office of governor until:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-803(1)(a): the governor, lieutenant governor, president of the Senate, or speaker of the House of Representatives becomes available; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-803(1)(b): a new governor is elected and qualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-803(2): (1) Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804 Emergency interim successors for state officers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(1): By July 1 of each year, each state officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(1)(a): designate three qualified emergency interim successors from within the state officer's department who meet the constitutional qualifications for the office, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(1)(b): specify their order of succession;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(1)(c): provide a list of those designated successors to the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(1)(d): notify emergency interim successors within 30 days of designation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(a): If any state officer is unavailable following a disaster, and if the state officer's deputy, if any, is also unavailable, a designated emergency interim successor shall exercise the powers and duties of the office according to the order of succession specified by the state officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(b): An emergency interim successor other than the attorney general, state auditor, or state treasurer shall exercise the state officer's powers and duties only until:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(b)(i): the person exercising the powers and duties of the office of governor appoints a successor to fill the vacancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(b)(ii): a permanent successor is appointed or elected and qualified as provided by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(b)(iii): the state officer, the state officer's deputy, or an emergency interim successor earlier in the order of succession becomes available to exercise or resume the exercise of the powers and duties of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(c): An emergency interim successor of the attorney general, state auditor, or state treasurer shall exercise the powers and duties of those offices only until:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(c)(i): a permanent successor is appointed or elected and qualified as provided by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-804(2)(c)(ii): the attorney general, state auditor, or state treasurer, their deputy, or an emergency interim successor earlier in the order of succession becomes available to exercise or resume the exercise of the powers and duties of the office.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-805 Division to consult with legislative and judicial branch.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Division of Emergency Management may consult with the Legislative Management Committee, the Judicial Council, and legislative and judicial staff offices to assist the division in preparing emergency succession plans and procedures.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-806 Place of legislative session.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-806(1): If the governor or the governor's interim successor declares a state of emergency or finds that a state of emergency is imminent, and the governor or the interim successor determines that the prescribed place of session is unsafe, the governor may change the place of session to any place in Utah that the governor considers safe and convenient.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-806(2): Each legislator shall proceed to the place of session as expeditiously as practicable.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807 Emergency interim successors for local officers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(1): Part 14, Local Emergency Management Act By July 1 of each year, each political subdivision shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(1)(a): Part 14, Local Emergency Management Act for each officer and the emergency manager described in
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(1)(b): identify the political subdivision's alerting authority and any individuals authorized to send emergency alerts;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(1)(c): provide a list of those designated successors and individuals to the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(1)(d): have an emergency alert plan in place and provide a copy of the plan to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(2): (1) In the event that a political subdivision does not designate emergency interim successors as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(2)(a): the chief executive officer of the political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(2)(b): the chief deputy executive officer of the political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(2)(c): the chair of the legislative body of the political subdivision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(2)(d): the chief law enforcement officer of the political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3)(a): Notwithstanding any other provision of law:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3)(a)(i): if any political subdivision officer or the political subdivision officer's legal deputy, if any, is unavailable, a designated emergency interim successor shall exercise the powers and duties of the office according to the order of succession specified by the political subdivision officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3)(a)(ii): counties may provide by ordinance that one member of the county legislative body may act as the county legislative body if the other members are absent.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3)(b): An emergency interim successor shall exercise the powers and duties of the office only until:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3)(b)(i): the vacancy is filled in accordance with the constitution or statutes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(3)(b)(ii): the political subdivision officer, the political subdivision officer's deputy, or an emergency interim successor earlier in the order of succession becomes available to exercise the powers and duties of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-807(4): The legislative bodies of each political subdivision may enact resolutions or ordinances consistent with this part and also provide for emergency interim successors to officers of the political subdivision not governed by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-808 Formalities of taking office.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-808(1): At the time that they are appointed as emergency interim successors or special emergency judges, emergency interim successors and special emergency judges shall sign prospectively whatever oath is required to enable them to exercise the powers and duties of the office to which they may succeed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-808(2): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no person is required to comply with any other provision of law relative to taking office as a prerequisite to the exercise of the powers or discharge of the duties of an office to which the person succeeds.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809 Period in which authority may be exercised.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(1): Persons authorized to act as governor, emergency interim successors, and special emergency judges shall exercise the powers and duties of the office to which they succeed only when a disaster has occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(2)(a): Emergency interim successors serve for 30 days after the date the governor or the governor's emergency successor calls the Legislature into special session, unless the unavailability of the elected official ends or an emergency interim successor earlier in the order of succession becomes available before expiration of the 30-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(2)(b): (2)(a) Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(3): The Legislature, by concurrent resolution, may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(3)(a): terminate the authority of any or all emergency interim successors and special emergency judges to exercise the powers and duties of their office at any time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-809(3)(b): extend the time during which any or all emergency interim successors and special emergency judges may exercise the powers and duties of their office.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-810 Removal of designees.
-----------------------------------------------------
Until the persons designated as emergency interim successors or special emergency judges succeed to the exercise of the powers and duties of an office, they shall serve as emergency interim successors or special emergency judges at the pleasure of the designating authority and may be removed and replaced by the designating authority at any time, with or without cause.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-811 Disputes.
-----------------------------------------
Except for factual disputes concerning the office of governor, the governor shall adjudicate any dispute concerning a question of fact arising under this part concerning a state officer.  The governor's decision is final.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-812 Governor to declare location of emergency seat of government.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-812(1): Whenever, due to an emergency resulting from the effects of a disaster, it becomes imprudent, inexpedient, or impossible to conduct the affairs of the state government in Salt Lake City, Utah, the governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-812(1)(a): by proclamation, declare an emergency temporary location for the seat of government in Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-812(1)(b): take whatever action and issue whatever orders are necessary for an orderly transition of the affairs of the state government to that emergency temporary location.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-812(2): That emergency temporary location shall remain as the seat of government until the Legislature establishes a new location by law, or until the emergency is declared to be ended by the governor and the seat of government is returned to its normal location.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-812(3): Local governments may provide, by ordinance, for temporary emergency locations for the seat of government.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-813 Official acts at emergency seat of government -- Validity.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
During the time when the seat of government remains at an emergency location, all official acts required by law to be performed at the seat of government by any officer, agency, department, or authority of this state or local government, including the convening and meeting of the Legislature in regular, extraordinary, or emergency session, shall be as valid and binding as when performed at the normal location of the seat of government.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1001 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Energy Emergency Powers of the Governor Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1002 Legislative findings and purpose.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1002(1): The Legislature finds that the lack of energy resources and other energy resource emergencies may threaten the availability of essential services and transportation and the operation of the economy, jeopardizing the peace, health, safety, and welfare of the people of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1002(2): The Legislature further finds that it is necessary to provide an orderly procedure for anticipating and responding to energy resource shortages and disruptions and to grant, under conditions prescribed in this part, emergency powers to the governor to order involuntary curtailments in the use of energy resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1002(3): The Legislature further finds and declares that it is the policy of this state to assist the United States in effective management and control of factors and situations as contribute to an emergency affecting or likely to affect this state; to cooperate with other states in matters related to an emergency affecting or likely to affect this state; to meet extraordinary conditions in this state arising out of the crisis by taking steps as are necessary and appropriate; and generally to protect the peace, health, safety, and welfare of the people of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1003 "Energy resources" defined.
------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "energy resources" includes electricity, natural gas, gasoline and middle distillates, coal, wood fuels, geothermal sources, radioactive materials, and any other resource yielding energy.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004 Information-gathering powers -- Subpoena power -- Coordination with other regulatory authorities.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(1): (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(c) On a continuing basis the governor may obtain all necessary information from energy resource producers, manufacturers, suppliers, and consumers doing business within, and from political subdivisions in, this state as necessary to determine whether shortages or an emergency will require energy resource conservation measures.  This information may include, but shall not be limited to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(1)(a): sales volumes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(1)(b): forecasts of energy resource requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(1)(c): from manufacturers, suppliers, and consumers, an inventory of energy resources; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(1)(d): (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(c) local distribution patterns of the information described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(2): (1)(c); (1) In obtaining information at any time from energy resource producers, manufacturers, suppliers, or consumers under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(3): In obtaining information under this section the governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(3)(a): seek to avoid eliciting information already furnished by a person or political subdivision in this state to a federal, state, or local regulatory authority that is available for the governor's study; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1004(3)(b): cause reporting procedures, including forms, to conform to existing requirements of federal, state, and local regulatory authorities wherever possible.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1005 Confidential nature of information preserved -- Relief from subpoena -- Unauthorized disclosure as misdemeanor -- Removal from office.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1005(1): 53-2a-1004; (4); (5) Information furnished pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1005(2): Nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of confidential information to prepare statistics or other general data for publication, so presented as to prevent identification of particular persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1005(3): Any person who is served with a subpoena to give testimony orally or in writing, or to produce books, papers, correspondence, memoranda, agreements, or other documents or records pursuant to this part may apply to any district court of this state for protection against abuse or hardship in the manner provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1005(4): References to the governor in this section include the governor and any other individuals designated for this purpose in writing by the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1005(5): Any person who wilfully discloses confidential information in violation of this section is guilty of a class A misdemeanor and, in addition, may be subject to removal from office or immediate dismissal from public employment.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1006 Curtailment of energy use -- Standby priorities -- Restriction on involuntary curtailment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In consultation with appropriate federal and state officials and officials of political subdivisions in this state, the governor shall cause to be established, and revised as appropriate, standby priorities for curtailment in the use of energy resources.  Involuntary curtailments, however, may be ordered only by means of executive orders issued pursuant to this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008 Curtailment, adjustment, and allocation of energy use by executive orders -- Limitations and considerations in issuance and application.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(1): 53-2a-1007 Upon issuance of a proclamation pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(1)(a): require reduction in energy resource usage and the application of conservation, prevention of waste, and the salvaging of energy resources and the materials, services, and facilities derived therefrom or dependent thereon, by state agencies and political subdivisions in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(1)(b): direct the establishment by state agencies and political subdivisions in this state of programs necessary to implement and comply with federal energy conservation programs where these programs have not theretofore been so established, including, but not limited to, allocation or rationing of energy resources and the distribution of the state's discretionary allotments;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(1)(c): require involuntary curtailments, adjustments, or allocations in the supply and consumption of energy resources applicable to all suppliers and consumers including, but not limited to, specification of the times and manner in which these resources are supplied or consumed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(1)(d): prescribe and direct activities promoting the conservation, prevention of waste, and salvage of energy resources and the materials, services, and facilities derived therefrom or dependent thereon, including, but not limited to, the modification of transportation routes and schedules, or the suspension of weight limits or other restrictions from the transportation of energy resources, to the extent permissible under federal law and regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(2): (1) Any restrictions, curtailments, adjustments, or allocations pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(2)(a): be ordered and continue only so long as demonstrably necessary for the maintenance of essential services or transportation, or the continued operation of the economy but no longer than the duration of the proclamation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(2)(b): be applied as uniformly as practicable within each class of suppliers and consumers and without discrimination within a class; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1008(2)(c): give due consideration to the needs of commercial, retail, professional, and service establishments whose normal function is to supply goods or services or both of an essential nature, including, but not limited to, food, lodging, fuel, or medical care facilities during times of the day other than conventional daytime working hours.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1009 Other emergency powers of governor unaffected.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The powers vested in the governor under this part shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other emergency powers otherwise constitutionally or statutorily vested in the governor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1010 Existing agencies to be used in implementation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The governor shall use, to the extent practicable, existing state boards, commissions, or agencies or officers or employees for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1011 Enforcement of orders and rules.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The governor may apply to any district court for appropriate equitable relief against any person violating or failing to carry out the provisions of this part or any order or rule issued pursuant to this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1012 Rules and regulations -- Approval by Legislature.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The board, commission, or agency designated by the governor for carrying out the provisions of this part is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations as are necessary for effective administration of this part with approval of the Legislature.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Search and Rescue Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1201 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Facilitating Business Rapid Response to State Declared Disasters Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(1): 53-2a-602 "Declared state disaster or emergency" means a declared disaster as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(2): "Disaster- or emergency-related work" means repairing, renovating, installing, building, rendering services, or other business activities that relate to infrastructure that has been damaged, impaired, or destroyed by a declared state disaster or emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(3): "Disaster period" means a period that begins within 10 days after the first day of a declared state disaster or emergency and that extends for a period of 60 calendar days after the end of the declared state disaster or emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(4): "Infrastructure" means property and equipment owned or used by communications networks, electric generation systems, transmission and distribution systems, gas distribution systems, water pipelines, and related support facilities that serve multiple customers or citizens, including real and personal property, such as buildings, offices, power and communication lines and poles, pipes, structures, and equipment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(5): "Out-of-state business" means a business entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(5)(a): has no presence in the state, other than any prior disaster- or emergency-related work, and conducts no business in the state, and whose services are requested by a registered business or by a state or local government for purposes of performing disaster- or emergency-related work in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(5)(b): has no registration or tax filings or presence sufficient to require the collection or payment of a tax in the state prior to the declared state disaster or emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(6): "Out-of-state employee" means an employee who does not work in the state, except for disaster- or emergency-related work during the disaster period.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1202(7): "Registered business" means a business entity that is currently registered to do business in the state prior to the declared state disaster or emergency.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203 Business and employee status during disaster period.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1): Title 16, Corporations; Title 42, Names; Title 48, Unincorporated Business Entity Act; 34A-2-406(1)(a); (1)(b); (2) Notwithstanding any other provision, an out-of-state business that conducts operations within the state for purposes of performing work or services related to a declared state disaster or emergency during the disaster period:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(a): is not considered to have established a level of presence that would require that business to be subject to any state licensing or registration requirements, provided that the out-of-state business is in substantial compliance with all applicable regulatory and licensing requirements in its state of domicile, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(a)(i): unemployment insurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(a)(ii): state or local occupational licensing fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(a)(iii): public service commission regulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(a)(iv): state or local licensing or regulatory requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(b): Title 16, Corporations; Title 42, Names; Title 48, Unincorporated Business Entity Act is exempt from the registration requirements under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(1)(c): 34A-2-406(1)(a); (1)(b); (2) shall, within a reasonable time after entry, upon the request of the Labor Commission or the Department of Insurance, confirm that it is in compliance with Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(2): Notwithstanding any other provision, an out-of-state employee who performs disaster- or emergency-related work specific to a declared state disaster or emergency during the disaster period is not subject to any state licensing or registration requirements provided that the out-of-state employee is in substantial compliance with all applicable regulatory and licensing requirements in the employee's state of residence or state of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(3): Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes; Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act; Title 59, Chapter 2, Property Tax Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(3)(a): Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes; Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act Income taxation related to an out-of-state employee or an out-of-state business is as provided in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(3)(a)(i): Title 59, Chapter 7, Corporate Franchise and Income Taxes
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(3)(a)(ii): Title 59, Chapter 10, Individual Income Tax Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(3)(b): Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act Sales and use taxation during a disaster period is as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1203(3)(c): Title 59, Chapter 2, Property Tax Act Any property brought into the state temporarily during the disaster period is not subject to any state or local  ad valorem taxes under


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1204 Business or employee activity after disaster period.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any out-of-state business or out-of-state employee that remains in the state after the disaster period will become subject to the state's normal standards for establishing presence or residency, or doing business in the state.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in the part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(1): 53-2a-1302 "Account" means the Response, Recovery, and Post-disaster Mitigation Restricted Account created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(2): "Affected community" means a community directly affected by an ongoing or recent disaster.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(3): "Affected community member" means a resident, property owner, business, nonprofit, or other individual or entity that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(3)(a): located within an affected community; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(3)(b): suffered damage due to the ongoing or recent disaster in the affected community.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(4): "Community" means a county, municipality, special district, or special service district.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(5): (5)(a) "Disaster response and recovery" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(5)(a): action taken to respond to and recover from a disaster, including action taken to remove debris, implement life-saving emergency protective measures, or repair, replace, or restore facilities in response to a disaster; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(5)(b): (5)(a) post-disaster hazard mitigation directly related to the recovery from the disaster described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(6): "Disaster response and recovery grant" means money granted to an affected community for disaster response and recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(7): "Minimum threshold payment amount" means the amount of costs that an affected community or an affected community member shall pay before the affected community or affected community member is eligible to receive money from a disaster response and recovery grant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(8): "Post-disaster hazard mitigation" means action taken, after a natural disaster, to reduce or eliminate risk to people or property that may occur as a result of the long-term effects of the natural disaster or a subsequent natural disaster, including action to prevent damage caused by flooding, earthquake, dam failure, wildfire, landslide, severe weather, drought, and problem soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1301(9): 53-2a-1305 "Official damage assessment" means a financial assessment of the damage to an affected community, caused by a disaster, that is conducted under the direction of the governing body of the affected community, in accordance with the rules described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1401 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Local Emergency Management Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402 Designation and duties of emergency managers.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402(1): Each political subdivision of the state of Utah shall designate an emergency manager.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402(2): A political subdivision may designate an officer of the political subdivision to serve as the emergency manager.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402(3): An emergency manager shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402(3)(a): create a plan to coordinate emergency preparedness, response, mitigation, coordination, and other recovery activities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402(3)(b): coordinate with other emergency managers and officials to ensure efficient, appropriate, and coordinated emergency preparedness, response, mitigation, and recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1402(4): Part 8, Emergency Interim Succession Act Each political subdivision shall provide for emergency interim succession of the emergency manager as described in


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1403 Emergency operations plan.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1403(1): Each county shall create and maintain an emergency operations plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1403(2): Each city and town shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1403(2)(a): create and maintain an emergency operations plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1403(2)(b): adopt the emergency operations plan created by the county in which the city or town is located.

---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1501(1): 53-2a-1503 "Committee" means the Grid Resilience Committee created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1501(3): "Grid resilience" means efforts to provide greater resilience to the state's infrastructure with respect to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1501(3)(a): weather events;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1501(3)(b): wildfire;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1501(3)(c): acts of terrorism; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1501(3)(d): other potentially damaging events.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503 Committee duties -- Reporting -- Staffing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503(1): The committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503(1)(a): develop knowledge about grid resilience and critical infrastructure protection;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503(1)(b): invite, as necessary, presenters with expertise in grid resilience or critical infrastructure protection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503(1)(c): discuss recommendations for state action related to increasing grid resilience and enhancing critical infrastructure protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503(2): The committee shall meet no fewer than four times each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1503(3): Annually, on or before November 30, the committee shall report recommendations to increase grid resilience and enhance critical infrastructure protection to the Public Utilities, Energy, and Technology Interim Committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1): "Emergency responder" includes a:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1)(a): firefighter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1)(b): structural engineer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1)(c): physician;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1)(d): physician assistant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1)(e): paramedic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(1)(f): technical rescue specialist.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(2): "Emergency response team" means a group of emergency responders placed at the direction, control, and funding of the Division of Emergency Management, in accordance with an agreement between the Division of Emergency Management and a sponsoring agency and the provisions of this part, to assist in urban search and rescue:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(2)(a): in response to a disaster, emergency, or important event; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(2)(b): in anticipation of a forecasted severe weather event, a flood, or a planned important event.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(3): "Emergency response team member" means an individual who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(3)(a): an emergency responder;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(3)(b): a member of an emergency response team; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(3)(c): acting within the scope of the individual's duties for an emergency response team.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(4): "Important event" includes an event attended by one or more officials of the United States or one or more foreign dignitaries and where a large crowd has or is anticipated to gather.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2a-1601(5): "Sponsoring agency" means an entity in the state that executes a written agreement to organize a National Urban Search and Rescue Response System task force as described in 44 C.F.R. Part 208 to assist the Federal Emergency Management Agency during a disaster or emergency.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 2b - Interstate Local Emergency Response Act
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Interstate Local Emergency Response Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-101(2): This part is known as "General Provisions."


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(1): "Assisting political subdivision" means a political subdivision that provides emergency services to a political subdivision in another state in accordance with a local emergency response agreement between the political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(2): "Certification" includes any license, certificate, permit, document, or other evidence issued by a government entity that authorizes a person to engage in an activity, within the person's scope of practice, that requires a specific skill set, education, expertise, or other qualifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(3): "Emergency" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(3)(a): a natural or man-made disaster, a riot, a civil disturbance, violence, criminal activity, a fire, a flood, or extreme weather;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(3)(b): an injury, illness, or other medical condition that requires an expedited response; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(3)(c): a circumstance that presents an imminent threat to life, property, or the public health, safety, or welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4): "Emergency responder" means a person employed by, under contract with, or acting as an official volunteer for a political subdivision of a state that provides emergency services, including any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4)(a): a law enforcement officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4)(b): a firefighter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4)(c): a provider of medical services or first aid;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4)(d): an explosives expert;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4)(e): a person who provides hazardous materials containment or cleanup; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(4)(f): another provider of emergency services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(5): "Emergency services" means services provided by a public entity in response to an emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(6): 53-2b-202(1) "Interstate emergency response agreement" means an agreement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(7): 53-2b-202(2)(a) "Local emergency response agreement" means an agreement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(7)(a): between a political subdivision in Utah and a political subdivision in another state, providing for the provision of emergency services to, or the receipt of emergency services from, each other; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(7)(b): entered into under the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-102(8): "Requesting political subdivision" means a political subdivision that requests emergency services from a political subdivision in another state in accordance with a local emergency response agreement between the political subdivisions.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-201 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Emergency Response Agreements."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202 Interstate emergency response agreement -- Local emergency response agreement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(1): Title 53, Chapter 2a, Part 4, Emergency Management Assistance Compact The governor may enter into an interstate emergency response agreement with another state, if the other state enacts a law substantially similar to this chapter, to permit and establish procedures and requirements relating to the sharing of emergency services between political subdivisions of the states under circumstances where the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(1)(a): when emergency responders in an assisting political subdivision may respond to an emergency more easily, quickly, or at less cost than responders in a requesting political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(1)(b): when a requesting political subdivision desires emergency responders in an assisting political subdivision to provide additional resources or other assistance in response to an emergency in the requesting political subdivision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(1)(c): when emergency responders in a requesting political subdivision are unable to respond, or unable to adequately respond, to an emergency in the requesting political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(2): (1); Part 3, Reciprocity; Part 4, Miscellaneous Provisions An emergency response agreement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(2)(a): (1) permit a political subdivision in one state to enter into a local emergency response agreement with a political subdivision in another state to permit, and establish procedures and requirements relating to, the sharing of emergency services described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(2)(b): describe the circumstances under which an assisting political subdivision may reject a request to provide resources to a requesting political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(2)(c): establish requirements relating to reimbursement of the assisting political subdivision by the requesting political subdivision for any loss, damage, costs, compensation of personnel, or other expenses incurred by the assisting political subdivision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-202(2)(d): Part 3, Reciprocity; Part 4, Miscellaneous Provisions incorporate the provisions described in


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Reciprocity."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-302 Reciprocal immunity -- Limitation on liability.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-302(1): An officer, employee, or agent of an assisting political subdivision who provides assistance in responding to an emergency in Utah under an emergency response agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-302(1)(a): is protected from liability under the laws of Utah as if the officer, employee, or agent of the assisting political subdivision is an officer, employee, or agent of Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-302(1)(b): is considered an agent of the requesting political subdivision for the purposes of tort liability and immunity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-302(2): (1); (3) In addition to the protections described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-302(3): (2) The additional liability protection described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-303 Reciprocal authority.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-303(1): An emergency responder from an assisting political subdivision outside of Utah who responds to an emergency in a requesting political subdivision inside of Utah has the same authority to act as an emergency responder of the same type in the requesting political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-303(2): An emergency responder from an assisting political subdivision outside of Utah who responds to an emergency in a requesting political subdivision inside of Utah and who holds a certification that is valid in the assisting political subdivision or in the assisting political subdivision's state shall, during the emergency response, have the authority to act as if the emergency responder holds the same certification in the requesting political subdivision or in Utah, if the emergency responder's actions authorized by the certification are taken for the purpose of responding to an emergency in the requesting political subdivision.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-401 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as "Miscellaneous Provisions."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-402 Benefits in case of injury or death.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
An assisting political subdivision shall provide its officers who respond, under this chapter, to an emergency in a requesting political subdivision and who, during the response, are injured or die in the state of the requesting political subdivision with the same death benefits and compensation, including workers' compensation, that the officers would be entitled to if the emergency and response had occurred in the assisting political subdivision.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2b-403 Emergency Management Assistance Compact takes precedence.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "COVID-19 Health and Economic Response Act."

--------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-102(2)(a): severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-102(2)(b): the disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-102(3): "COVID-19 emergency" means the spread of COVID-19 that the World Health Organization declared a pandemic on March 11, 2020.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-102(4): "Elective surgery or procedure" means a surgery or procedure that is not medically necessary to correct a serious medical condition or preserve the life of a patient.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-102(7)(a): that is caused by epidemic or pandemic disease;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-102(7)(b): that poses a substantial risk of a significant number of human fatalities or incidents of permanent or long-term disability; and
