Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202 Commission duties -- Recommendations -- Governor's response.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(1): The commission shall advise and make recommendations to the governor regarding the state's response to the COVID-19 emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2): (1); (2)(a); (2)(a) As part of the commission's duties under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a): identify at least three economic and health guidance levels that may be used to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a)(i): establish an overall risk assessment for the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a)(ii): provide targeted risk assessments based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a)(ii)(A): geographic areas of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a)(ii)(B): groups of individuals, based on each group's risk level of serious illness from COVID-19 due to demographic characteristics, including age or underlying health conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a)(ii)(C): groups of individuals, based on each group's personal experience with COVID-19, including testing positive for, having symptoms of, or having recovered from COVID-19; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(a)(ii)(D): industries;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(b): (2)(a) establish criteria for assigning each economic and health guidance level described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(c): (2)(a) identify the social and economic activities that the commission recommends take place or be restricted under each economic and health guidance level described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(d): develop a plan to promote widespread testing of individuals for COVID-19;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(e): develop a plan to encourage individuals to use available technology to allow the state to identify and track the prevalence and transmission of COVID-19; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(2)(f): develop universal communication elements for governmental entities to use in messaging related to the COVID-19 emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(3): (2)(a)(i); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(3)(a): (2)(a)(i) On or before April 22, 2020, the commission shall present a plan to the governor that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(3)(a)(i): (2)(a)(i) provides for the state to operate under an economic and health guidance level described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(3)(a)(ii): includes reasonable guidelines under which health care providers may perform elective surgeries and procedures and restaurants may resume or continue, subject to the reasonable guidelines, normal operations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(3)(a)(iii): is available to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(3)(b): (3)(a) If the governor does not implement the commission's plan described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(4): In conducting the commission's work, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(4)(a): focus on the overall well-being of the state's residents by balancing economic and public health considerations and exploring all options to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 emergency on daily life; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2c-202(4)(b): consult with local government officials, as appropriate.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-101(4)(b): is capable of recognizing the presence or absence of ventricular fibrillation or rapid ventricular tachycardia;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-101(4)(c): is capable of determining, without intervention by an operator, whether defibrillation should be performed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-101(4)(d): upon determining that defibrillation should be performed, automatically charges, enabling delivery of, or automatically delivers, an electrical impulse through the chest wall and to an individual's heart.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-102 Bureau of Emergency Medical Services -- Creation -- Bureau chief appointment, qualifications, and compensation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-102(1): There is created within the department the Bureau of Emergency Medical Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-102(2): The bureau shall be administered by a bureau chief appointed by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-102(3): The bureau chief shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-102(4): The bureau chief acts under the supervision and control of the commissioner and may be removed from the position at the will of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-102(5): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act The bureau chief shall receive compensation as provided by

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-104 State Emergency Medical Services Committee -- Membership -- Expenses.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-104(1): There is created the State Emergency Medical Services Committee.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(1): (1)(a)(ii); (iii) Upon application, the bureau, or the committee with the concurrence of the bureau, may waive the requirements of a rule  the bureau, or the committee with the concurrence of the bureau, has adopted if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(1)(a): the person applying for the waiver satisfactorily demonstrates that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(1)(a)(i): the waiver is necessary for a pilot project to be undertaken by the applicant;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(1)(b): (1)(a)(ii); (iii) for a waiver granted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(1)(b)(i): the committee or bureau extends the waiver to similarly situated persons upon application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(1)(b)(ii): the bureau, or the committee with the concurrence of the bureau,  amends the rule to be consistent with the waiver.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(2)(b): successfully passes any examination required.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-106(3): No waiver may be granted under this section that is inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-201 Public awareness efforts.
---------------------------------------------------------
The bureau may:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-201(1): develop programs to inform the public of the emergency medical service system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-201(2): develop and disseminate emergency medical training programs for the public, which emphasize the prevention and treatment of injuries and illnesses.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-202 Emergency medical communications.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Consistent with federal law, the bureau is the lead agency for coordinating the statewide emergency medical service communication systems under which emergency medical personnel, dispatch centers, and treatment facilities provide medical control and coordination between emergency medical service providers.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-204 Disaster coordination plan.
-----------------------------------------------------------
The bureau shall develop and implement, in cooperation with state, federal, and local agencies empowered to oversee disaster response activities, plans to provide emergency medical services during times of disaster or emergency.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-205 Pediatric quality improvement program.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The bureau shall establish a pediatric quality improvement resource program.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206 Personnel critical incident stress management program.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(1): The bureau shall facilitate a statewide program to provide support and counseling for personnel who have been exposed to one or more stressful incidents in the course of providing emergency services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(2): The critical incident stress management program shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(2)(a): ongoing training for agencies providing emergency services and counseling program volunteers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(2)(b): critical incident stress debriefing for personnel at no cost to the emergency provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(2)(c): advising the department on training requirements for licensure as a behavioral emergency services technician.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(3)(a): The department shall annually provide informational resources to first responder agencies about the critical incident stress management program in a format that will ensure that the first responder agency receives the information.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(3)(b): The informational resources described in Subsection (3)(a) shall include educational resources about the critical incident stress management program directed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(3)(b)(i): the first responder agency administration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(3)(b)(ii): the employees or volunteers of the first responder agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(4)(a): The department shall receive, process, and reimburse reasonable actual expenses, including mileage, incurred by a volunteer during the course of a volunteer's provision of critical incident stress management services under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(4)(b): The department shall, on the department's website, provide information concerning:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(4)(b)(i): the expenses that are eligible for reimbursement for a critical incident stress management program volunteer under Subsection (4)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(4)(b)(ii): instructions on how a critical incident stress management volunteer may submit a request for reimbursement under Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(5)(a): The department shall, in collaboration with current critical incident stress management program volunteers, organize and provide an annual training for critical incident stress management program volunteers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(5)(b): For the training described in Subsection (5)(a), the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(5)(b)(i): pay for or reimburse reasonable actual expenses for a critical incident stress management program volunteer who attends the training;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(5)(b)(ii): collaborate with existing critical incident stress management program volunteers to determine a location for the training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-206(5)(b)(iii): provide information on the department's website about the training.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-301 Establishment of statewide trauma system.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The bureau shall establish and actively supervise a statewide trauma system to:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-301(1): promote optimal care for trauma patients;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-301(2): alleviate unnecessary death and disability from trauma and emergency illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-301(3): inform health care providers about trauma system capabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-301(4): encourage the efficient and effective continuum of patient care, including prevention, prehospital care, hospital care, and rehabilitative care; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-301(5): minimize the overall cost of trauma care.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302 Trauma system advisory committee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(1): There is created within the bureau the Trauma System Advisory Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(2)(a): The committee shall be comprised of individuals knowledgeable in adult or pediatric trauma care, including physicians, physician assistants, nurses, hospital administrators, emergency medical services personnel, government officials, consumers, and persons affiliated with professional health care associations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(2)(b): Representation on the committee shall be broad and balanced among the health care delivery systems in the state with no more than three representatives coming from any single delivery system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(3): The committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(3)(a): advise the bureau regarding trauma system needs throughout the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(3)(b): assist the bureau in evaluating the quality and outcomes of the overall trauma system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(3)(c): review and comment on proposals and rules governing the statewide trauma system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(3)(d): make recommendations for the development of statewide triage, treatment, transportation, and transfer guidelines.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(4): The bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(4)(a): determine, by rule, the term and causes for removal of committee members;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(4)(b): establish committee procedures and administration policies consistent with this chapter and department rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-302(4)(c): provide administrative support to the committee.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303 Department duties.
--------------------------------------------------
In connection with the statewide trauma system established in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(1): establish a statewide trauma system plan that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(1)(a): identifies statewide trauma care needs, objectives, and priorities;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(1)(b): identifies the equipment, facilities, personnel training, and other things necessary to create and maintain a statewide trauma system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(1)(c): organizes and coordinates trauma care within defined geographic areas;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2): 53-2d-304; 53-2d-305 support the statewide trauma system by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(a): facilitating the coordination of prehospital, acute care, and rehabilitation services and providers through state regulation and oversight;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(b): facilitating the ongoing evaluation and refinement of the statewide trauma system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(c): providing educational programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(d): encouraging cooperation between community organizations, health care facilities, public health officials, emergency medical service providers, and rehabilitation facilities for the development of a statewide trauma system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(e): 53-2d-304 implementing a quality assurance program using information from the statewide trauma registry established pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(f): 53-2d-305 establishing trauma center designation requirements in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(g): developing standards so that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(g)(i): trauma centers are categorized according to their capability to provide care;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(g)(ii): trauma victims are triaged at the initial point of patient contact; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-303(2)(g)(iii): trauma patients are sent to appropriate health care facilities.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304 Statewide trauma registry and quality assurance program.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1): 53-2d-305 The bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(a): establish and fund a statewide trauma registry to collect and analyze information on the incidence, severity, causes, and outcomes of trauma;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(b): establish, by rule, the data elements, the medical care providers that shall report, and the time frame and format for reporting;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(c): use the data collected to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(c)(i): improve the availability and delivery of prehospital and hospital trauma care;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(c)(ii): assess trauma care delivery, patient care outcomes, and compliance with the requirements of this chapter and applicable department rules; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(c)(iii): regularly produce and disseminate reports to data providers, state government, and the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(d): 53-2d-305 support data collection and abstraction by providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(d)(i): a data collection system and technical assistance to each hospital that submits data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(1)(d)(ii): 53-2d-305 funding or, at the discretion of the bureau, personnel for collection and abstraction for each hospital not designated as a trauma center under the standards established pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(2): 53-2d-303
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(2)(a): Each hospital shall submit trauma data in accordance with rules established under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(2)(b): 53-2d-303 A hospital designated as a trauma center shall submit data as part of the ongoing quality assurance program established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(3): The department shall assess:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(3)(a): the effectiveness of the data collected pursuant to Subsection (1); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(3)(b): the impact of the statewide trauma system on the provision of trauma care.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(4): Data collected under this section shall be subject to Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 4, Health Statistics.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-304(5): No person may be held civilly liable for having provided data to the department in accordance with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405 Ambulance license required for emergency medical transport.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as provided in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(1): is in an emergency medical condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(2): is medically or mentally unstable, requiring direct medical observation during transport;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(3): is physically incapacitated because of illness or injury and in need of immediate transport by emergency medical service personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(4): is likely to require medical attention during transport;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(5): is being maintained on any type of emergency medical electronic monitoring;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(6): is receiving or has recently received medications that could cause a sudden change in medical condition that might require emergency medical services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(7): requires IV administration or maintenance, oxygen that is not patient-operated, or other emergency medical services during transport;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(8): needs to be immobilized during transport to a hospital, an emergency patient receiving facility, or mental health facility due to a mental or physical condition, unless the individual is in the custody of a peace officer and the primary purpose of the restraint is to prevent escape;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(9): needs to be immobilized due to a fracture, possible fracture, or other medical condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-405(10): otherwise requires or has the potential to require a level of medical care that the committee establishes as requiring direct medical observation.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-406 Medical control.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-406(1): The committee shall establish requirements for the coordination of emergency medical services rendered by emergency medical service providers, including the coordination between prehospital providers, hospitals, emergency patient receiving facilities, and other appropriate destinations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-406(2): The committee shall establish requirements for the medical supervision of emergency medical service providers to assure adequate physician oversight of emergency medical services and quality improvement.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-407 Patient destination.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-407(1): If an individual being transported by a ground or air ambulance is in a critical or unstable medical condition, the ground or air ambulance shall transport the patient to the trauma center or closest emergency patient receiving facility appropriate to adequately treat the patient.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-407(2): If the patient's condition is not critical or unstable as determined by medical control, the ground or air ambulance may transport the patient to the:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-407(2)(a): hospital, emergency patient receiving facility, licensed mental health facility, or other medical provider chosen by the patient and approved by medical control as appropriate for the patient's condition and needs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-407(2)(b): nearest hospital, emergency patient receiving facility, licensed mental health facility, or other medical provider approved by medical control as appropriate for the patient's condition and needs if the patient expresses no preference.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408 Exemptions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1): The following persons may provide emergency medical services to a patient without being licensed under this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(a): out-of-state emergency medical service personnel and providers in time of disaster;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(b): an individual who gratuitously acts as a Good Samaritan;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(c): a family member;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(d): a private business if emergency medical services are provided only to employees at the place of business and during transport;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(e): an agency of the United States government if compliance with this chapter would be inconsistent with federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(f): police, fire, and other public service personnel if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(f)(i): emergency medical services are rendered in the normal course of the person's duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(1)(f)(ii): medical control, after being apprised of the circumstances, directs immediate transport.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(2): 53-2d-404 An ambulance or emergency response vehicle may operate without a permit issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(3): Title 58, Occupations and Professions; 53-2d-801 Nothing in this chapter or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(4): Nothing in this chapter may be construed as requiring a license, permit, or designation for an acute care hospital, medical clinic, physician's office, or other fixed medical facility that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(4)(a): is staffed by a physician, physician's assistant, nurse practitioner, or registered nurse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-408(4)(b): treats an individual who has presented himself or was transported to the hospital, clinic, office, or facility.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-409(2)(a): transport a patient into Utah; and

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-506(5): Others who may be affected by the grant of a license to the applicant may join the proceeding, if the presiding officer determines that they meet the requirement of legal standing.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508 Criteria for determining public convenience and necessity.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(1): (2); (6) The criteria for determining public convenience and necessity is set forth in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(2)(a): Access to emergency medical services shall be maintained or improved.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(2)(b): The officer shall consider the impact on existing services, including the impact on response times, call volumes, populations and exclusive geographic service areas served, and the ability of surrounding licensed providers to service their exclusive geographic service areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(2)(c): The issuance or amendment of a license may not create an orphaned area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(a): The quality of service in the area shall be maintained or improved.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b): The officer shall consider the:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b)(i): staffing and equipment standards of the current licensed provider and the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b)(ii): training and licensure levels of the current licensed provider's staff and the applicant's staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b)(iii): continuing medical education provided by the current licensed provider and the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b)(iv): levels of care as defined by department rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b)(v): plan of medical control; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(3)(b)(vi): the negative or beneficial impact on the regional emergency medical service system to provide service to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4): 53-2d-503
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(a): The cost to the public shall be justified.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(b): 53-2d-503 The officer shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(b)(i): the financial solvency of the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(b)(ii): 53-2d-503 the applicant's ability to provide services within the rates established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(b)(iii): the applicant's ability to comply with cost reporting requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(b)(iv): the cost efficiency of the applicant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(4)(b)(v): the cost effect of the application on the public, interested parties, and the emergency medical services system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5): (7)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(a): Local desires concerning cost, quality, and access shall be considered.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b): (7) The officer shall assess and consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b)(i): the existing provider's record of providing services and the applicant's record and ability to provide similar or improved services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b)(ii): (7) locally established emergency medical services goals, including those established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b)(iii): comment by local governments on the applicant's business and operations plans;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b)(iv): comment by interested parties that are providers on the impact of the application on the parties' ability to provide emergency medical services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b)(v): comment by interested parties that are local governments on the impact of the application on the citizens it represents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(5)(b)(vi): public comment on any aspect of the application or proposed license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(6): Other related criteria:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(6)(a): the officer considers necessary; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(6)(b): established by bureau rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(7): Local governments shall establish cost, quality, and access goals for the ground ambulance and paramedic services that serve their areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-508(8): In a formal adjudicative proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that public convenience and necessity require the approval of the application for all or part of the exclusive geographic service area requested.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509 Ground ambulance and paramedic licenses -- Hearing and presiding officers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509(1): The bureau shall set training standards for hearing officers and presiding officers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509(2): At a minimum, a presiding officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509(2)(a): be familiar with the theory and application of public convenience and necessity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509(2)(b): have a working knowledge of the emergency medical service system in the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509(2)(c): be licensed to practice law in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-509(3): The bureau shall provide training for hearing officer and presiding officer candidates in the theory and application of public convenience and necessity and on the emergency medical system in the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-510 Local approvals.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-510(1): Licensed ambulance providers and paramedic providers shall meet all local zoning and business licensing standards generally applicable to businesses operating within the jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-510(2): Publicly subsidized providers shall demonstrate approval of the taxing authority that will provide the subsidy.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-510(3): A publicly operated service shall demonstrate that the governing body has approved the provision of services to the entire exclusive geographic service area that is the subject of the license, including those areas that may lie outside the territorial or jurisdictional boundaries of the governing body.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-511 Limitation on repetitive applications.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who has previously applied for a license under SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 53-2d-511(1): 53-2d-507 one year has passed from the date of the issuance of a final decision under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-511(2): all interested parties and the department agree that a new application is in the public interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512 License for air ambulance providers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(1): An applicant for an air ambulance provider shall apply to the bureau for a license only by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(1)(a): submitting a complete application;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(1)(b): providing information in the format required by the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(1)(c): paying the required fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2): The bureau may make rules establishing minimum qualifications and requirements for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(a): personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(b): capital reserves;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(c): equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(d): business plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(e): operational procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(f): resource hospital and medical direction agreements;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(g): management and control qualifications and requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(2)(h): other matters that may be relevant to an applicant's ability to provide air ambulance services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(3): Upon receiving a completed application and the required fees, the bureau shall review the application and determine whether the application meets the minimum requirements for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(4): The bureau may deny an application for an air ambulance if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(4)(a): the bureau finds that the application contains any materially false or misleading information or is incomplete;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(4)(b): the application demonstrates that the applicant fails to meet the minimum requirements for licensure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(4)(c): the bureau finds after inspection that the applicant does not meet the minimum requirements for licensure.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-512(5): If the bureau denies an application under this section, it shall notify the applicant in writing setting forth the grounds for the denial.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-513 License renewals.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-513(1): A licensed provider desiring to renew its license shall meet the renewal requirements established by bureau rule.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515 Changes in ownership.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(1): (2); 53-2d-508 A licensed provider whose ownership or controlling ownership interest has changed shall submit information to the bureau, as required by bureau rule:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(1)(a): to establish whether the new owner or new controlling party meets minimum requirements for licensure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(1)(b): (2); 53-2d-508 except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2): (1)(b) An administrative proceeding is not required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(a): the change in ownership interest is among existing owners of a closely held corporation and the change does not result in a change in the management of the licensee or in the name of the licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(b): the change in ownership in a closely held corporation results in the introduction of new owners, provided that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(b)(i): the new owners are limited to individuals who would be entitled to the equity in the closely held corporation by the laws of intestate succession had the transferor died intestate at the time of the transfer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(b)(ii): the majority owners on January 1, 1999, have been disclosed to the department by October 1, 1999, and the majority owners on January 1, 1999, retain a majority interest in the closely held corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(b)(iii): the name of the licensed provider remains the same;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(c): the change in ownership is the result of one or more owners transferring their interests to a trust, limited liability company, partnership, or closely held corporation so long as the transferors retain control over the receiving entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(d): the change in ownership is the result of a distribution of an estate or a trust upon the death of the testator or the trustor and the recipients are limited to individuals who would be entitled to the interest by the laws of intestate succession had the transferor died intestate at the time of the transfer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-515(2)(e): other similar changes that the department establishes, by rule, as having no significant impact on the cost, quality, or access to emergency medical services.

-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(1)(a): "Overlap" means two ground ambulance interfacility transport providers that are licensed at the same level of service in all or part of a single geographic service area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(1)(b): "Overlay" means two ground ambulance interfacility transport providers that are licensed at a different level of service in all or part of a single geographic service area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(2): 53-2d-502 Notwithstanding the exclusive geographic service requirement of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(4): An amendment of a license under this section may not alter:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(4)(a): other terms of the original license, including the applicable geographic service area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-516(4)(b): the license of other providers that provide interfacility transport services in the geographic service area.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-601 Discrimination prohibited.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-601(1): No person licensed or designated pursuant to this chapter may discriminate in the provision of emergency medical services on the basis of race, sex, color, creed, or prior inquiry as to ability to pay.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-601(2): This chapter does not authorize or require medical assistance or transportation over the objection of an individual on religious grounds.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602 Illegal activity.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(1): 53-2d-408; 53-2d-201 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(1)(a): practice or engage in the practice, represent that the person is practicing or engaging in the practice, or attempt to practice or engage in the practice of any activity that requires a license, certification, or designation under this chapter unless that person is licensed, certified, or designated under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(1)(b): offer an emergency medical service that requires a license, certification, or designation under this chapter unless the person is licensed, certified, or designated under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(2): A person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(2)(a): advertise or represent that the person holds a license, certification, or designation required under this chapter, unless that person holds the license, certification, or designation under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(2)(b): employ or permit any employee to perform any service for which a license or certification is required by this chapter, unless the person performing the service possesses the required license or certification under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(2)(c): display, sell, reproduce, or otherwise use any Utah Emergency Medical Services insignia without authorization from the bureau;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(2)(d): reproduce or otherwise use materials developed by the department for licensure or certification testing or examination without authorization from the bureau; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602(2)(e): willfully summon an ambulance or emergency response vehicle or report that one is needed when the person knows that the ambulance or emergency response vehicle is not needed.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1 Prohibition on the use of "911".
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(a): "Emergency services" means services provided by a person in response to an emergency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(b): "Emergency services" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(b)(i): fire protection services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(b)(ii): paramedic services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(b)(iii): law enforcement services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(b)(iv): 911 ambulance or paramedic services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(1)(b)(v): any other emergency services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(2): A person may not use "911" or other similar sequence of numbers in the person's name with the purpose to deceive the public that the person operates or represents emergency services, unless the person is authorized to provide emergency services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(3): (2) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(3)(a): a class C misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-602.1(3)(b): subject to a fine of up to $500 per violation.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605 Service interruption or cessation -- Receivership -- Default coverage -- Notice.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(a): Acting in the public interest, the department may petition a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, to appoint the bureau or an independent receiver to continue the operations of a provider upon any one of the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(a)(i): the provider ceases or intends to cease operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(a)(ii): the provider becomes insolvent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(a)(iii): the bureau has initiated proceedings to revoke the provider's license and has determined that the lives, health, safety, or welfare of the population served within the provider's exclusive geographic service area are endangered because of the provider's action or inaction pending a full hearing on the license revocation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(a)(iv): the bureau has revoked the provider's license and has been unable to adequately arrange for another provider to take over the provider's exclusive geographic service area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(b): Notwithstanding Title 78B, Chapter 3a, Venue for Civil Actions, if the department brings a petition described in Subsection (1)(a) in the district court, the department shall bring the petition in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(b)(i): Salt Lake County; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(1)(b)(ii): the county in which the ambulance or paramedic provider operates.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(2): If a licensed or designated provider ceases operations or is otherwise unable to provide services, the bureau may arrange for another licensed provider to provide services on a temporary basis until a license is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-605(3): A licensed provider shall give the department 30 days' notice of its intent to cease operations.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702 Notification of air ambulance policies and charges.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(1): For any patient who is in need of air medical transport provider services, an emergency medical service provider shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(1)(a): provide the patient or the patient's representative with the following information before contacting an air medical transport provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(1)(a)(i): which health insurers in the state the air medical transport provider contracts with;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(1)(a)(ii): if sufficient data is available, the average charge for air medical transport services for a patient who is uninsured or out of network; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(1)(a)(iii): whether the air medical transport provider balance bills a patient for any charge not paid by the patient's health insurer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(1)(b): if multiple air medical transport providers are capable of providing the patient with services, provide the patient or the patient's representative an opportunity to choose the air medical transport provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(2): Subsection (1) does not apply if the patient:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(2)(a): is unconscious and the patient's representative is not physically present with the patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-702(2)(b): is unable, due to a medical condition, to make an informed decision about the choice of an air medical transport provider, and the patient's representative is not physically present with the patient.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703 Volunteer Emergency Medical Service Personnel  Insurance Program -- Creation -- Administration -- Eligibility -- Benefits -- Rulemaking -- Advisory board.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1): 31A-22-646; 31A-1-301; 49-20-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(a): "Basic life insurance benefit" means the standard group life insurance benefit offered by PEHP that combines basic life, line-of-duty, accidental death and disability, and dependent coverage into one benefit package.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(b): "Basic long-term disability benefit" means a $1,000 monthly benefit arising from a disability determined in accordance with Title 49, Chapter 21, Public Employee's Long-term Disability Act and excluding any coverage offered on a pilot basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(c): 31A-22-646 "Dental plan" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(d): 31A-1-301 "Health benefit plan" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(e): "Local government entity" means a political subdivision that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(e)(i): is licensed as a ground ambulance provider under Part 5, Ambulance and Paramedic Providers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-703(1)(e)(ii): does not offer health insurance benefits to volunteer emergency medical service personnel.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-801 Authority to administer CPR or use an AED.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-801(1): administer CPR on another individual without a license, certificate, or other governmental authorization if the person reasonably believes that the individual is in sudden cardiac arrest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-801(2): use an AED on another individual without a license, certificate, or other governmental authorization if the person reasonably believes that the individual is in sudden cardiac arrest.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-806 Education and training.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-806(1): The office shall work in cooperation with federal, state, and local agencies and schools, to encourage individuals to complete courses on the administration of CPR and the use of an AED.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-806(2): A person who owns or leases an AED shall encourage each individual who is likely to use the AED to complete courses on the administration of CPR and the use of an AED.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-808 Tampering with an AED prohibited -- Penalties.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class C misdemeanor if the person removes, tampers with, or otherwise disturbs an AED, AED cabinet or enclosure, or AED sign, unless:Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-808(1): the person is authorized by the AED owner for the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-808(1)(a): inspecting the AED or AED cabinet or enclosure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-808(1)(b): performing maintenance or repairs on the AED, the AED cabinet or enclosure, a wall or structure that the AED cabinet or enclosure is directly attached to, or an AED sign;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-808(2): the person is responding to, or providing care to, a potential sudden cardiac arrest patient; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-2d-808(3): the person acts in good faith with the intent to support, and not to violate, the recognized purposes of the AED.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-103 Driver License Division -- Creation -- Director -- Appointment -- Term -- Compensation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-103(1): There is created within the department the Driver License Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-103(2): The division shall be administered by a director appointed by the commissioner with the approval of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-103(3): The director is the executive and administrative head of the division and shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-103(4): The director acts under the supervision and control of the commissioner and may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-103(5): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act The director shall receive compensation as provided by


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104 Division duties.
-----------------------------------------------
The division shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1): 53-3-205; 53-3-410; 53-3-804 in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(a): for examining applicants for a license, as necessary for the safety and welfare of the traveling public;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(b): for acceptable documentation of an applicant's identity, Social Security number, Utah resident status, Utah residence address, proof of legal presence, proof of citizenship in the United States, honorable or general discharge from the United States military, and other proof or documentation required under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(c): for acceptable documentation to verify that an individual is homeless as verified by the Department of Workforce Services, for purposes of residency, address verification, and obtaining a fee waiver;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(d): regarding the restrictions to be imposed on an individual driving a motor vehicle with a temporary learner permit or learner permit;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(e): for exemptions from licensing requirements as authorized in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(f): 53-3-205; 53-3-410; 53-3-804 establishing procedures for the storage and maintenance of applicant information provided in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(g)(i): ways drivers can improve air quality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(1)(g)(ii): the harmful effects of vehicle emissions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(2): examine each applicant according to the class of license applied for;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(3): license motor vehicle drivers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(4): file every application for a license received by the division and shall maintain indices containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(4)(a): all applications denied and the reason each was denied;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(4)(b): all applications granted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(4)(c): the name of every licensee whose license has been suspended, disqualified, or revoked by the division and the reasons for the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(5): suspend, revoke, disqualify, cancel, or deny any license issued in accordance with this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(6): file all accident reports and abstracts of court records of convictions received by the division under state law;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(7): maintain a record of each licensee showing the licensee's convictions and the traffic accidents in which the licensee has been involved where a conviction has resulted;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(8): consider the record of a licensee upon an application for renewal of a license and at other appropriate times;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-104(9): 53-3-109 search the license files, compile, and furnish a report on the driving record of any individual licensed in the state in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106 Disposition of revenues under this chapter -- Restricted account created -- Uses as provided by appropriation -- Nonlapsing.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(1): There is created within the Transportation Fund a restricted account known as the "Department of Public Safety Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(2): 63J-1-504; 41-1a-1201 The account consists of money generated from the following revenue sources:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(2)(a): all money received under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(2)(b): 63J-1-504 administrative fees received according to the fee schedule authorized under this chapter and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(2)(c): 41-1a-1201 beginning on January 1, 2013, money received in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(2)(d): any appropriations made to the account by the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(3)(a): The account shall earn interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(3)(b): All interest earned on account money shall be deposited into the account.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-106(4): The expenses of the department in carrying out this chapter shall be provided for by legislative appropriation from this account.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-108 Authority to administer oaths.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Officers and employees of the division designated by the director for the purpose of administering this chapter may administer oaths and acknowledge signatures and shall do so without fee.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111 Blood and urine test reports -- Permissible uses and restrictions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(1): The division shall receive a result of a blood or urine test report in accordance with Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 4, Health Statistics.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(a): The division may only use an individual's personally identifiable health data from a blood and urine test in connection with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(a)(i): an administrative hearing involving that individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(a)(ii): in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 3, Agency Review, an agency review of the administrative hearing described in Subsection (2)(a)(i); or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(a)(iii): in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review, a judicial review of the administrative hearing described in Subsection (2)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(b)(i): The division shall aggregate and anonymize data from a blood and urine test.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(b)(ii): The division may only use the anonymized and aggregated data from blood and urine tests:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(b)(ii)(A): to create a report required or requested by the Legislature; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(2)(b)(ii)(B): to create statistical reports for criminal justice agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(3): The division shall securely retain each blood and urine test as a private record as provided in Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(4): The division may provide the information from a blood and urine test received under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(4)(a): to the individual who is the subject of the blood and urine test;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(4)(b): to the individual's attorney in connection with an administrative proceeding before the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-111(4)(c): as otherwise required by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203 Authorizing or permitting driving in violation of chapter -- Renting of motor vehicles -- License requirements -- Employees must be licensed -- Violations.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(1): A person may not authorize or knowingly permit a motor vehicle owned by the person or under the person's control to be driven by a person in violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2): (2)(b); (2)(c)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(a): A person may not rent a motor vehicle to another person unless the person who will be the driver is licensed in this state, or in the case of a nonresident, licensed under the laws of the state or country of his residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(b): A person may not rent a motor vehicle to another person until the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(b)(i): has inspected the license certificate of the person who will be the driver; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(b)(ii): verified the signature on the license certificate by comparison with the signature of the person who will be the driver written in his presence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(c): (2)(b); (2)(c)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(c)(i): (2)(b) A person may verify the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(c)(ii): (2)(c)(i) The electronic system described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(c)(ii)(A): information included on the driver license certificate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(c)(ii)(B): biometric information.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(d): A person renting a motor vehicle to another shall keep a record of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(d)(i): registration number of the rented motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(d)(ii): name and address of the person to whom the motor vehicle is rented;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(d)(iii): number of the license certificate of the renter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(d)(iv): date and place the license certificate was issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(2)(e): The record is open to inspection by any peace officer or officer or employee of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(3): A person may not employ a person to drive a motor vehicle who is not licensed as required under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-203(4): A person who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6 Emergency contact database.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1)(a): The division shall establish a database of the emergency contacts of a person who holds a license certificate, learner permit, identification card, or any other type of license or permit issued under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1)(b): Information in the database created under this section may only be accessed by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1)(b)(i): employees of the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1)(b)(ii): law enforcement officers employed by a law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1)(b)(iii): employees or authorized agents of a law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(1)(c): A law enforcement officer may share information contained in the emergency contact database with other public safety workers on the scene of a motor vehicle accident or other emergency situation, as needed to conduct official law enforcement duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(2): A person holding a license certificate, learner permit, identification card, or any other type of license or permit issued under this chapter may provide the division, in a manner specified by the division, the name, address, telephone number, and relationship to the holder of no more than two emergency contact persons whom the holder wishes to be contacted by a law enforcement officer if the holder:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(2)(a): is involved in a motor vehicle accident or other emergency situation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(2)(b): is unable to communicate with the contact person or persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(3): The information contained in the database created under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(3)(a): shall only be used for the purposes described in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(3)(b): may not be used for criminal investigation purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(4)(a): specifying the method for a license certificate, instruction permit, or identification card holder to provide the division with emergency contact information;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(4)(b): specifying the method for a license certificate, learner permit, or identification card holder to change the emergency contact information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(4)(c): other rules required for the implementation of the database or its operation that the division determines necessary to implement the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(5)(a): If a person involved in a motor vehicle accident or other emergency situation is unable to communicate with the contact person or persons specified in the database, a law enforcement officer shall make a good faith effort to notify the contact person or persons of the situation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(5)(b): A law enforcement officer or a law enforcement agency that employs a law enforcement officer may not incur any liability if the law enforcement officer is not able to make contact with a designated emergency contact person.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(5)(c): Except for willful or wanton misconduct, a law enforcement officer or a law enforcement agency that employs a law enforcement officer may not incur any liability relating to the reporting or use of the database during a motor vehicle accident or other emergency situation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-205.6(6): The division is not liable for any damages, costs, or expenses arising or resulting from any inaccurate or incomplete data or system unavailability.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206 Examination of applicant's physical and mental fitness to drive a motor vehicle.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1): The division shall examine every applicant for a license, including a test of the applicant's:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(a): eyesight either:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(a)(i): by the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(a)(ii): by allowing the applicant to furnish to the division a statement from a physician licensed under Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act, a physician assistant licensed under Title 58, Chapter 70A, Utah Physician Assistant Act, or an optometrist licensed under Title 58, Chapter 16a, Utah Optometry Practice Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(b): ability to read and understand highway signs regulating, warning, and directing traffic;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(c): ability to read and understand simple English used in highway traffic and directional signs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(d): knowledge of the state traffic laws;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(e): other physical and mental abilities the division finds necessary to determine the applicant's fitness to drive a motor vehicle safely on the highways; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-206(1)(f): ability to exercise ordinary and responsible control driving a motor vehicle, as determined by actual demonstration or other indicator.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208 Restrictions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(1)(a): When granting a license, the division may for good cause impose restrictions, suitable to the licensee's driving ability, for the type of motor vehicle or special mechanical control devices required on a motor vehicle that the licensee may drive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(1)(b): The division may impose other restrictions on the licensee as it determines appropriate to assure safe driving of a motor vehicle by the licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(2): The division may either grant a special restricted license or may set forth restrictions upon the regular license certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(3)(a): The division may suspend or revoke any license upon receiving satisfactory evidence of any violation of the restrictions imposed on the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(3)(b): Each licensee is entitled to a hearing for a suspension or revocation under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-208(4): It is an infraction for a person to drive a motor vehicle in violation of the restrictions imposed on his license under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216 Change of address -- Duty of licensee to notify division within 10 days -- Change of name -- Proof necessary -- Method of giving notice by division.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), if an individual, after applying for or receiving a license, moves from the address named in the application or in the license certificate issued to the individual, the individual shall, within 10 days after the day on which the individual moves, notify the division in a manner specified by the division of the individual's new address and the number of any license certificate held by the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(1)(b): If an individual who is required to register as a sex offender, kidnap offender, or child abuse offender under Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry, after applying for or receiving a license, moves from the address named in the application or in the license certificate issued to the individual, the individual shall, within 30 days after the day on which the individual moves, apply for an updated license in-person at a division office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2): If an applicant requests to change the surname on the applicant's license, the division shall issue a substitute license with the new name upon receiving an application and fee for a duplicate license and any of the following proofs of the applicant's full legal name:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(a): an original or certified copy of the applicant's marriage certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(b): a certified copy of a court order under Title 42, Chapter 1, Change of Name, showing the name change;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(c): an original or certified copy of a birth certificate issued by a government agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(d): a certified copy of a divorce decree or annulment granted the applicant that specifies the name change requested; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(e): a certified copy of a divorce decree that does not specify the name change requested together with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(e)(i): an original or certified copy of the applicant's birth certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(e)(ii): the applicant's marriage license;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(e)(iii): a driver license record showing use of a maiden name; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(2)(e)(iv): other documentation the division finds acceptable.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(3)(a): If the division is authorized or required to give a notice under this chapter or other law regulating the operation of vehicles, the notice shall, unless otherwise prescribed, be given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(3)(a)(i): personal delivery to the individual to be notified; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(3)(a)(ii): deposit in the United States mail with postage prepaid, addressed to the individual at the individual's address as shown by the records of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(3)(b): The giving of notice by mail is complete upon the expiration of four days after the deposit of the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(3)(c): Proof of the giving of notice in either manner may be made by the certificate of an officer or employee of the division or affidavit of an individual 18 years of age or older, naming the individual to whom the notice was given and specifying the time, place, and manner of giving the notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(4): The division may use state mailing or United States Postal Service information to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(4)(a): verify an address on an application or on records of the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(4)(b): correct mailing addresses in the division's records.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-216(5): A violation of the provisions of Subsection (1) is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(c): Every person convicted of a traffic violation shall have assessed against the person's driving record the number of points that the division has assigned to the type of violation of which the person has been convicted, except that the number of points assessed shall be decreased by 10% if on the abstract of the court record of the conviction the court has graded the severity of violation as minimum, and shall be increased by 10% if on the abstract the court has graded the severity of violation as maximum.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d)(i): A separate procedure for assessing points for speeding offenses shall be established by the division based upon the severity of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d)(ii): The severity of a speeding violation shall be graded as:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d)(ii)(A): "minimum" for exceeding the posted speed limit by up to 10 miles per hour;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d)(ii)(B): "intermediate" for exceeding the posted speed limit by from 11 to 20 miles per hour; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d)(ii)(C): "maximum" for exceeding the posted speed limit by 21 or more miles per hour.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(d)(iii): Consideration shall be made for assessment of no points on minimum speeding violations, except for speeding violations in school zones.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(e)(i): Points assessed against a person's driving record shall be deleted for violations occurring before a time limit set by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(e)(ii): The time limit may not exceed three years.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(e)(iii): The division may also delete points to reward violation-free driving for periods of time set by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(f)(i): By publication in two newspapers having general circulation throughout the state, the division shall give notice of the number of points it has assigned to each type of traffic violation, the time limit set by the division for the deletion of points, and the point level at which the division will generally take action to deny or suspend under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-221(4)(f)(ii): The division may not change any of the information provided above regarding points without first giving new notice in the same manner.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-222 Purpose of revocation or suspension for driving under the influence.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that the purpose of this title relating to suspension or revocation of a person's license or privilege to drive a motor vehicle for driving with a blood alcohol content above a certain level or while under the influence of alcohol, any drug, or a combination of alcohol and any drug, or for refusing to take a chemical test as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-224 Filing a petition for hearing -- Judicial review of license cancellation, revocation, or suspension -- Scope of review.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-224(1): A person denied a license or whose license has been cancelled, suspended, or revoked by the division following an administrative hearing may seek judicial review of the division's order.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-224(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-224(2)(a): Venue for judicial review of informal adjudicative proceedings is in the district court in the county where the offense occurred, which resulted in the cancellation, suspension, or revocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-224(2)(b): Persons not residing in the state shall file in Salt Lake County or the county where the offense occurred, which resulted in the cancellation, suspension, or revocation.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229 Prohibited uses of license certificate -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1): It is a class C misdemeanor for an individual to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(a): lend or knowingly permit the use of a license certificate issued to the individual, by another individual not entitled to the license certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(b): display or represent as the individual's own license certificate a license certificate not issued to the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(c): refuse to surrender to the division or a peace officer upon demand any license certificate issued by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(d): use a false name or give a false address in any application for a license or any renewal or duplicate of the license certificate, or to knowingly make a false statement, or to knowingly conceal a material fact or otherwise commit a fraud in the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(e): display a canceled, denied, revoked, suspended, or disqualified driver license certificate as a valid driver license certificate;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(f): knowingly acquire, use, display, or transfer an item that purports to be an authentic driver license certificate issued by a governmental entity if the item is not an authentic driver license certificate issued by that governmental entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(1)(g): alter any information on an authentic driver license certificate so that it no longer represents the information originally displayed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(2): (1)(e) The provisions of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(3)(c): 76-10-101 acquire, use, display, or transfer a false or altered driver license certificate to procure a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-229(4): 32B-1-403 An individual may not use, display, or transfer a false or altered driver license certificate to procure alcoholic beverages, gain admittance to a place where alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed, or obtain employment that may not be obtained by a minor in violation of Section
