Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-601 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Drivers' License Compact."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-602 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-602(1): "Executive head" means the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-602(2): "Licensing authority" means the department, the division, or both as the text may require.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-603 Ratification.
--------------------------------------------
The Drivers' License Compact is ratified for the state and is entered into with all other jurisdictions legally joining in the compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-604 Text of compact -- Party states to report traffic violations and exchange driving record information in home state of driver.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-605 Furnishing information and documents.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall furnish to the appropriate authorities of other party states any information or documents reasonably necessary to facilitate the administration of Articles III, IV, and V of the compact.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-606 Expenses of compact administrator.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The compact administrator provided for in Article VII of the compact is not entitled to any additional compensation on account of his service as administrator, but is entitled to expenses incurred in connection with his duties and responsibilities as administrator, in the same manner as for expenses incurred in connection with any other duties or responsibilities of his office or employment.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-607 Court and agency reporting of actions to department.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any court or other agency of this state, or a subdivision of the state that has jurisdiction to take any action suspending, revoking, or otherwise limiting a license to drive, shall report any action suspending, revoking, or limiting a license to drive and the adjudication upon which it is based, to the department within ten days, in a manner specified by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-701 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Nonresident Violator Compact."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(1): "Citation" means a summons, ticket, or other official document issued by a peace officer for a traffic violation, containing an order that requires the motorist to respond.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(2): "Collateral" means cash or other security deposited to secure an appearance for trial, following the issuance by a peace officer of a citation for a traffic violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(3): "Court" means a court of law or traffic tribunal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(4): "Driver license" means a license or privilege to operate a motor vehicle issued under the laws of the home jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(5): "Home jurisdiction" means the jurisdiction that issued the driver's license of the traffic violator.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(6): "Issuing jurisdiction" means the jurisdiction in which the traffic citation was issued to the motorist.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(7): "Jurisdiction" means a state, territory, or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, or the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(8): "Motorist" means a driver of a motor vehicle operating in a party jurisdiction other than the home jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(9): "Personal recognizance" means an agreement by a motorist made at the time of issuance of the traffic citation that he will comply with the terms of that traffic citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-702(10): "Terms of the citation" means those options expressly stated upon the citation.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-703 Violations exempted from compact.
----------------------------------------------------------------
This compact does not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-703(1): parking or standing violations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-703(2): highway weight limit violations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-703(3): violations of law governing the transportation of hazardous materials.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-704 Authority to enter compact.
----------------------------------------------------------
The director of the division shall execute all documents and perform all other acts necessary to enter into and carry out this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705 Procedures for issuing traffic citation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The following is the procedure of the issuing jurisdiction:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(1): (2) When issuing a citation for a traffic violation, a peace officer shall issue the citation to a motorist who possesses a driver license issued by a party jurisdiction and shall not, subject to the exceptions noted in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(2): Personal recognizance is acceptable only if not prohibited by law. If mandatory appearance is required, it must take place immediately following issuance of the citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(3)(a): Upon failure of a motorist to comply with the terms of a traffic citation, the appropriate official shall report the failure to comply to the licensing authority of the jurisdiction in which the traffic citation was issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(3)(b): The report shall be made in accordance with procedures specified by the issuing jurisdiction and shall contain information as specified in the compact manual as minimum requirements for effective processing by the home jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(4): Upon receipt of the report, the licensing authority of the issuing jurisdiction shall transmit to the licensing authority in the home jurisdiction of the motorist the information in a form and content contained in the compact manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(5): The licensing authority of the issuing jurisdiction may not suspend the privilege of a motorist for whom a report has been transmitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(6): The licensing authority of the issuing jurisdiction may not transmit a report on any violation if the date of transmission is more than six months after the date on which the traffic citation was issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-705(7): The licensing authority of the issuing jurisdiction shall not transmit a report on any violation where the date of issuance of the citation predates the most recent of the effective dates of entry for the two jurisdictions affected.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-706 Procedure for home jurisdictions upon report of a licensee's failure to comply with out-of-state authority.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The following is the procedure for the home jurisdiction:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-706(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-706(1)(a): Upon receipt of a report of a failure to comply from the licensing authority of the issuing jurisdiction, the licensing authority of the home jurisdiction may notify the motorist and initiate a suspension action, in accordance with the home jurisdiction's procedures, and suspend the motorist's driver license until satisfactory evidence of compliance with the terms of the traffic citation has been furnished to the home jurisdiction licensing authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-706(1)(b): Due process safeguards will be accorded.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-706(2): The licensing authority of the home jurisdiction shall maintain a record of actions taken and make reports to issuing jurisdictions as provided in the compact manual.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-707 Rights of party jurisdictions not affected by compact.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as expressly required by  the compact, nothing contained in this part affects the right of any party jurisdiction to apply any of its other laws relating to licenses to drive to any person or circumstance, or to invalidate or prevent any driver license agreement or other cooperative arrangement between a party jurisdiction and a nonparty jurisdiction.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-708 Compact administrator.
-----------------------------------------------------
The director of the division is the compact administrator for the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709 Amendment of compact.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(1)(a): This compact may be amended from time to time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(1)(b): Amendments shall be presented in resolution form to the chairman of the board of compact administrators and may be initiated by one or more party jurisdictions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(2): Adoption of an amendment requires endorsement of all party jurisdictions and becomes effective 30 days after the date of the last endorsement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(3): 53-3-104; (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(3)(a): Failure of a party jurisdiction to respond to the compact chairman within 120 days after receipt of the proposed amendment constitutes endorsement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(3)(b): 53-3-104 A report authorized by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(3)(c): (3)(b) The provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(3)(c)(i): a CDIP or CDL license holder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-709(3)(c)(ii): a violation that occurred in a commercial motor vehicle.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-801 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Identification Card Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-802 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-802(1): "Adult" means a person 21 years of age or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-802(2): "Identification card" means a card for identification issued under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-802(3): "Minor" means a person younger than 21 years of age.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803 Application for identification card -- Age requirements -- Application on behalf of others.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(1): A person at least 16 years old or older may apply to the division for an identification card.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(2): A person younger than 16 years old may apply to the division for an identification card with the consent of the applicant's parent or guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(3)(a): If a person is unable to apply for the card due to his youth or incapacitation, the application may be made on behalf of that person by his parent or guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(3)(b): A parent or guardian applying for an identification card on behalf of a child or incapacitated person shall provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(3)(b)(i): identification, as required by the commissioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(3)(b)(ii): the consent of the incapacitated person, as required by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(4): Part 2, Driver Licensing Act The division may not issue a Utah identification card or an extension of a regular identification card to a person who holds an unexpired Utah license certificate issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(4)(a): the Utah license certificate is canceled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-803(4)(b): if the Utah license certificate is in the person's possession, the Utah license certificate is surrendered to the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(1): To apply for a regular identification card or limited-term identification card, an applicant shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(2)(i)(i)(B): a United States national; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(2)(i)(i)(C): a legal permanent resident alien; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(2)(i)(ii): of the applicant's:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(2)(i)(ii)(B): pending or approved application for asylum in the United States;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(2)(i)(ii)(D): pending or approved application for temporary protected status in the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-804(2)(i)(ii)(E): approved deferred action status;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-806 Portrait-style format -- Minor's card distinguishable.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-806(1): 53-3-207 The division shall use a portrait-style format for all identification cards, similar to the format used for license certificates issued to an individual younger than 21 years old under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-806(2): The identification card issued to an individual younger than 21 years old shall be distinguished by use of plainly printed information or by the use of a color or other means not used for the identification card issued to an individual 21 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-806(3): The division shall distinguish an identification card issued to an individual younger than 21 years old by plainly printing the date the identification card holder is 21 years old.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-806(4)(b): its expiration date.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807 Expiration -- Address and name change -- Extension.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(1)(a): A regular identification card expires on the birth date of the applicant in the fifth year after the issuance of the regular identification card.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(1)(b): A limited-term identification card expires on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(1)(b)(i): the expiration date of the period of time of the individual's authorized stay in the United States or on the birth date of the applicant in the fifth year after the issuance of the limited-term identification card, whichever is sooner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(1)(b)(ii): on the date of issuance in the first year after the year that the limited-term identification card was issued if there is no definite end to the individual's period of authorized stay.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), if an individual has applied for and received an identification card and subsequently moves from the address shown on the application or on the card, the individual shall, within 10 days after the day on which the individual moves, notify the division in a manner specified by the division of the individual's new address.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-807(2)(b): If an individual who is required to register as a sex offender, kidnap offender, or child abuse offender under Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry, has applied for and received an identification card and subsequently moves from the address shown on the application or on the card, the individual shall, within 30 days after the day on which the individual moves, apply for an updated identification card in-person at a division office.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-809 Revocation of card for providing false information or altering card.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner shall revoke and repossess the identification card of any person who has:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-809(1): furnished false or forged information or evidence in support of any application for any identification card; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-809(2): altered any information or photograph on an identification card.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810 Prohibited uses of identification card -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1): It is a class C misdemeanor to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(a): lend or knowingly permit the use of an identification card issued to the individual, by an individual not entitled to the identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(b): display or to represent as the individual's own identification card an identification card not issued to the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(c): refuse to surrender to the division or a peace officer upon demand any identification card issued by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(d): use a false name or give a false address in any application for an identification card or any renewal or duplicate of the identification card, or to knowingly make a false statement, or to knowingly conceal a material fact in the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(e): display a revoked identification card as a valid identification card;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(f): knowingly acquire, use, display, or transfer an item that purports to be an authentic identification card issued by a governmental entity if the item is not an authentic identification card issued by that governmental entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(1)(g): alter any information contained on an authentic identification card so that it no longer represents the information originally displayed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(2): 53-3-806; 76-10-101 It is a class A misdemeanor to knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(2)(a): issue an identification card with false or fraudulent information;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(2)(b): 53-3-806 issue an identification card to an individual who is younger than 21 years old if the identification card is not distinguished as required for an individual who is younger than 21 years old under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(2)(c): 76-10-101 acquire, use, display, or transfer a false or altered identification card to procure a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(3): 32B-1-403 An individual may not knowingly use, display, or transfer a false or altered identification card to procure alcoholic beverages, gain admittance to a place where alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed, or obtain employment that may not be obtained by a minor in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(4): It is a third degree felony if an individual's acquisition, use, display, or transfer of a false or altered identification card:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(4)(a): aids or furthers the individual's efforts to fraudulently obtain goods or services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-810(4)(b): aids or furthers the individual's efforts to commit a violent felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-901 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Motorcycle Rider Education Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-902 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-902(1): 41-1a-102 "Motorcycle" has the same meaning as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-902(2): 53-3-903 "Program" means the motorcycle rider education program for training and information disbursement created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-902(3): "Rider training course" means a motorcycle rider education curriculum and delivery system approved by the division as meeting national standards designed to develop and instill the knowledge, attitudes, habits, and skills necessary for the safe operation of a motorcycle.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903 Motorcycle Rider Education Program.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(1)(a): The division shall develop standards for and administer the Motorcycle Rider Education Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall make rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(2): The program shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(2)(a): a novice rider training course;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(2)(b): a rider training course for experienced riders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(2)(c): an instructor training course.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(3): The division may expand the program to include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(3)(a): enhancing public awareness of motorcycle riders;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(3)(b): increasing the awareness of motorcycle riders of the effects of alcohol and drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(3)(c): motorcycle rider skills improvement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(3)(d): program and other motorcycle safety promotion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(3)(e): improvement of motorcycle licensing efforts.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4): (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(a): (4)(b) Subject to the restriction in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(a)(i): are at least 15 years 6 months of age; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(a)(ii): either hold a valid learner permit or driver license for any classification or are eligible for a motorcycle learner permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(b): A person who has been issued a learner permit may enroll in and complete a rider training course if the course is conducted on a closed course that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(b)(i): is not conducted on a public highway;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(b)(ii): is approved by the division; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(b)(iii): meets or exceeds established national standards for motorcycle rider training courses prescribed by the Motorcycle Safety Foundation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(c): An adequate number of novice rider training courses shall be provided to meet the reasonably anticipated needs of all persons in the state who are eligible and who desire to participate in the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(4)(d): Program delivery may be phased in over a reasonable period of time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(a): The division may enter into contracts with either public or private institutions to provide a rider training course approved by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(b): The institution shall issue certificates of completion in the manner and form prescribed by the director to persons who satisfactorily complete the requirements of the course.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(c): An institution conducting a rider training course may charge a reasonable tuition fee to cover the cost of offering the course.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(d)(i): The division may use program funds to defray its own expenses in administering the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(d)(ii): The division may reimburse entities that offer approved courses for actual expenses incurred in offering the courses, up to a limit established by the division based upon available program funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(5)(d)(iii): Any reimbursement paid to an entity must be entirely reflected by the entity in reduced course enrollment fees for students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(6): 53-3-904
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(6)(a): Standards for the motorcycle rider training courses, including standards for course curriculum, materials, and student evaluation, and standards for the training and approval of instructors shall meet or exceed established national standards for motorcycle rider training courses prescribed by the Motorcycle Safety Foundation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(6)(b): 53-3-904 Motorcycle rider training courses shall be taught only by instructors approved under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(6)(c): Motorcycle rider training courses for novices shall include at least eight hours of practice riding.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-903(7): The commissioner shall appoint a full-time program coordinator to oversee and direct the program.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904 Instructor training and approval.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(1): The program coordinator shall approve instructors for the motorcycle rider training courses.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(2): A person may not be approved as an instructor unless the person holds a current instructor certification issued by the Motorcycle Safety Foundation or another nationally recognized motorcycle safety instructor certifying body.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3)(a): The program shall include instructor training courses as necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3)(b): Prior to completion of an instructor training course, the participant shall demonstrate:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3)(b)(i): knowledge of the course material;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3)(b)(ii): knowledge of proper motorcycle operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3)(b)(iii): proficiency in riding motorcycles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(3)(b)(iv): the necessary aptitude for instructing students.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(4): An applicant for an instructor training course shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(4)(a): have a high school diploma or its equivalent;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(4)(c): have a valid endorsement to his driver's license for motorcycles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(4)(d): have at least two years of recent motorcycle riding experience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(5): The division shall refuse to certify or revoke certification of an instructor if the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(5)(a): has had his driver's license suspended or revoked during the preceding two years or within the preceding five years if the suspension or revocation was for an alcohol or drug-related offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(5)(b): fails to successfully complete an instructor course or required course updates; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-904(5)(c): no longer meets the requirements of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1001 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Ignition Interlock System Program Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(1): 41-6a-518.2 "Ignition interlock system" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2): (2) "Ignition interlock system provider" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2)(a): is acting on behalf of a business enterprise conducted by a person, association, partnership, or corporation for the purpose of installation and maintenance of an ignition interlock system;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2)(b): is certified as an installer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2)(c): has met the requirements for ignition interlock system provider status as established by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2)(d): is authorized or certified to operate or manage an ignition interlock system business;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2)(e): may supervise the work of another installer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(2)(f): (2) charges a fee for the services described under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(3): "Installer" means a person, whether acting as an ignition interlock system provider or for an ignition interlock system provider for compensation, who is certified by the division to install ignition interlock systems.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(4): 41-6a-518.2 "Interlock restricted driver" has the same meaning as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1002(5): "Provider" means an ignition interlock system provider.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1003 Licenses required -- Inspections.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1003(1): An ignition interlock system provider may be certified to facilitate installation of ignition interlock systems only if the provider applies for and obtains a license from the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1003(2): A person may act as an ignition interlock system installer only if the person applies for and obtains a license from the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1003(3): The division shall inspect the provider facilities and equipment of applicants and licensees and examine applicants for provider licenses and installer licenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1003(4): The division shall administer and enforce this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-3-1008 Violations -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------
A violation of the requirement under this part to be licensed as an ignition interlock system provider or installer is a class C misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201 Findings.
-----------------------------------------
To protect and preserve the individual right to keep and bear arms as guaranteed by the Second Amendment to the United States Constitution andUtah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201(1): the Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees to the state and the state's people all powers not granted to the federal government elsewhere in the United States Constitution and reserves to the state and people of Utah certain powers as those powers were understood at the time that Utah was admitted to statehood;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201(2): the guarantee of powers to the state and the state's people under the Tenth Amendment is a matter of contract between the state and people of Utah and the United States as of the time of statehood;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201(3): the Ninth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees to the people rights not granted in the United States Constitution and reserves to the people of Utah certain rights as those rights were understood at the time that Utah was admitted to statehood;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201(4): the guarantee of rights to the people under the Ninth Amendment is a matter of contract between the state and people of Utah and the United States as of the time of statehood;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201(5): the Second Amendment to the United States Constitution reserves to the people the right to keep and bear arms as that right was understood at the time that Utah was admitted to statehood, and the guarantee of the right is a matter of contract between the state and people of Utah and the United States as of the time of statehood; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-201(6): the Utah Constitution clearly secures to Utah citizens, and prohibits unconstitutional government interference with, the right of individual Utah citizens to keep and bear arms.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(1)(a): "Federal regulation" means a federal executive order, rule, or regulation that infringes upon, prohibits, restricts, or requires individual licensure for, or registration of, the purchase, ownership, possession, transfer, or use of a firearm, ammunition, or firearm accessory.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(1)(b): "Federal regulation" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(1)(b)(i): a federal firearm statute; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(1)(b)(ii): a federal executive order, rule, or regulation that is incorporated into the Utah Code by reference.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(2): 76-10-501 "Firearm" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(3): 53-13-103 "Law enforcement officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-202(4): "Political subdivision" means a city, town, county, special district, or water conservancy district.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203 Prohibition on enforcement.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(1): A law enforcement officer, state employee, or employee of a political subdivision is prohibited from implementing, enforcing, assisting, or cooperating in the enforcement of a federal regulation on firearms, firearm accessories, or ammunition.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(2): An employee of the state or a political subdivision may not expend public funds or allocate public resources for the enforcement of a federal regulation on firearms, firearm accessories, or ammunition.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3): (1); (2) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(a): cooperating, communicating, or collaborating with a federal agency if the primary purpose of the cooperation is not the investigation or enforcement of a federal regulation on firearms, ammunition, or firearm accessories;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b): serving on or participating in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b)(i): a federal law enforcement task force or program if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b)(i)(A): investigation and prosecution of state or federal firearms regulations are part of the duties of the task force or program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b)(i)(B): the law enforcement officer, state employee, or employee of the political subdivision is compensated by federal funds; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b)(ii): a state law enforcement task force or program that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b)(ii)(A): receives federal funding; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(b)(ii)(B): has participation from federal law enforcement officials; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(3)(c): referring an investigation to a federal law enforcement agency if the law enforcement officer, state employee, or political subdivision employee reasonably believes that a federal law regarding firearms, ammunition, or firearm accessories has been violated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(4): 53-10-201; 53-6-103; Title 39A, National Guard and Militia Act This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(4)(a): 53-10-201; 53-6-103; Title 39A, National Guard and Militia Act a law enforcement officer or state employee employed by or assisting:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5a-203(4)(a)(i): 53-10-201 the Bureau of Criminal Identification of the Department of Public Safety established in Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 5b - Utah State-Made Firearms Protection Act
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah State-Made Firearms Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102 Legal considerations.
-----------------------------------------------------
In reviewing any matter covered by this chapter, a court shall consider the following:Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(1): The Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees to the state and its people all powers not granted to the federal government elsewhere in the Constitution and reserves to the state and people of Utah certain powers as they were understood at the time that Utah was admitted to statehood.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(2): The guarantee of powers to the state and its people under the Tenth Amendment is a matter of contract between the state and people of Utah and the United States as of the time of statehood.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(3): The Ninth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees to the people rights not granted in the Constitution and reserves to the people of Utah certain rights as they were understood at the time that Utah was admitted to statehood.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(4): The guarantee of rights to the people under the Ninth Amendment is a matter of contract between the state and people of Utah and the United States as of the time of statehood.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(5): The regulation of intrastate commerce is vested in the state under the Ninth and Tenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(6): The Second Amendment to the United States Constitution reserves to the people the right to keep and bear arms as that right was understood at the time that Utah was admitted to statehood, and the guarantee of the right is a matter of contract between the state and people of Utah and the United States as of the time of statehood.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(7): The Utah Constitution clearly secures to Utah citizens, and prohibits government interference with, the right of individual Utah citizens to keep and bear arms.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(8): A personal firearm, a firearm action or receiver, a firearm accessory, or ammunition that is manufactured commercially or privately in the state to be used or sold within the state is not subject to federal law or federal regulation, including registration, under the authority of congress to regulate interstate commerce.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(9): (8) The Legislature declares that a firearm, a firearm action or receiver, a firearm accessory, and ammunition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(10): The importation into the state of generic and insignificant parts and those parts' incorporation into a firearm, a firearm action or receiver, a firearm accessory, or ammunition manufactured in the state does not subject the firearm, firearm accessory, firearm action or receiver, or ammunition to federal law or regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(11): Basic materials, including unmachined steel and unshaped wood, are not firearms, firearm actions or receivers, firearms accessories, or ammunition.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(12): Trade in basic materials is not subject to congressional authority to regulate firearms, firearm actions or receivers, firearms accessories, and ammunition as if the basic materials were actually firearms, firearm actions or receivers, firearms accessories, or ammunition.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(13): Congress's authority to regulate interstate commerce in basic materials does not include authority to regulate firearms, firearm actions or receivers, firearms accessories, and ammunition made in the state from basic materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-102(14): The attachment or use of firearms accessories in conjunction with a firearm manufactured in the state does not subject the firearm to federal regulation under Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce, without regard to whether the firearms accessories are themselves subject to federal regulation.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(1): "Firearm" means a device from which is expelled a projectile by action of an explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2): "Firearm accessory" means an item that is used in conjunction with or mounted upon a firearm, firearm action, or firearm receiver but is not essential to the basic function of a firearm, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(a): a telescopic or laser sight;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(b): a magazine;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(c): a flash or sound suppressor;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(d): a folding or aftermarket stock or grip;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(e): a speed-loader;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(f): an ammunition carrier; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(2)(g): a light for target illumination.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3): "Generic and insignificant parts:"
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3)(a): means parts that have other manufacturing or consumer product applications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3)(b): includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3)(b)(i): springs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3)(b)(ii): screws;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3)(b)(iii): nuts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(3)(b)(iv): pins.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(4): "Manufactured" means creating a firearm, a firearm action or receiver, a firearm accessory, or ammunition from basic materials for functional usefulness, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(4)(a): forging;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(4)(b): casting;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(4)(c): machining; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-103(4)(d): another process for working materials.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201 Intrastate firearm manufacturing.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201(1): This chapter applies to a firearm, a firearm action or receiver, a firearm accessory, or ammunition that is manufactured in the state to remain in the state from basic materials that can be manufactured without the inclusion of any significant parts imported into the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201(2): This chapter does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201(2)(a): a firearm that cannot be carried and used by one person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201(2)(b): a firearm that has a bore diameter greater than 1-1/2 inches and that uses smokeless powder, not black powder, as a propellant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201(2)(c): a firearm that discharges two or more projectiles with one activation of the trigger or other firing device, other than a shotgun; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-201(2)(d): ammunition with a projectile that explodes using an explosion of chemical energy after the projectile leaves the firearm.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-5b-202 Required markings.
--------------------------------------------------
A firearm, firearm action, or firearm receiver manufactured or sold in Utah under this chapter must have the words "Made in Utah" or "Made in UT" clearly stamped on a central metallic part, such as the receiver or frame.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 5d - Lawful Commerce in Arms Act
*************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Lawful Commerce in Arms Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(1): "Ammunition" means a bullet, a cartridge case, primer, propellant powder, or other ammunition designed for use in any firearm, either as an individual component part or in a completely assembled cartridge.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(2): "Manufacturer" means, with respect to a qualified product, a person who is engaged in the business of manufacturing a qualified product and who is licensed to engage in business as a manufacturer under 18 U.S.C. Chapter 44.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(3): "Negligent entrustment" means the supplying of a qualified product by a seller for use by another person when the seller knows, or reasonably should know, the person to whom the product is supplied is likely to, and does, use the product in a manner involving unreasonable risk of physical injury to the person or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(4): 68-3-12.5 "Person" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5): 76-10-503; 76-10-503; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(a): "Qualified civil liability action" means a civil action or proceeding or an administrative proceeding brought by any person against a manufacturer or seller of a qualified product, or a trade association, for damages, punitive damages, injunctive or declaratory relief, abatement, restitution, fines, or penalties, or other relief, resulting from the criminal or unlawful misuse of a qualified product by the person or a third party.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b): 76-10-503; 76-10-503; Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons "Qualified civil liability action" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(i): 76-10-503 an action brought against a transferor convicted under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 924(h) or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(ii): an action brought against a seller for negligent entrustment or negligence per se;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(iii): 76-10-503 an action in which a manufacturer or seller of a qualified product knowingly violated a state or federal statute applicable to the sale or marketing of the product, and the violation was a proximate cause of the harm for which relief is sought, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(iii)(A): any incident in which the manufacturer or seller knowingly made any false entry in, or failed to make appropriate entry in, any record required to be kept under federal or state law with respect to the qualified product, or aided, abetted, or conspired with any person in making any false or fictitious oral or written statement with respect to any fact material to the lawfulness of the sale or other disposition of a qualified product; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(iii)(B): 76-10-503 any case in which the manufacturer or seller aided, abetted, or conspired with any other person to sell or otherwise dispose of a qualified product, knowing, or having reasonable cause to believe, that the actual buyer of the qualified product was prohibited from possessing or receiving a firearm or ammunition under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 922(g) or (n) or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(iv): an action for breach of contract or warranty in connection with the purchase of the product;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(v): an action for death, physical injuries, or property damage resulting directly from a defect in design or manufacture of the product, when used as intended or in a reasonably foreseeable manner, except that where the discharge of the product was caused by a volitional act that constituted a criminal offense, then the act shall be considered the sole proximate cause of any resulting death, personal injuries, or property damage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(5)(b)(vi): Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons an action or proceeding commenced to enforce the provisions of 18 U.S.C. Chapter 44, 26 U.S.C. Chapter 53, or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(6): 76-10-501 "Qualified product" means a firearm or antique firearm, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(7): 76-10-501 "Seller" means, with respect to a qualified product, a federal firearms licensee, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(8): "Trade association" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(8)(a): any corporation, unincorporated association, federation, business league, or professional or business organization not organized or operated for profit and no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(8)(b): an organization described in 26 U.S.C. Sec. 501(c)(6) and exempt from tax under 26 U.S.C. Sec. 501(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(8)(c): an organization, two or more members of which are manufacturers or sellers of a qualified product.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-102(9): "Unlawful misuse" means conduct that violates a statute, ordinance, or regulation as it relates to the use of a qualified product.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-103 Limitations on liability.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-103(1): A manufacturer or seller of a qualified product, or trade association, is not subject to a qualified civil liability action regarding the unlawful misuse of a qualified product unless an injury or death results from an act or omission of the manufacturer, seller, or trade association that constitutes gross negligence, recklessness, or intentional misconduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-5d-103(2): 53-5d-102(5)(b) A civil liability action against a manufacturer, seller, or trade association that does not allege any of the provisions of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 6 - Peace Officer Standards and Training Act
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Peace Officer Standards and Training Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(1): "Addiction" means the unlawful or habitual use of alcohol or a controlled substance which endangers public health and safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(2): 53-6-105 "Certified academy" means a peace officer training institution certified in accordance with the standards developed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(3): 53-6-106 "Council" means the Peace Officer Standards and Training Council created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4): "Conviction" means an adjudication of guilt regarding criminal conduct, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(a): a finding of guilt by a court or a jury;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(b): a guilty plea;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(c): a plea of nolo contendere;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(d): a plea which is held in abeyance pending the successful completion of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(d)(i): a probationary period; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(d)(ii): a diversion agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(4)(e): a conviction which has been expunged or dismissed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(5): 53-6-104 "Director" means the director of the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(6): "Dispatcher" means an employee of a public safety agency of the state or any of its political subdivisions and whose primary duties are to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(6)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(6)(a)(i): receive calls for one or a combination of, emergency police, fire, and medical services, and to dispatch the appropriate personnel and equipment in response to the calls; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(6)(a)(ii): in response to emergency calls, make urgent decisions affecting the life, health, and welfare of the public and public safety employees; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(6)(b): supervise dispatchers or direct a dispatch communication center.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(7): 53-6-103 "Division" means the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-102(8): "POST" means the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-103 Peace Officer Standards and Training Division -- Creation -- Administration -- Duties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-103(1): There is created within the department the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-103(2): The division shall be administered by a director acting under the supervision and control of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-103(3): The division shall promote and ensure the safety and welfare of the citizens of this state in their respective communities and provide for efficient and professional law enforcement by establishing minimum standards and training for peace officers and dispatchers throughout the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-104 Appointment of director of division -- Qualifications -- Appointment of employees -- Term of office -- Compensation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-104(1): The commissioner, upon recommendation of the council and with the approval of the governor, shall appoint a director of the  division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-104(2): The director is the executive and administrative head of the division and shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-104(3): The director shall be a full-time officer of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-104(4): The director may appoint deputies, consultants, clerks, and other employees from eligibility lists authorized by the Division of Human Resource Management.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-104(5): The director may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105 Duties of director -- Powers -- Rulemaking.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The director, with the advice of the council, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(a): prescribe standards for the certification of a peace officer training academy, certify an academy that meets the prescribed standards, and prescribe standards for revocation of certification for cause;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(b): prescribe minimum qualifications for certification of peace officers appointed or elected to enforce the laws of this state and its subdivisions and prescribe standards for revocation of certification for cause;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(c): establish minimum requirements for the certification of training instructors and establish standards for revocation of certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(d): provide for the issuance of appropriate certificates to those peace officers completing the basic training programs offered by a certified academy or those persons who pass a certification examination as provided for in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(e): consult and cooperate with certified academy administrators and instructors for the continued development and improvement of the basic training programs provided by the certified academy and for the further development and implementation of advanced in-service training programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(f): consult and cooperate with state institutions of higher education to develop specialized courses of study for peace officers in the areas of criminal justice, police administration, criminology, social sciences, and other related disciplines;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(g): consult and cooperate with other departments, agencies, and local governments concerned with peace officer training;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(h): perform any other acts necessary to develop peace officer training programs within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(i): report to the council at regular meetings of the council and when the council requires;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(j): recommend peace officer standards and training requirements to the commissioner, governor, and the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(1)(k): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(2): With the permission of the commissioner, the director may execute contracts on behalf of the division with criminal justice agencies to provide training for employees of those agencies if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(2)(a): the employees or the employing agency pay a registration fee equivalent to the cost of the training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(2)(b): the contract does not reduce the effectiveness of the division in its primary responsibility of providing training for peace officers of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(3): The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(3)(a): revoke certification of a certified academy for cause; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(3)(b): make training aids and materials available to local law enforcement agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(4): The director shall, with the advice of the council, make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(4)(a): establishing minimum requirements for the certification of dispatcher training instructors in a certified academy or interagency program and standards for revocation of this certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(4)(b): establishing approved curriculum and a basic schedule for the basic dispatcher training course and the content of the dispatcher certification examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(4)(c): providing for the issuance of appropriate certificates to a person who completes the basic dispatcher course or who passes a dispatcher certification examination as provided for in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(4)(d): establishing approved courses for certified dispatchers' annual training; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(4)(e): establishing a reinstatement procedure for a certified dispatcher who has not obtained the required annual training hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-105(5): The director may not, in approving and reviewing curriculum and training aids for academies, approve or recommend any curriculum which includes the use of chokeholds, carotid restraints, or any act that impedes the breathing or circulation of blood likely to produce a loss of consciousness, as a valid method of restraint.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106 Creation of Peace Officer Standards and Training Council -- Purpose -- Membership -- Quorum -- Meetings -- Compensation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(1): There is created the Peace Officer Standards and Training Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(2): The council shall serve as an advisory board to the director of the division on matters relating to peace officer and dispatcher standards and training.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3): The council includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(a): the attorney general or a designated representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(b): the superintendent of the highway patrol or a designated representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(c): the executive director of the Department of Corrections or a designated representative; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d): 14 additional members appointed by the governor having qualifications, experience, or education in the field of law enforcement as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(i): one incumbent mayor;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(ii): one incumbent county commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(iii): three incumbent sheriffs, one of whom is a representative of the Utah Sheriffs Association, one of whom is from a county having a population of 100,000 or more, and one of whom is from a county having a population of less than 100,000;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(iv): three incumbent police chiefs, one of whom is a representative of the Utah Chiefs of Police Association, one of whom is from a city of the first or second class, and one of whom is from a city of the third, fourth, or fifth class or town;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(v): one representative of the Utah Peace Officers Association;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(vi): one educator in the field of public administration, criminal justice, or a related area;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(vii): one current Utah certified law enforcement officer, employed in a non-supervisory role, rotated every term; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-106(3)(d)(viii): three persons selected at large by the governor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-201 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Peace Officer Training and Certification Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202 Basic training course -- Completion required -- Annual training -- Prohibition from exercising powers -- Reinstatement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1)(a): The director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1)(a)(i)(A): suggest and prepare subject material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1)(a)(i)(B): schedule instructors for basic training courses; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1)(a)(ii): review the material and instructor choices submitted by a certified academy.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(1)(b): The subject material, instructors, and schedules shall be approved or disapproved by a majority vote of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(2): The materials shall be reviewed and approved by the council on or before July 1st of each year and may from time to time be changed or amended by majority vote of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(3): 76-3-203.14 The basic training in a certified academy:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(3)(a): shall be appropriate for the basic training of peace officers in the techniques of law enforcement in the discretion of the director;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(3)(b): may not include the use of chokeholds, carotid restraints, or any act that impedes the breathing or circulation of blood likely to produce a loss of consciousness, as a valid method of restraint; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(3)(c): 76-3-203.14 shall include instruction on identifying, responding to, and reporting a criminal offense that is motivated by a personal attribute as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(4)(a): All peace officers shall satisfactorily complete the basic training course or the waiver process provided for in this chapter as well as annual certified training of not less than 40 hours as the director, with the advice and consent of the council, directs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(4)(b): A peace officer who fails to satisfactorily complete the annual training described in Subsection (4)(a) shall automatically be prohibited from exercising peace officer powers until any deficiency is made up.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(4)(c): The annual training described in Subsection (4)(a) shall include training focused on arrest control and de-escalation training.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(5): 53-10-908
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(5)(a): 53-10-908 Beginning July 1, 2024, all peace officers who are currently employed shall participate in a training at least every three years focused on the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(5)(a)(i): mental health and other crisis intervention responses;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(5)(a)(ii): intervention responses for mental illnesses, autism spectrum disorder, and other neurological and developmental disorders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(5)(a)(iii): 53-10-908 responses to sexual traumas and investigations of sexual assault and sexual abuse in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(5)(b): Any training in which a peace officer participates as described in Subsection (5)(a) shall count toward the peace officer's 40-hour required annual training described in Subsection (4)(a) for the year in which the peace officer participated in the training.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(6)(a): The director or the director's designee, in coordination with the council, shall promulgate the standards for the trainings described in Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-202(6)(b): The chief law enforcement officer or executive officer of the peace officer's employing agency shall determine if a peace officer has complied with the standards established under Subsection (6)(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203 Applicants for admission to training programs or for certification examination -- Requirements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1): Before being accepted for admission to the training programs conducted by a certified academy, and before being allowed to take a certification examination, each applicant for admission or certification examination shall meet the following requirements:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(a): be:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(a)(i): a United States citizen;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(a)(ii): a United States national; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(a)(iii): a lawful permanent resident of the United States who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(a)(iii)(A): has been in the United States legally for the five years immediately before the day on which the application is made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(a)(iii)(B): has legal authorization to work in the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(b): be at least:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(b)(i): 19 years old at the time of certification as a special function officer or  correctional officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(b)(ii): 21 years old at the time of certification as a law enforcement officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(c): be a high school graduate or furnish evidence of successful completion of an examination indicating an equivalent achievement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(d): have not been convicted of a crime for which the applicant could have been punished by imprisonment in a federal penitentiary or by imprisonment in the penitentiary of this or another state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(e): have demonstrated good moral character, as determined by a background investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(f): be free of any physical, emotional, or mental condition that might adversely affect the performance of the applicant's duties as a peace officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(1)(g): meet all other standards required by POST.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(2)(a): An application for admission to a training program shall be accompanied by a criminal history background check of local, state, and national criminal history files and a background investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(2)(b): The costs of the background check and investigation shall be borne by the applicant or the applicant's employing agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(3)(a): Notwithstanding any expungement statute or rule of any other jurisdiction, any conviction obtained in this state or other jurisdiction, including a conviction that has been expunged, dismissed, or treated in a similar manner to either of these procedures, may be considered for purposes of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(3)(b): This provision applies to convictions entered both before and after the effective date of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(4): Any background check or background investigation performed under the requirements of this section shall be to determine eligibility for admission to training programs or qualification for certification examinations and may not be used as a replacement for any background investigations that may be required of an employing agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(5): 53-6-211 An applicant shall be considered to be of good moral character under Subsection (1)(e) if the applicant has not engaged in conduct that would be a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-203(6): 53-13-103 An applicant seeking certification as a law enforcement officer, as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-207 Municipalities may set higher minimum standards.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The minimum standards in this part concerning peace officer qualifications and training  do not preclude counties, cities, or towns from establishing standards higher than the minimum standards contained in this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208 Inactive certificates -- Lapse of certificate -- Reinstatement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208(1)(a): The certificate of a peace officer who has not been actively engaged in performing the duties as a certified and sworn peace officer for 18 consecutive months or more, but less than four consecutive years, is designated "inactive."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208(1)(b): A peace officer whose certificate is inactive shall pass the certification examination and a physical fitness test before the certificate may be reissued or reinstated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208(2)(a): The certificate of a peace officer who has not been actively engaged in performing the duties as a certified and sworn peace officer for four continuous years or more is designated as "lapsed."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-208(2)(b): A peace officer whose certificate is lapsed shall pass the basic training course at a certified academy, the certification examination, and a physical fitness test before the certificate may be reissued or reinstated.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209 Termination of employment -- Change of status form.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(1): When a peace officer's employment terminates, the employing agency shall submit a change of status form noting the termination of the peace officer to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(2): The change of status form shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(2)(a): be completed and submitted within 30 days after the day on which the peace officer's employment terminates;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(2)(b): identify the circumstances of the peace officer's status change by indicating that the peace officer has resigned, retired, terminated, transferred, is deceased, or that the peace officer's name has changed;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(2)(c): indicate the effective date of action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(2)(d): indicate the name of the new employer, if the status change is due to a transfer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(3): 53-6-211(1); 53-6-211(6) If a peace officer's employment terminates during an open internal investigation regarding that peace officer and involving an alleged violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(3)(a): 53-6-211(6) notify the division of the investigation in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(3)(b): provide a reasonable estimated date of completion for the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(4): (4)(a); 53-6-211(1); 53-6-211(6)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(4)(a): If an employing agency receives credible allegations and opens an internal investigation within two years after the day on which a peace officer's employment terminates, the employing agency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(4)(a)(i): notify the division within 30 days after the day on which the employing agency opens the investigation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(4)(a)(ii): provide a reasonable estimated date of completion for the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(4)(b): (4)(a); 53-6-211(1); 53-6-211(6) If the allegations described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(5): 53B-8-112.5
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(5)(a): Any person or agency who intentionally falsifies, misrepresents, or fails to give notice of the change of status of a peace officer is liable to the division for any damages that the failure to make the notification causes.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-209(5)(b): 53B-8-112.5 The division shall provide the change of status form described in this section to the Utah Board of Higher Education within 30 days after the day on which the division receives a notice of termination if the relevant peace officer has received a Karen Mayne Public Safety Officer Scholarship as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210 Investigations and certification hearings -- Powers of division -- Violation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210(1): For investigations by the division and for certification hearings or other testimony before the council, the division may administer oaths and affirmations, subpoena witnesses, take evidence, and require by subpoena duces tecum the production of relevant papers, records, or other documents or information, whether filed or kept in original form, or electronically stored or recorded.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210(2): A person who willfully disobeys a properly served subpoena issued by the division is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5 Duty to intervene or report officer misconduct.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1): 53-13-102; Title 76, Chapter 2, Part 4, Justification Excluding Criminal Responsibility As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(a): "Adverse action" means to discharge, threaten, or discriminate against an employee in a manner that affects the employee's employment, including compensation, terms, conditions, location, rights, immunities, promotions, or privileges.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(b): "Law enforcement agency" means an agency that is part of or administered by the state or any of the state's political subdivisions and whose primary and principal role is the prevention and detection of crime and the enforcement of criminal statutes or ordinances of this state or any of the state's political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(c): 53-13-102 "Officer" means the same as peace officer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(d): Title 76, Chapter 2, Part 4, Justification Excluding Criminal Responsibility "Police misconduct" means conduct by an officer in the course of the officer's official duties that constitutes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(d)(i): Title 76, Chapter 2, Part 4, Justification Excluding Criminal Responsibility force that is clearly excessive in type or duration, clearly beyond what is objectively reasonable under the circumstances, or clearly not subject to legal justification under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(d)(ii): a search or seizure without a warrant where it is clear, under the circumstances, that the search or seizure would not fit within an exception to the warrant requirement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(d)(iii): conduct that an objectively reasonable person would consider biased or discriminatory conduct against one or more individuals based on race, color, sex, pregnancy, age, religion, national origin, disability, sexual orientation, or gender identity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(e)(i): "Retaliatory action" means any adverse action, formal or informal, taken by a law enforcement agency or any of the law enforcement agency's employees, or by any individual with authority to oversee or direct a law enforcement agency, solely as a result of a law enforcement officer's or law enforcement agency employee's good faith actions in conformance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(1)(e)(ii): "Retaliatory action" does not mean education, training, or administrative discussion requested or required by a law enforcement agency or any of the law enforcement agency's employees, or by any individual with authority to oversee or direct a law enforcement agency, following or in connection with a law enforcement officer's or law enforcement agency employee's good faith actions taken in conformance with this section.
