Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-210.5(5)(b): The threshold standards in this section do not preclude a law enforcement agency from adopting policies or establishing standards higher than the standards contained in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211 Suspension or revocation of certification -- Right to a hearing -- Grounds -- Notice to employer -- Reporting -- Judicial appeal.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1): 53-13-102 The council has the authority to issue a Letter of Caution, or suspend or revoke the certification of a peace officer, if the peace officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(a): willfully falsifies any information to obtain certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(b): has any physical or mental disability affecting the peace officer's ability to perform duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(c): engages in, or is convicted of, conduct constituting a state or federal criminal offense, but not including a traffic offense that is a class C misdemeanor or infraction;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(d): refuses to respond, or fails to respond truthfully, to questions after having been issued a warning issued based on Garrity v. New Jersey, 385 U.S. 493 (1967);
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(e): engages in sexual conduct while on duty;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(f): 53-13-102 is certified as a law enforcement peace officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(g): is found by a court or by a law enforcement agency to have knowingly engaged in conduct that involves dishonesty or deception in violation of a policy of the peace officer's employer or in violation of a state or federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(h): is found by a court or by a law enforcement agency to have knowingly engaged in biased or prejudicial conduct against one or more individuals based on the individual's race, color, sex, pregnancy, age, religion, national origin, disability, sexual orientation, or gender identity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(1)(i): is a chief, sheriff, or administrative officer of a law enforcement agency and fails to comply with Subsection (6).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(2): The council may not issue a Letter of Caution or suspend or revoke the certification of a peace officer for a violation of state or federal law or a violation of a law enforcement agency's policies, general orders, or guidelines of operation that do not amount to a cause of action under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(a): The division is responsible for investigating officers who are alleged to have engaged in conduct in violation of Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(b): The division shall initiate all adjudicative proceedings under this section by providing to the peace officer involved notice and an opportunity for a hearing before an administrative law judge.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(c): All adjudicative proceedings under this section are civil actions, notwithstanding whether the issue in the adjudicative proceeding is a violation of statute that may be prosecuted criminally.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(d)(i): The burden of proof on the division in an adjudicative proceeding under this section is by clear and convincing evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(d)(ii): If a peace officer asserts an affirmative defense, the peace officer has the burden of proof to establish the affirmative defense by a preponderance of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(e): If the administrative law judge issues findings of fact and conclusions of law stating there is sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the officer engaged in conduct that is in violation of Subsection (1), the division shall present the finding and conclusions issued by the administrative law judge to the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(f): The division shall notify the chief, sheriff, or administrative officer of the police agency which employs the involved peace officer of the investigation and shall provide any information or comments concerning the peace officer received from that agency regarding the peace officer to the council before a Letter of Caution is issued, or a peace officer's certification may be suspended or revoked.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(3)(g): If the administrative law judge finds that there is insufficient evidence to demonstrate that the officer is in violation of Subsection (1), the administrative law judge shall dismiss the adjudicative proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(a): The council shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(a)(i): accept the administrative law judge's findings of fact and conclusions of law, and the information concerning the peace officer provided by the officer's employing agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(a)(ii): choose whether to issue a Letter of Caution, or suspend or revoke the officer's certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(b): Before making a decision, the council may consider aggravating and mitigating circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(c): A member of the council shall recuse him or herself from consideration of an issue that is before the council if the council member:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(c)(i): has a personal bias for or against the officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(c)(ii): has a substantial pecuniary interest in the outcome of the proceeding and may gain or lose some benefit from the outcome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(4)(c)(iii): employs, supervises, or works for the same law enforcement agency as the officer whose case is before the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(5)(a): Termination of a peace officer, whether voluntary or involuntary, does not preclude suspension or revocation of a peace officer's certification by the council if the peace officer was terminated for any of the reasons under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(5)(b): Employment by another agency, or reinstatement of a peace officer by the original employing agency after termination by that agency, whether the termination was voluntary or involuntary, does not preclude suspension or revocation of a peace officer's certification by the council if the peace officer was terminated for any of the reasons under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(6)(a): A chief, sheriff, or administrative officer of a law enforcement agency who is made aware of an allegation against a peace officer employed by that agency that involves conduct in violation of Subsections (1)(a) through (h) shall conduct an administrative or internal investigation into the allegation and report the findings of the investigation to the division if the allegation is substantiated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(6)(b): If a peace officer who is the subject of an internal or administrative investigation into allegations that include any of the conditions or circumstances outlined in Subsections (1)(a) through (h) resigns, retires, or otherwise separates from the investigating law enforcement agency before the conclusion of the investigation, the chief, sheriff, or administrative officer of that law enforcement agency shall complete the investigation and report the findings to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211(7): The council's issuance of a Letter of Caution, or suspension or revocation of an officer's certification under Subsection (4) may be appealed under Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211.5 Voluntary relinquishment of peace officer certification.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211.5(1): A peace officer may voluntarily relinquish the peace officer's certification to the division at any time when a disciplinary issue regarding the peace officer has been referred to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211.5(2): 53-6-208
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211.5(2)(a): A peace officer who voluntarily relinquishes certification under this section may not subsequently be certified as a peace officer in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-211.5(2)(b): 53-6-208 This section does not apply to a peace officer whose certification has become inactive or has lapsed as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-301 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Dispatcher Training and Certification Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302 Applicants for certification examination -- Requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1): Before being allowed to take a dispatcher certification examination, each applicant shall meet the following requirements:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(a): be:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(a)(i): a United States citizen;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(a)(ii): a United States national; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(a)(iii): a lawful permanent resident of the United States who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(a)(iii)(A): has been in the United States legally for the five years immediately before the day on which the application is made; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(a)(iii)(B): has legal authorization to work in the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(b): be 18 years old or older at the time of employment as a dispatcher;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(c): be a high school graduate or have a G.E.D. equivalent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(d): have not been convicted of a crime for which the applicant could have been punished by imprisonment in a federal penitentiary or by imprisonment in the penitentiary of this or another state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(e): have demonstrated good moral character, as determined by a background investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(f): be free of any physical, emotional, or mental condition that might adversely affect the performance of the applicant's duty as a dispatcher; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(1)(g): meet all other standards required by POST.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(2)(a): An application for certification shall be accompanied by a criminal history background check of local, state, and national criminal history files and a background investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(2)(b): The costs of the background check and investigation shall be borne by the applicant or the applicant's employing agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(3)(a): Notwithstanding Title 77, Chapter 40a, Expungement of Criminal Records, regarding expungements, or a similar statute or rule of any other jurisdiction, any conviction obtained in this state or other jurisdiction, including a conviction that has been expunged, dismissed, or treated in a similar manner to either of these procedures, may be considered for purposes of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(3)(b): Subsection (3)(a) applies to convictions entered both before and after May 1, 1995.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(4): Any background check or background investigation performed under the requirements of this section shall be to determine eligibility for admission to training programs or qualification for certification examinations and may not be used as a replacement for any background investigations that may be required of an employing agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-302(5): 53-6-309 An applicant is considered to be of good moral character under Subsection (1)(e) if the applicant has not engaged in conduct that would be a violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-305 Local governments -- Option -- Higher minimum standards.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-305(1): Participation in dispatcher training and certification under this part is at the option of the legislative body of each county or municipality that employs dispatchers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-305(2): The minimum standards in this part concerning dispatcher qualifications and training do not preclude counties or municipalities from establishing standards higher than the minimum standards contained in this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306 Inactive and lapsed certificates -- Reissuance or reinstatement -- Annual training requirement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(1)(a): The certificate of a dispatcher who has not been actively engaged in performing the duties of a dispatcher for 18 consecutive months or more is designated "inactive."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(1)(b): A dispatcher whose certificate is inactive shall pass the certification examination before the certificate may be reissued or reinstated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(2)(a): The certificate of a dispatcher who has not been actively engaged in performing the duties of a dispatcher for four continuous years shall be designated "lapsed."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(2)(b): A dispatcher whose certificate has lapsed shall successfully complete the basic training course and pass the certification examination before the certificate may be reissued or reinstated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(3)(a): A certified dispatcher shall complete annual training approved by the director of 20 hours or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-306(3)(b): If a dispatcher fails to satisfactorily complete the annual training, the dispatcher's certificate shall be suspended until any deficiency in the annual training is remedied.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307 Termination of employment -- Change of status form.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(1): When a certified dispatcher's employment terminates or a certified dispatcher's status changes, the employing agency shall submit a change of status form noting the termination of the certified dispatcher to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(2): The change of status form shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(2)(a): be completed and submitted within 30 days of the certified dispatcher's termination date;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(2)(b): identify the circumstances of the certified dispatcher's status change by indicating that the certified dispatcher has resigned, retired, terminated, transferred, deceased, or that the certified dispatcher's name has changed;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(2)(c): indicate the effective date of action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(2)(d): indicate the name of the new employer, if the status change is due to a transfer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-307(3): Any person or agency who intentionally falsifies, misrepresents, or fails to give notice of the change of status of a certified dispatcher is liable to the division for any damages that may be sustained by the failure to make the notification.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-308 Investigations and certification hearings -- Powers of division -- Violation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-308(1): For investigations by the division and for certification hearings or other testimony before the council, the division may administer oaths and affirmations, subpoena witnesses, take evidence, and require by subpoena duces tecum the production of relevant papers, records, or other documents or information, whether filed or kept in original form, or electronically stored or recorded.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-308(2): A person who willfully disobeys a properly served subpoena issued by the division is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309 Suspension or revocation of certification -- Right to a hearing -- Grounds -- Notice to employer -- Reporting.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(1): The council has the authority to issue a Letter of Caution, or suspend or revoke the certification of a dispatcher, if the dispatcher:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(1)(a): willfully falsifies any information to obtain certification;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(1)(b): has any physical or mental disability affecting the dispatcher's ability to perform duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(1)(c): engages in, or is convicted of, conduct constituting a state or federal criminal offense, but not including a traffic offense that is a class C misdemeanor or infraction;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(1)(d): refuses to respond, or fails to respond truthfully, to questions after having been issued a warning based on Garrity v. New Jersey, 385 U.S. 493 (1967); or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(1)(e): engages in sexual conduct while on duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(2): The council may not issue a Letter of Caution, or suspend or revoke the certification of a dispatcher for a violation of the employing agency's policies, general orders, or guidelines of operation that do not amount to a cause of action under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(a): The division is responsible for investigating dispatchers who are alleged to have engaged in conduct in violation of Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(b): The division shall initiate all adjudicative proceedings under this section by providing to the dispatcher involved notice and an opportunity for a hearing before an administrative law judge.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(c): All adjudicative proceedings under this section are civil actions, notwithstanding whether the issue in the adjudicative proceeding is a violation of statute that may be prosecuted criminally.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(d)(i): The burden of proof on the division in an adjudicative proceeding under this section is by clear and convincing evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(d)(ii): If a dispatcher asserts an affirmative defense, the dispatcher has the burden of proof to establish the affirmative defense by a preponderance of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(e): If the administrative law judge issues findings of fact and conclusions of law stating there is sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the dispatcher engaged in conduct that is in violation of Subsection (1), the division shall present the findings and conclusions issued by the administrative law judge to the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(f): The division shall notify the agency that employs the involved dispatcher of the investigation and shall provide any information or comments concerning the dispatcher received from that agency regarding the dispatcher to the council before a Letter of Caution is issued, or a dispatcher's certification may be suspended or revoked.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(3)(g): If the administrative law judge finds that there is insufficient evidence to demonstrate that the dispatcher is in violation of Subsection (1), the administrative law judge shall dismiss the adjudicative proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(a): The council shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(a)(i): accept the administrative law judge's findings of fact and conclusions of law and the information concerning the dispatcher provided by the dispatcher's employing agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(a)(ii): choose whether to issue a Letter of Caution, or suspend or revoke the dispatcher's certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(b): Before making a decision, the council may consider aggravating and mitigating circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(c): A council member shall recuse himself or herself from consideration of an issue that is before the council if the council member:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(c)(i): has a personal bias for or against the dispatcher;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(c)(ii): has a substantial pecuniary interest in the outcome of the proceeding and may gain or lose some benefit from the outcome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(4)(c)(iii): employs, supervises, or works for the same agency as the dispatcher whose case is before the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(5)(a): Termination of a dispatcher, whether voluntary or involuntary, does not preclude suspension or revocation of a dispatcher's certification by the council if the dispatcher was terminated for any of the reasons under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(5)(b): Employment by another agency, or reinstatement of a dispatcher by the original employing agency after termination by that agency, whether the termination was voluntary or involuntary, does not preclude suspension or revocation of a dispatcher's certification by the council if the dispatcher was terminated for any of the reasons under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(6)(a): An agency that is made aware of an allegation against a dispatcher employed by that agency that involves conduct in violation of Subsection (1) shall investigate the allegation and report to the division if the allegation is found to be true.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(6)(b): If a dispatcher who is the subject of an internal or administrative investigation into allegations that include any of the conditions or circumstances outlined in Subsection (1) resigns, retires, or otherwise separates from the investigating law enforcement agency before the conclusion of the investigation, the agency shall report the allegations and any investigation results to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-309(7): The council's issuance of a Letter of Caution, or suspension or revocation of an officer's certification under Subsection (4) may be appealed under Title 63G, Chapter 4, Part 4, Judicial Review.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-310 Responsibility for training -- Certification.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-310(1): The division is not responsible for providing basic or in-service training for certified dispatchers except for approval of the instructors and content of training where required by this chapter or division rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-6-310(2): Where this chapter requires an agency head to certify that a member has completed required training, the division shall rely on the certification, as provided, to be accurate.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104 Enforcement of state fire code and rules -- Division of authority and responsibility.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104(1): The authority and responsibility for enforcing the state fire code and rules made under this chapter is divided as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104(2): The fire officers of any city or county shall enforce the state fire code and rules of the state fire marshal in their respective areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104(3): The state fire marshal may enforce the state fire code and rules in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104(3)(a): areas outside of corporate cities, fire protection districts, and other special districts or special service districts organized for fire protection purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104(3)(b): state-owned property, school district owned property, and privately owned property used for schools located within corporate cities and county fire protection districts, asylums, mental hospitals, hospitals, sanitariums, homes for the aged, residential health-care facilities, children's homes or institutions, or similar institutional type occupancy of any capacity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-104(3)(c): corporate cities, counties, fire protection districts, and special service districts organized for fire protection purposes upon receiving a request from the chief fire official or the local governing body.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-105 State fire marshal, deputies, and investigators -- Status of law enforcement officers -- Inclusion in Public Safety Retirement -- Training.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-105(3): The commissioner, with the concurrence of the Peace Officer Standards and Training Advisory Board may require peace officer standards and training for the state fire marshal, his deputies, and investigators.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-201 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Fire Prevention and Fireworks Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(1): "Agricultural and wildlife fireworks" means a division 1.4G dangerous explosive that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(1)(a): uses sound or light when deployed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(1)(b): is designated to prevent crop damage or unwanted animals from entering a specified area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(2): "Commercial cooking appliance fire suppression system":
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(2)(a): means an automatic or manual fire protection system designed for commercial cooking appliances, exhaust hoods, and ducts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(2)(b): includes a commercial kitchen exhaust system attached to a fire suppression system that is designed to remove smoke, soot, toxic gases, and grease-laden vapor resulting from cooking operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(3)(a): "Display fireworks" means large firework devices that consist of explosive materials that are intended for use in outdoor aerial fireworks displays to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(3)(b): "Display fireworks" includes aerial shells, salutes, roman candles, flash shells, comets, mines, and other similar explosives.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(4): 53-7-223
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(4)(a): 53-7-223 "Display operator" means a person licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(4)(b): "Display operator" does not mean a fire department.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(5): "Division 1.4G common state approved explosive" means a firework that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(5)(a): is purchased at retail for use by a consumer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(5)(b): is not a division 1.4G dangerous explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a): "Division 1.4G dangerous explosive" means a division 1.4G explosive that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(i): a firecracker, cannon cracker, ground salute, M-80, cherry bomb, or other similar explosive;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(ii)(A): a skyrocket;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(ii)(B): a missile type rocket;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(ii)(C): a single shot or reloadable aerial shell; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(ii)(D): a rocket similar to an item described in Subsection (6)(a)(ii)(A), (B), or (C), including an aerial salute, a flash shell, a comet, a mine, or a cake containing more than 500 grams of pyrotechnic composition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(iii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(iii)(A): a bottle rocket;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(iii)(B): a roman candle;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(iii)(C): a rocket mounted on a wire or stick; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(a)(iii)(D): a device containing a rocket described in this Subsection (6)(a)(iii).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(6)(b): "Division 1.4G dangerous explosive" does not mean an exempt explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(7): "Division 1.1G explosive" means an explosive described in 49 C.F.R. Sec. 173.50 (b)(1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(8): "Division 1.2G explosive" means an explosive described in 49 C.F.R. Sec. 173.50 (b)(2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(9): "Division 1.3G explosive" means an explosive described in 49 C.F.R. Sec. 173.50(b)(3).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(10): "Division 1.4G explosive" means an explosive described in 49 C.F.R. Sec. 173.50 (b)(4).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(11): "Exempt explosive" means a model rocket, toy pistol cap, emergency signal flare, snake or glow worm, party popper, trick noisemaker, match, and wire sparkler under 12 inches in length.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(12): "Fire executive" means a fire chief, deputy fire chief, or other active member of a fire department or fire district who has been appointed by the elected officials of a municipality or county, by a fire district board, or by an established procedure within a volunteer fire service organization, to officially represent a fire department.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(13): "Fire extinguisher" means a portable or stationary device that discharges water, foam, gas, or other material to extinguish a fire.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(14): "Fire suppression system" means an automatic fire protection system that automatically detects fire and discharges a fire extinguishing agent onto or in the area of the fire.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(a): "Fireworks" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(a)(i): a division 1.4G explosive;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(a)(ii): a division 1.4G dangerous explosive; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(a)(iii): a division 1.4G common state approved explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(b): "Fireworks" does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(b)(i): an exempt explosive; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(15)(b)(ii): a division 1.1G explosive, a division 1.12 explosive, or a division 1.3G explosive.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(16): "Flame effects" means the combustion of flammable solids, liquids, or gases to produce thermal, physical, visual, or audible phenomena before an audience.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17): 53-7-223
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17)(a): 53-7-223 "Flame effects operator" means a person licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17)(a)(i): storage, setup, operations, teardown, devices, equipment, overseeing assistants and support personnel, and preventing accidental discharge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17)(a)(ii): completion of the sequence of control system functions that release the fuel for ignition to cause combustion and create the flame effects.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17)(b)(i): "Flame effects operator" does not include a person who participates in a meeting, as limited under Subsection (16)(b)(ii), with other persons solely to receive training, to practice, or provide instruction regarding flame effects performance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(17)(b)(ii): A meeting under Subsection (16)(b)(i) may include a nonpaying and unsolicited audience of not more than 25 persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(18): "Importer" means a person who brings division 1.2G explosives, division 1.3G explosives, or division 1.4G explosives into the state for the general purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(18)(a): resale or use within the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(18)(b): exportation to other states.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(19): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(19)(a): "Pyrotechnic" means any composition or device manufactured or used to produce a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(19)(b): "Pyrotechnic" does not mean exempt explosives.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(20): 53-7-225 "Retail seller" means a person who sells division 1.4G common state approved explosives to the public during the period authorized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(21): "Service" means the inspection, maintenance, repair, modification, testing, or cleaning of an automatic fire suppression system.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(22): "Special effects" means a visual or audible effect caused by chemical mixtures that produce a controlled, self-sustaining, and self-controlled exothermic chemical reaction that results in heat, gas, sound, or light and may also create an illusion.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(23): 53-7-223 "Special effects operator" means a person licensed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24): "Trick noisemaker" includes a:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(a): tube or sphere containing pyrotechnic composition that produces a white or colored smoke as its primary effect when ignited; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b): device that produces a small report intended to surprise the user, including a:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(i): "booby trap," which is a small tube with a string protruding from both ends that ignites the friction sensitive composition in the tube when the string is pulled;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(ii): "snapper," which is a small paper-wrapped device containing a minute quantity of explosive composition coated on bits of sand that explodes producing a small report;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(iii): "trick match," which is a kitchen or book match coated with a small quantity of explosive or pyrotechnic composition that produces a small shower of sparks when ignited;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(iv): "cigarette load," which is a small wooden peg coated with a small quantity of explosive composition that produces a small report when ignited; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(v): "auto burglar alarm," which is a tube that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(v)(A): contains pyrotechnic composition that produces a loud whistle and smoke when ignited;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(v)(B): may contain a small quantity of explosive to produce a small explosive noise; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(24)(b)(v)(C): is ignited by a squib.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(25): "Unclassified fireworks" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(25)(a): a pyrotechnic device that is used, given away, or offered for sale, that has not been tested, approved, and classified by the United States Department of Transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(25)(b): an approved device that has been altered or redesigned since obtaining approval by the United States Department of Transportation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(25)(c): a pyrotechnic device that is being tested by a manufacturer, importer, or wholesaler before receiving approval by the United States Department of Transportation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(26): "Wholesaler" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(26)(a): a person who sells division 1.4G common state approved explosives to a retailer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-202(26)(b): a person who sells division 1.2G explosives, division 1.3G explosives, or division 1.4G explosives for display use.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-206 Equipment for new fire protection systems -- Standard equipment.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All equipment for fire protective purposes, purchased in connection with the installation of completely new fire protection systems by any authorities having charge of public property, shall be equipped with the standard hydrant stem and cap nuts and standard threads for fire hose and fire hydrant couplings and fittings designated as the national standard, as adopted by the board, which standard is designated as the standard for the equipment in the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-207 Selling or offering for sale nonstandard equipment unlawful -- Exception.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-207(1): A person may not sell or offer for sale any fire hose, fire hydrant, fire engine, or other equipment with threaded parts unless the equipment is fitted and equipped with the threads designated as national standard and adopted by the board and designated by law as the standard of  the equipment in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-207(2): (1); 11-4-2 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-207(2)(a): 11-4-2 equipment sold or offered for sale to a local governing body for the purposes of maintaining, repairing, replacing, or extending existing fire protection equipment as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-207(2)(b): adapters and caps for fire protective purposes.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-209(2): A fire chief or officer may enter a building or premises not used as a private dwelling at any reasonable hour to inspect the building or premises and enforce the rules made under this part and the state fire code.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-209(3): The owner, lessee, manager, or operator of a building or premises not used as a private dwelling shall permit inspections under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-210 Fire investigations by local officers -- Notification to division.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-210(1): The chief fire officer of any city, town, or county fire department, or of any fire district or special service district organized for fire protection purposes, or his authorized representative shall investigate the cause, origin, and circumstances of each fire occurring in his jurisdiction when property has been destroyed or damaged.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-210(2): The fire officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-210(2)(a): begin the investigation immediately after the occurrence of the fire; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-210(2)(b): attempt to determine, among other things, whether the fire was the result of carelessness or of design.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-210(3): If the fire officer making this investigation determines that the fire appears to be suspicious, or of unknown origin, the officer may notify the division to request assistance.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211 Fire investigations by fire marshal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211(1): If the division is of the opinion that further investigation of a fire is necessary, the state fire marshal, his deputy, or representative may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211(1)(a): join the investigation in cooperation with the fire officers who have been conducting it;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211(1)(b): upon the request of the chief fire official of the political subdivision, assume control of the investigation and direct it; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211(1)(c): conduct an independent investigation if necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211(2): A fire officer who has conducted or is conducting the investigation shall cooperate in every possible way with the state fire marshal, his deputy, and representative to further the purpose of the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-211(3): The county attorney or district attorney of the county in which the fire occurred shall, upon the request of the state fire marshal, his deputy, or representative, assist in the investigation.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-212 Powers of fire marshal in respect to investigation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In investigating any fire the state fire marshal and his deputy may:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-212(1): subpoena witnesses;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-212(2): compel their attendance and testimony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-212(3): require the production of books, papers, documents, records, and other tangible items that constitute or may contain evidence relevant to the investigation in the judgment of the state fire marshal or his deputy.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-213 Criminal charges resulting from investigation -- Procedure.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the state fire marshal, his deputy, or representative, or any other officer participating in the investigation of any fire  believes that there is evidence sufficient to charge a person with arson, burning with intent to defraud or prejudice the insurer, or a similar crime, he shall furnish the county attorney or district attorney of the county in which the crime occurred with his evidence and request the county attorney or district attorney to commence the proper procedures to charge the person with the appropriate crime.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214 Insurance company reports of fires.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(1): The state fire marshal, his deputy, and investigator may, in writing, require any insurance company transacting business in this state to release to the state fire marshal all relevant information or evidence found important by the state fire marshal, his deputy, and investigator that the company may have in its possession, relating to any fire loss in this state in which the company has an insuring interest.  Relevant information includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(1)(a): insurance policy information related to a fire loss under investigation and any application for the policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(1)(b): available policy premium payment records;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(1)(c): history of previous claims made by the insured; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(1)(d): material relating to the investigation of the loss, including statements of any person, proof of loss, and any other evidence related to the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(a): Every insurance company transacting business in the state must file with the division a report of any fire of suspicious origin.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b): The report shall show:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(i): the name of the insured;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(ii): the location of the property burned;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(iii): the probable cause of the fire;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(iv): the occupancy of the property burned;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(v): the construction of the building or structure burned;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(vi): the market value of the property involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(vii): the actual loss;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(viii): the insurance carried;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(ix): the insurance paid;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(x): the apportionment of loss where more than one company was on the risk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(b)(xi): if a motor vehicle or building is involved in any fire loss, a description of the motor vehicle or building.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(c): In case of a fire of suspicious or incendiary origin, a preliminary report shall be made immediately through some officer or representative of the insurance company, showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(c)(i): the name of the insured;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(c)(ii): the date of the fire;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(c)(iii): the location;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(c)(iv): occupancy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(2)(c)(v): other facts and circumstances tending to establish the cause or origin of the fire.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(3): All persons making an adjustment occasioned by a loss due to a fire of suspicious or incendiary origin in this state shall, upon written request, send to the division a copy of the final adjustment immediately after the adjustment is made, signed by the person making the adjustment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-214(4): (1); (2); (3) Any insurance company or person acting in its behalf or any person making adjustments occasioned by a loss due to fire who releases information, whether oral or written, pursuant to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-215 Portable fire extinguishers -- Persons not subject to part.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-215(1): The filling or charging of portable fire extinguishers prior to initial sale by the manufacturer is not subject to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-215(2): Any firm that maintains its own fully equipped and specially staffed fire prevention, fire protection, and fire extinguisher servicing facilities is not subject to the licensing provisions of this part if it services only its own portable fire extinguishers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-215(3): Individuals shall maintain a current certificate of registration.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216 Portable fire extinguishers and fire suppression systems -- Certification and licensure required to service.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(1): Each firm engaged in the business of servicing portable fire extinguishers or automatic fire suppression systems that automatically detect fire and discharge an approved fire extinguishing agent onto or in the area of the fire shall be licensed by the state fire marshal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(2): Each person who services portable fire extinguishers or fire suppression systems that discharge an approved fire extinguishing agent onto or in the area of the fire shall be certified by the state fire marshal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(3): The board shall by rule prescribe an application form and standards for licensure or certification qualification and for renewal and revocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(4): (5) Applicants for licensure or certification shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(4)(a): submit a written application on the form prescribed by the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(4)(b): provide evidence of competency as required by the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(4)(c): (5) submit the fee established under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(5): 63J-1-504 The board may establish a fee under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-216(6): This section does not apply to standpipe systems, deluge systems, or automatic fire sprinkler systems.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-217 Portable fire extinguishers -- Permit required to perform hydrostatic testing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each firm performing hydrostatic testing of portable fire extinguishers shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-217(1): perform the tests in accordance with the specifications of the United States Department of Transportation for compressed gas cylinders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-217(2): obtain a permit from the division by applying in writing on forms provided by the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-218 Portable fire extinguishers -- Sale or lease without approval prohibited.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A portable fire extinguisher may not be sold or leased in the state unless it is approved, labeled, or listed by a nationally recognized testing laboratory approved by the division as qualified to test portable fire extinguishers.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-219 Portable fire extinguishers -- Hearings authorized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The state fire marshal may conduct hearings or proceedings concerning the renewal, revocation, or refusal to issue permits.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-225.6(2)(c): (3) submit the fee established under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226 Violations -- Misdemeanor.
---------------------------------------------------------
A person is guilty of a class B misdemeanor if he:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(1): violates this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(2): violates any order made under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(3): produces, reproduces, or uses the official seal of registration of the division in any manner or for any purpose inconsistent with the designated purpose of the seal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(4): removes, uses, or damages service tags or other labels or markings in a manner inconsistent with the designated use of the service tag;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(5): engages in the sale, storage, or handling of division 1.4G common state approved explosives without a permit where a local government requires a permit;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(6): sells at retail, transports, possesses, or discharges division 1.4G dangerous explosives;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(7): performs or intends to perform services or induces the public to enter into any obligation relating to the performance of those services that are untrue, misleading, or reasonably known to be untrue or misleading; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-226(8): builds in violation of the division's plan review or written instructions conducted on building specifications, building plans, or amendments of those specifications or plans as required under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-301 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Liquefied Petroleum Gas Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(1): 53-7-304 "Board" means the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(2): "Container" means any vessel, including cylinders, tanks, portable tanks, and cargo tanks used for transporting or storing liquefied petroleum gases, except containers subject to regulation and inspection by the Department of Transportation and under federal laws or regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(3): "Distributor" means any person engaged in the distribution of liquefied petroleum gas, either wholesale or retail, including a commercial carrier, as identified by the Department of Transportation or the Interstate Commerce Commission, who transports or hauls liquefied petroleum gas that is to be distributed or sold within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(4): "Enforcing authority" means the division, the municipal or county fire department, another fire-prevention agency acting within its jurisdiction, or the building official of any city or county and his authorized representatives.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(5): "Final consumer" means an individual or business who is the ultimate user of LPG.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(6): "Gas appliance" means any device that uses liquefied petroleum gas to produce light, heat, power, steam, hot water, refrigeration, or air conditioning.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(7): "Installer" means any person who has satisfactorily passed an examination under the supervision of the board, testing his knowledge and ability to install or properly repair domestic systems, industrial systems, liquefied petroleum gas carburetion systems, bulk plant systems, standby plant systems, or other similar systems, and who holds an installer's certificate under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(8): "Licensee" means a person licensed by the board to engage in the liquefied petroleum gas business.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(9): "Liquefied petroleum gas" means any material having a vapor pressure not exceeding that allowed for commercial propane and composed predominantly of the following hydrocarbons, either by themselves or as mixtures: propane, propylene, butane, normal butane, or isobutane, and butylene, including isomers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(10): "Liquefied petroleum gas carburetion system" means any carburetion system using liquefied petroleum gas as a fuel in a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(11): "Liquefied petroleum gas fueling system" means an assembly consisting of compressors, containers, piping, and other delivery devices for the purpose of dispensing liquefied petroleum gas for use as a fuel in a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(12): "LPG" means liquefied petroleum gas.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(13): "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, corporation, estate, trust, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(13)(a): a husband, wife, or both where joint benefits are derived from the operation of a business or activity subject to this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(13)(b): any state, county, municipality, or other agency engaged in a business or activity subject to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(14): "Red tag" means a card or device, red in color, containing printed notice of the condemnation of a liquefied petroleum gas system as a result of a violation of this part, or any rules or orders made by the board; the tag, when attached to the system, is official notice of condemnation and of the prohibition of further use, so long as the red tag remains lawfully affixed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-302(15): "System" means an assembly consisting of one or more containers with a means for conveying LPG from the container or containers to dispensing or consuming devices, either continuously or intermittently, and that incorporates components intended to achieve control of quantity, flow, and pressure or state, either liquid or vapor.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303 Exclusions from part.
----------------------------------------------------
This part does not apply to any of the following:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303(1): the production, refining, or manufacture of LPG;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303(2): the storage, sale, or transportation of LPG by pipeline or railroad tank car by a pipeline company, producer, refiner, or manufacturer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303(3): equipment used by a pipeline company, producer, refiner, or manufacturer in a producing, refining, or manufacturing process or in the storage, sale, or transportation by pipeline or railroad tank car;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303(4): any deliveries of LPG to another person at the place of production, refining, or manufacturing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303(5): underground storage facilities other than LPG containers designed for underground use;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-303(6): refineries, pipeline terminals, or natural gas processing plants.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Board -- Creation -- Composition -- Appointment -- Terms of officers -- Meetings -- Compensation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(1)(a): There is created within the division the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(1)(b): The board is composed of seven members:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(1)(b)(i): two Utah fire chiefs or marshals;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(1)(b)(ii): two members of the general public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(1)(b)(iii): three members who are representatives of the LPG industry.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(2): The fire chiefs or marshals and the members of the general public shall be appointed by the governor, on a nonpartisan basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(3): Members of the board who are representatives of the LPG industry shall have been legal residents of the state for at least one year immediately preceding the date of appointment and have been actively engaged in the LPG industry for a period of at least five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(4): (7) The LPG industry representatives shall be appointed by the governor from a list of at least five but no more than the 12 nominees receiving the largest number of votes according to written ballots executed by representatives of the licensees under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(5)(b): (5)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(5)(c): Members serve from the date of appointment until a replacement is appointed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(6): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(7): 53-7-309; (7)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(7)(a): The balloting of licensees shall be conducted by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(7)(b): 53-7-309 For the appointments, the division shall forward to each licensee an official ballot for each staffed plant or facility held under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(7)(c): (7)(b) The division shall send the official ballot and instructions described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(7)(c)(i): registered or certified United States mail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(7)(c)(ii): email.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(8)(a): The board shall elect its own chair and vice chair at its first regular meeting each calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(8)(b): All meetings of the board shall be held on a prescribed date, at least quarterly, and at any time a majority of the board members sends a request to the board chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-304(8)(c): A majority of the members of the board is a quorum for the transaction of business.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305 Board rulemaking -- Notice.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(1)(a): The board shall make rules as reasonably necessary for the protection of the health, welfare, and safety of the public and persons using LPG.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(1)(b): The rules shall be in substantial conformity with the generally accepted standards of safety concerning LPG, and shall include the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(1)(b)(i): the rules relating to safety in the storage, distribution, dispensing, transporting, and use of LPG in this state and in the manufacture, fabrication, assembly, sale, installation, and use of LPG systems, containers, apparatus, or appliances shall be reasonable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(1)(b)(ii): the rules shall conform as nearly as possible to the standards of the National Fire Protection Association, relating to the design, construction, installation, and use of systems, containers, apparatus, appliances, and pertinent equipment for the storage, transportation, dispensation, and use of LPG.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(2): The board may make rules:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(2)(a): setting minimum general standards covering the design, construction, location, installation, and operation of equipment for storing, handling, transporting by tank truck or tank trailer, or using LPG;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(2)(b): specifying the odorization of the gases and the degree of odorization;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(2)(c): governing LPG distributors and installers and the installation of LPG systems, carburetion systems, and fueling systems; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(2)(d): prescribing maximum container removal rates.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(3)(a): When a proposed rule is filed, the board shall give at least 10 days' notice to all license applicants and licensees under this chapter by sending a notice of the proposed new, revised, or amended rule together with a notice of hearing to the licensee's current address on file with the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(3)(b): Any person affected by rulemaking under this part may submit comment, in a format prescribed by the board, on the rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(3)(c): A certificate citing the adoption and the effective date of a rule shall be signed by the members comprising a majority of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(3)(d): Within 10 days after the adoption of the rule, the board shall send to each license applicant or licensee, at his current address on file, a notice of the adoption of the rule, including its effective date.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-305(3)(e): A facsimile of any member's signature may be used under this section if authorized by the member.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306 Duties and powers of the board -- Fee setting.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(1): The board shall monitor rates charged in the industry for container removal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2): The board may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(a): set civil penalties for violation of any rule or order made under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(b): in conducting hearings on the issuance or revocation of any license:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(b)(i): compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(b)(ii): require the production of any records or documents determined by it to be pertinent to the subject matter of the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(b)(iii): apply to the district court of the county where the hearing is held for an order citing any applicant or witness for contempt, and for failure to attend, testify, or produce required documents;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(c): suspend or revoke licenses and refuse renewals of licenses if the applicant or licensee has been guilty of conduct harmful to either the safety or protection of the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(d): adopt bylaws for its procedures and methods of operation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(2)(e): at the request of the enforcing authority, grant exceptions from its rules to accommodate local needs as it determines to be in the best interest of public safety or the persons using LPG materials or services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-306(3): 53-7-314 The board shall, in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307 Duties of the division.
------------------------------------------------------
The division shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(1): prescribe the method and form to apply for, or renew, a LPG license or certificate, with the approval of the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(2): investigate the experience, reputation, and background of applicants and persons who hold a license or certificate and who are applying for renewal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(3): recommend to the board issuing, renewing, suspending, revoking, and denying licenses or certificates;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(4): assist the board in conducting hearings in connection with the applications for, renewal of, suspension of, or revocation of, licenses or certificates;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(5): submit to the governor a biennial report before September 1 of each even-numbered year, covering the board's transactions during the biennium ending June 30 of that year, including a complete statement of the receipts and expenditures of the board during that period;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(6): keep accurate records and minutes of all meetings, which shall be open to public inspection at all reasonable times, and keep a public record of all applications for licenses and licenses issued by the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(7): conduct examinations of every license applicant to determine the responsibility, ability, knowledge, experience, or other qualifications of the applicant for a license;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(8): require competency testing for all employees and subcontractors of licensees engaged in transporting or dispensing LPG or installing, servicing, or repairing an LPG fueling or carburetion system under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(9): prepare applications, collect fees, and issue licenses for any facility that handles LPG;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(10): provide for or direct the inspection of the site of any facility that stores, dispenses, services, or handles LPG;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(11): provide inspections to any facility where a qualified authority does not exist; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-307(12): prepare and administer examinations, collect fees, and issue LPG certificates to personnel who handle or work with LPG.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308 Licenses and certificates.
---------------------------------------------------------
A person may not engage in any of the following activities related to LPG unless the person has obtained an authorizing license or certification from the board:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(1): container activities, including the manufacture, assembly, repair, sale, installation, or subframing of containers for use in this state, except that a license is not required for the sale of new containers of 96 pounds water capacity or less;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(2): systems activities, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(2)(a): the installation, service, or repair of LPG systems for use in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(2)(b): laying or connecting of pipes and fittings connecting with or to systems or servicing a system and appliances to be used with LPG as a fuel;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(3): appliance activities, including the service, installation, or repair of appliances used or to be used in this state in connection with systems using LPG as a fuel; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(4): product activities, including the sale, transportation, dispensation, or storage of LPG in this state, except that a license or certification is not required for a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(4)(a): who sells LPG but does not obtain possessory rights to the product sold; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-308(4)(b): when the product is stored, transferred, or used by the final consumer.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311 Certification of licensees for certain activities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(1): A person that transports or dispenses LPG or that installs, repairs, or services appliances, containers, equipment, systems, or piping for the use of LPG shall be certified by the division by passing an appropriate examination based on the safety requirements of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(2)(a): A trainee employee is exempt from this examination for 45 working days, and until examined by a representative of the board.  A trainee employee, during the 45-day period, shall be supervised by a qualified instructor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(2)(b): Any LPG licensee hiring a trainee shall, within 20 days of the commencement of employment, notify the board, so that an examination may be scheduled.  If the trainee fails to pass the examination, the trainee may retake it after additional instruction.  Prior to retaking the exam, the trainee shall again be supervised by a qualified instructor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(3): 53-7-314
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(3)(a): 53-7-314 The board shall establish a reasonable fee in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-311(3)(b): All examinations shall be administered by the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312 Division approval of certain storage system plans -- Procedure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312(1)(a): The complete plans and specifications for all systems involving the storage of more than 5,000 water gallons of LPG shall be submitted to the division by a person licensed under this part, and receive approval by the division before installation is started.  The plans shall be drawn to scale and contain sufficient detail and clarity as necessary to indicate the nature and character of the proposed system and its compliance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312(1)(b): Two copies of the plans shall be submitted to the division and one copy shall be returned to the applicant with approval or disapproval indicated on it.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312(2)(a): For dispensing systems for 5,000 water gallons or less of LPG, a detailed sketch or plan shall be submitted to the division by a person licensed under this part, and receive approval by the division before installation is started.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-312(2)(b): Two copies of the plans shall be submitted to the division and one copy shall be returned to the applicant with approval or disapproval indicated on it.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-313 Removal of LPG containers -- Reasonableness of rates.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-313(1): Rates charged for removal of leased LPG containers shall be reasonable.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-313(2): The lessor of an LPG container shall credit the lessee's account the current retail price for the amount of LPG remaining in the leased container at the time the container is removed.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-314(2): Fees collected by the division under this part, shall be deposited with the state treasurer as a dedicated credit, to be used for the implementation of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315 Enforcement of part and rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(1): (6) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(1)(a): the enforcing authority, unless otherwise provided by the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(1)(b): the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(2)(a): A person who knowingly violates or fails to comply with this part is guilty of a class B misdemeanor and is punishable by a fine of not less than $50 nor more than $500.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(2)(b): (2)(a) A person previously convicted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(2)(c): Each day the violation or failure to comply continues constitutes a separate offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(3): The enforcing authority may enter the premises of a licensee under this part, or any building or other premises open to the public, at any reasonable time, for the purpose of determining and verifying compliance with this part and the rules and orders of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(4): An enforcing authority may declare any container, appliance, equipment, transport, or system that does not conform to the safety requirements of this part or the rules or orders of the board, or that is otherwise defective, as unsafe or dangerous for LPG service, and shall attach a red tag in a conspicuous location.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(5)(a): A person who knowingly sells, furnishes, delivers, or supplies LPG for storage in, or use or consumption by, or through, a container, appliance, transport, or system to which a red tag is attached is guilty of a class B misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $100 and not more than $2,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(5)(b): Liquefied petroleum gas shall be removed from a container to which a red tag is attached only as provided by rules made by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(5)(c): An unauthorized person who knowingly removes, destroys, or in any way obliterates a red tag attached to a container, appliance, transport, or system is guilty of a class B misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $50 and not more than $2,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(5)(d): The enforcing authority may establish and collect a fee for any services or inspections required by this part, the rules made under it, and orders issued by the board.  The fee shall be reasonable and may not exceed the amount of the cost of service or inspection provided. Fees collected under this subsection may be retained by the enforcing authority, and shall be applied to the expenses of providing these services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6): (6)(c); (6)(a); (6)(b); (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(a): (6)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(a)(i): the actual damages to the container lessor, including incidental and consequential damages and attorneys' fees; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(a)(ii): $500 for each violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b): (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b)(i): (6)(a) The burden of ascertaining the terms of a written lease for purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b)(ii): A person has ascertained the terms of a written lease if he has:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b)(ii)(A): read the lease;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b)(ii)(B): received the assurance of the container owner that the lease does not prohibit the person from filling the container;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b)(ii)(C): obtained a signed, written statement from the lessee that the written lease does not prohibit the person from filling the container; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(6)(b)(ii)(D): the leased container is clearly labelled as a container subject to lease terms prohibiting the filling of the container without the lessor's permission.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(7): If a written container lease entered into after May 1, 1992, restricts the right to fill a leased container, the restriction shall be plainly stated in the lease in any manner designed to draw the attention of the lessee to the lease provision, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(7)(a): typing the restriction in at least two point larger type than the majority of the document type;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-315(7)(b): underlining the restriction; or
