Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-316 Effect of part on state and local provision.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-316(1): This part supersedes all other conflicting state laws or rules concerning LPG as regulated under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-316(2): A municipality or other political subdivision may not adopt or enforce any ordinance or rule in conflict with this part, or with the rules made under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-401 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "The Reduced Cigarette Ignition Propensity and Firefighter Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(1): "Agent" means any person authorized by the State Tax Commission to purchase and affix stamps on packages of cigarettes.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(2): "Cigarette" means any roll for smoking made wholly or in part of tobacco, irrespective of size or shape, and whether or not such tobacco is flavored, adulterated, or mixed with any other ingredient, the wrapper or cover of which is made of paper or any other substance or material except tobacco.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3): (3)(a); (3)(b) "Manufacturer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3)(a): any entity which:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3)(a)(i): manufactures or otherwise produces cigarettes to be sold in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3)(a)(ii): causes cigarettes to be manufactured or produced anywhere with the intent to sell in the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3)(a)(iii): manufactures or otherwise produces cigarettes or causes cigarettes to be manufactured or produced with the intent to sell in the United States through an importer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3)(b): the first purchaser anywhere that intends to resell in the United States cigarettes manufactured anywhere that the original manufacturer or maker does not intend to be sold in the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(3)(c): (3)(a); (3)(b) any entity that becomes a successor of an entity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(4): 53-7-403(2)(f) "Quality control and quality assurance program" means the laboratory procedures implemented to ensure that operator bias, systematic, and nonsystematic methodological errors, and equipment related problems do not affect the results of the testing.  Such a program ensures that the testing repeatability remains within the required repeatability values stated in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(5): "Repeatability" means the range of values within which the repeat results of cigarette test trials from a single laboratory will fall 95% of the time.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(6): "Retail dealer" means any person, other than a manufacturer or wholesale dealer, engaged in selling cigarettes or tobacco products.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(7): "Sale":
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(7)(a): means any transfer of title or possession or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatever or any agreement therefore; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(7)(b): includes, in addition to cash and credit sales, the giving of cigarettes as samples, prizes, or gifts, and the exchanging of cigarettes for any consideration other than money.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(8): "Sell" means to sell, or to offer or agree to sell.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(9): "Wholesale dealer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(9)(a): any person who sells cigarettes or tobacco products to retail dealers or other persons for purposes of resale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-402(9)(b): any person who owns, operates, or maintains one or more cigarette or tobacco product vending machines in, at, or upon premises owned or occupied by any other person.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403 Test method and performance standard.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(1): (8); 53-7-404; 53-7-405 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(1)(a): the cigarettes have been tested in accordance with the test method required by this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(1)(b): the cigarettes meet the performance standard specified in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(1)(c): 53-7-404 a written certification has been filed by the manufacturer with the state fire marshal in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(1)(d): 53-7-405 the cigarettes have been marked in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(a): Testing of cigarettes shall be conducted in accordance with the American Society of Testing and Materials ("ASTM") standard E2187-04, "Standard Test Method for Measuring the Ignition Strength of Cigarettes."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(b): Testing shall be conducted on 10 layers of filter paper.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(c): No more than 25% of the cigarettes tested in a test trial in accordance with this section shall exhibit full-length burns.  Forty replicate tests shall comprise a complete test trial for each cigarette tested.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(d): The performance standard required by this section shall only be applied to a complete test trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(e): Written certifications shall be based upon testing conducted by a laboratory that has been accredited pursuant to standard ISO/IEC 17025 of the International Organization for Standardization ("ISO"), or other comparable accreditation standard required by the state fire marshal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(f): Laboratories conducting testing in accordance with this section shall implement a quality control and quality assurance program that includes a procedure that will determine the repeatability of the testing results.  The repeatability value shall be no greater than 0.19.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(g): This section does not require additional testing if cigarettes are tested consistent with this part for any other purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(2)(h): Testing performed or sponsored by the state fire marshal to determine a cigarette's compliance with the performance standard required shall be conducted in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(3): 53-7-404 Each cigarette listed in a certification submitted pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(4): (2)(a); (2)(c); 53-7-404 A manufacturer of a cigarette that the state fire marshal determines cannot be tested in accordance with the test method prescribed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(5): Each manufacturer shall maintain copies of the reports of all tests conducted on all cigarettes offered for sale for a period of three years, and shall make copies of these reports available to the state fire marshal and the attorney general upon written request.  Any manufacturer who fails to make copies of these reports available within 60 days of receiving a written request shall be subject to a civil penalty not to exceed $10,000 for each day after the sixtieth day that the manufacturer does not make the copies available.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(6): (2)(c) The state fire marshal may adopt a subsequent ASTM Standard Test Method for Measuring the Ignition Strength of Cigarettes upon a finding that the subsequent method does not result in a change in the percentage of full-length burns exhibited by any tested cigarette when compared to the percentage of full-length burns the same cigarette would exhibit when tested in accordance with ASTM Standard E2187-04 and the performance standard in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(7): The state fire marshal shall review the effectiveness of this section and report every three years to the Legislature the state fire marshal's findings and, if appropriate, recommendations for legislation to improve the effectiveness of this section.  The report and legislative recommendations shall be submitted no later than November 1, 2011 and every November 1 of each three-year period thereafter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(8): (1) The requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-403(9): This part shall be implemented in accordance with the implementation and substance of the New York Fire Safety Standards for Cigarettes.

The state fire marshal is authorized to annually adjust this fee to ensure it defrays the actual costs of the processing, testing, enforcement, and oversight activities required by this part.

Proposed markings shall be considered approved if the state fire marshal fails to act within 10 business days of receiving a request for approval.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406 Penalties.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(1): 53-7-403
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(1)(a): 53-7-403 Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b), a manufacturer, wholesale dealer, agent, or any other person or entity who knowingly sells or offers to sell cigarettes, other than through retail sale, in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(1)(a)(i): for a first offense shall be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $10,000 per each sale of cigarettes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(1)(a)(ii): for a subsequent offense shall be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $25,000 per each sale of such cigarettes.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(1)(b): A penalty imposed under Subsection (1)(a) may not exceed $100,000 during any 30-day period against any one entity described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2): 53-7-403
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a): 53-7-403 Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), a retail dealer who knowingly sells cigarettes in violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a)(i): for a first offense for each sale or offer for sale of cigarettes, if the total number of cigarettes sold or offered for sale:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a)(i)(A): does not exceed 1,000 cigarettes, be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $500 for each sale or offer of sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a)(i)(B): does exceed 1,000 cigarettes, be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $1,000 for each sale or offer of sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a)(ii): for a subsequent offense, if the total number of cigarettes sold or offered for sale:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a)(ii)(A): does not exceed 1,000 cigarettes, be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $2,000 for each sale or offer of sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(a)(ii)(B): does exceed 1,000 cigarettes, be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $5,000 for each sale or offer of sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(2)(b): A penalty imposed under Subsection (2)(a) against any retail dealer shall not exceed $25,000 during a 30-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(3): 53-7-404 In addition to any penalty prescribed by law, any corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, limited partnership, or association engaged in the manufacture of cigarettes that knowingly makes a false certification pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(3)(a): for a first offense, be liable for a civil penalty of at least $75,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(3)(b): for a subsequent offense, be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $250,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(4): Any person violating any other provision in this part shall be liable for a civil penalty for each violation:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(4)(a): for a first offense, not to exceed $1,000; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(4)(b): for a subsequent offense, not to exceed $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(5)(a): In addition to any other remedy provided by law, the state fire marshal or attorney general may bring an action in a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, for a violation of this part, including petitioning for injunctive relief or to recover any costs or damages suffered by the state because of a violation of this part, including enforcement costs relating to the specific violation and attorney fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-406(5)(b): Each violation of this part or of rules or regulations adopted under this part constitutes a separate civil violation for which the state fire marshal or attorney general may obtain relief.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-408 Inspection.
------------------------------------------
To enforce the provisions of this part, the attorney general and the state fire marshal are hereby authorized to examine the books, papers, invoices, and other records of any person in possession, control, or occupancy of any premises where cigarettes are placed, stored, sold, or offered for sale, as well as the stock of cigarettes on the premises.  Every person in the possession, control, or occupancy of any premises where cigarettes are placed, sold, or offered for sale, is hereby directed and required to give the attorney general and the state fire marshal the means, facilities, and opportunity for the examinations authorized by this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-409 Sale outside of Utah.
----------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part shall be construed to prohibit any person or entity from manufacturing or selling cigarettes that do not meet the requirements of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-410 Preemption.
------------------------------------------
This part shall be repealed if a federal reduced cigarette ignition propensity standard that preempts this part is adopted and becomes effective.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-411 Local regulation.
------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a political subdivision of this state may neither enact nor enforce any ordinance or other local law or regulation conflicting with, or preempted by, any provision of this part or with any policy of this state expressed by this part, whether that policy be expressed by inclusion of a provision in this part or by exclusion of that subject from this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-501 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as "Regulation of Novelty Lighters."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(1): "Audio effect" includes music, animal sounds, whistles, buzzers, or other noises not pertinent to the flame-producing function of the lighter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(2)(a): "Distribute" means to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(2)(a)(i): deliver to a person other than the purchaser; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(2)(a)(ii): provide as part of a commercial promotion or as a prize or premium.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(2)(b): "Distribute" does not include providing as a personal gift.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(3): "Importer" means a person who causes a lighter to enter this state from a manufacturing, wholesale, distribution, or retail sales point outside this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(3)(a): for the purpose of selling or distributing the lighter within this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(3)(b): with the result that the lighter is sold or distributed within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(4): "Lighter" means a handheld mechanical device of a type typically used for igniting tobacco products by use of a flame.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(5): "Misleading design" means a lighter that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(5)(a): has a shape that resembles or imitates an object other than a lighter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(5)(b): may have one or more audio or visual effects; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(5)(c): has other features of a type that would reasonably be expected to make the lighter appealing or attractive to a child younger than 10 years of age.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6): "Novelty lighter":
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(a): means a lighter that has:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(a)(i): a misleading design; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(a)(ii): operates on any fuel, including butane or liquid fuel;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(b): does not mean:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(b)(i): a lighter manufactured before January 1, 1980;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(b)(ii): a lighter that has been rendered permanently incapable of producing a flame or otherwise causing combustion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(6)(b)(iii): a mechanical device primarily used to ignite fuel for fireplaces, or for charcoal or gas grills.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(7): "Sell" means to provide or promise to provide a product to a wholesale, retail, mail-order, or other purchaser in exchange for consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(8): "Visual effect":
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(8)(a): includes flashing lights, color-changing lights, or changing images; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-502(8)(b): does not include logos, decals, decorative artwork, or heat-shrinkable sleeves.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-503(2)(b): The state fire marshal shall make the list available on the website maintained by the Department of Public Safety.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-504(1):

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-504(1)(b): A person may not import a novelty lighter into this state for the purpose of selling or distributing the novelty lighter within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-504(1)(c): A person may not possess a novelty lighter in inventory for the purpose of selling or distributing the novelty lighter within this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-7-504(2)(b): (1) The civil penalty for a violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 8 - Utah Highway Patrol Act
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah Highway Patrol Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-102(1): 53-8-103 "Division" means the Utah Highway Patrol Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-102(2): 53-8-104 "Highway Patrol" means the Highway Patrol troopers employed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-102(3): 53-8-103 "Superintendent" means the director of the division, appointed under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-103 Utah Highway Patrol Division -- Creation -- Appointment of superintendent -- Powers -- Qualifications -- Term -- Compensation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-103(1): There is created the Utah Highway Patrol Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-103(2): The director of the division shall be the superintendent appointed by the commissioner with the approval of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-103(3): The superintendent is the executive and administrative head of the division and shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-103(4): The superintendent acts under the supervision and control of the commissioner and may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-103(5): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act The superintendent shall receive compensation as provided by


Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104 Superintendent's duties.
-------------------------------------------------------
The superintendent shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(1): divide the state highways into sections for the purpose of patrolling and policing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(2): employ peace officers known as highway patrol troopers to patrol or police the highways within this state and to enforce the state statutes as required;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(3): establish ranks, grades, and positions in the Highway Patrol and designate the authority and responsibility in each rank, grade, and position;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(4): establish for the Highway Patrol standards and qualifications and fix prerequisites of training, education, and experience for each rank, grade, and position;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(5): appoint personnel to each rank, grade, and position necessary for the efficient operation and administration of the Highway Patrol;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(6): devise and administer examinations designed to test applicants for positions with the Highway Patrol;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(7): make rules governing the Highway Patrol as appear to the superintendent advisable;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(8): discharge, demote, or temporarily suspend any employee in the Highway Patrol for cause;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(9): prescribe the uniforms to be worn and the equipment to be used by employees of the Highway Patrol;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(10): charge against each employee of the  Highway Patrol the value of any property of the state lost or destroyed through the carelessness of the employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(11): establish, with the approval of the Division of Finance, the terms and conditions under which expense allowance should be paid to any employee of the Highway Patrol while away from his station;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(12): station the Highway Patrol in localities as he finds advisable for the enforcement of the laws of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(13): conduct in conjunction with the State Board of Education in and through all state schools  an educational campaign in highway safety and work in conjunction with civic organizations, churches, local units of government, and other organizations that may function in accomplishing the purposes of reducing highway accidents;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(14): provide the initial mandatory uniform items for each new trooper hired after July 1, 1998;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(15): determine by rule a basic uniform allowance system which includes the manner in which troopers may receive maintenance services and vouchers for basic uniforms and administer any funds appropriated by the Legislature to the division for that purpose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-104(16): on or before January 1, 2003, adopt a written policy that prohibits the stopping, detention, or search of any person when the action is solely motivated by considerations of race, color, ethnicity, age, or gender.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105 Duties of Highway Patrol.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1): 41-6a-1630 In addition to the duties in this chapter, the Highway Patrol shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(a): enforce the state laws and rules governing use of the state highways;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(b): regulate traffic on all highways and roads of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(c): assist the governor in an emergency or at other times at his discretion;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(d): in cooperation with federal, state, and local agencies, enforce and assist in the enforcement of all state and federal laws related to the operation of a motor carrier on a highway, including all state and federal rules and regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(e): 41-6a-1630 inspect certain vehicles to determine road worthiness and safe condition as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(f): upon request, assist with any condition of unrest existing or developing on a campus or related facility of an institution of higher education;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(g): assist the Alcoholic Beverage Services Commission in an emergency to enforce the state liquor laws;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(h): provide security and protection for both houses of the Legislature while in session as the speaker of the House of Representatives and the president of the Senate find necessary;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(i): enforce the state laws and rules governing use of capitol hill; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(j): carry out the following for the Supreme Court and the Court of Appeals:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(j)(i): provide security and protection to those courts when in session in the capital city of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(j)(ii): execute orders issued by the courts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(1)(j)(iii): carry out duties as directed by the courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2): 72-1-201
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2)(a): The division and the department shall annually:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2)(a)(i): evaluate the inventory of new and existing state highways, in coordination with relevant local law enforcement agencies, to determine which law enforcement agency is best suited to patrol and enforce state laws and regulate traffic on each state highway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2)(a)(ii): before October 1 of each year, report to the Transportation Interim Committee and the Executive Offices and Criminal Justice Appropriations Subcommittee regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2)(a)(ii)(A): significant changes to the patrol and enforcement responsibilities resulting from the evaluation described in Subsection (2)(a)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2)(a)(ii)(B): any budget request necessary to accommodate additional patrol and enforcement responsibilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-105(2)(b): 72-1-201 The division and the department shall, before July 1 of each year, coordinate with the Department of Transportation created in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-106 Vested with powers of peace officers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-106(1): The commissioner, superintendent, and each member of the Highway Patrol have the powers of peace officers in each county of the state with the exception of the power to serve civil process.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-106(2): They may serve criminal process, arrest and prosecute violators of any law of this state, and have the same right as other peace officers to require aid in executing their duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-106(3): The powers and duties conferred upon the superintendent and members of the Highway Patrol are supplementary to and not a limitation on the powers and duties of other peace officers in the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-107 Cooperation with other officers.
---------------------------------------------------------------
To secure information in order to achieve greater success in prevention and detection of crime and apprehension of criminals, the Highway Patrol shall cooperate and exchange information with:Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-107(1): any other departments of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-107(2): other law enforcement agencies, both within and outside this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-107(3): federal law enforcement agencies.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-206(2)(a): A safety inspection station permit may not be assigned, or transferred, or used at any location other than a designated location.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-208 Counterfeit certificates of inspection.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-208(1): A person may not make, issue, or knowingly use any imitation or counterfeit of a safety inspection certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-208(2): A person may not present or cause or permit to be presented any safety inspection certificate knowing the certificate to be fictitious, issued for another motor vehicle, or issued without a safety inspection having been made and passed.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(1): A peace officer may stop, inspect, and test a vehicle at any time upon reasonable cause to believe that:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(1)(b): the vehicle's equipment is not in proper adjustment or repair; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(1)(c): the vehicle has been in an accident and a post accident investigation is necessary.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(a)(ii)(A): require that the vehicle be placed in safe condition and the vehicle's equipment in proper repair and adjustment;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(a)(ii)(B): specify the repairs and adjustments needed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(a)(ii)(C): require that a safety inspection certificate be obtained within 14 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(b): If a vehicle is, in the reasonable judgment of the peace officer, hazardous to operate, the peace officer may require that the vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(b)(i): not be operated under its own power; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(b)(ii): be driven to the nearest garage or other place of safety.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-209(2)(c)(i): If the owner or driver does not comply with the notice requirements and secure a safety inspection certificate within 14 days, the vehicle may not be operated on the highways of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210 Enforcement of inspection requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(1): A person operating a vehicle shall submit the vehicle to a safety inspection when required to do so by a peace officer.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(2)(a): 53-8-209 An owner or driver, upon receiving a notice as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(2)(a)(i): secure a safety inspection certificate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(2)(a)(ii): present the certificate and the repaired vehicle to the Utah Highway Patrol for verification.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(2)(b): (3) In lieu of compliance with this subsection, the vehicle may not be operated, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(3): Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(3)(a): A person may not operate any vehicle after receiving a notice  from a peace officer that the vehicle is in need of repair or adjustment, except that a peace officer may allow the vehicle to be driven to the residence or place of business of the owner or driver or to the nearest garage where repairs are available if driving the vehicle is not excessively dangerous.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(3)(b): Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code The vehicle may not be operated again on the highways until its equipment has been placed in proper repair and adjustment and otherwise conforms to the requirements of this part and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-210(4): If repair or adjustment of any vehicle or its equipment is necessary, the owner of the vehicle may obtain repair or adjustment at any place he may choose.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-301 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Aero Bureau Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-302 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this section, "Aero Bureau" means the bureau within the division that provides aerial assistance for law enforcement activities within the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303 Utah Highway Patrol Aero Bureau Restricted Account.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(1): As used in this section, "account" means the Utah Highway Patrol Aero Bureau Restricted Account created by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(2): There is created a restricted account in the General Fund known as the "Utah Highway Patrol Aero Bureau Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3): 41-22-19 The account shall consist of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(a): 41-22-19 money deposited into the account in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(b): money appropriated to the account by the Legislature; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(c): any other public or private money received by the division that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(c)(i): given to the division for purposes consistent with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(c)(ii): deposited into the account at the request of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(c)(ii)(A): the division; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(3)(c)(ii)(B): the person giving the money.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(4): Money in the account may only be expended for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(4)(a): the purchase of aircraft and helicopters for use by the Aero Bureau in search and rescue operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(4)(b): replacement, maintenance, and upgrade of search and rescue equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(4)(c): search and rescue training and certification for division officers and employees;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(4)(d): personnel and fuel costs of the Aero Bureau associated with providing search and rescue services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-8-303(4)(e): any other equipment or expenses necessary or appropriate for conducting search and rescue activities.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 9 - Private Investigator Regulation Act
********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Private Investigator Regulation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
In this chapter, unless otherwise stated:Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(1): "Adequate records" means records containing, at a minimum, sufficient information to identify the client, the dates of service, the fee for service, the payments for service, the type of service given, and copies of any reports that may have been made.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(2): "Advertising" means the submission of bids, contracting or making known by any public notice, publication, or solicitation of business, directly or indirectly, that services regulated under this chapter are available for consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(3): "Agency" means a person who holds an agency license pursuant to this chapter, and includes one who employs an individual for wages and salary, and withholds all legally required deductions and contributions, or contracts with a registrant or an apprentice on a part-time or case-by-case basis to conduct an investigation on behalf of the agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(4): "Applicant" means any person who has submitted a completed application and all required fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(5): "Apprentice" means a person who holds an apprentice license pursuant to this chapter, has not met the requirements for registration, and works under the direct supervision and guidance of an agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(6): 53-9-104 "Board" means the Private Investigator Hearing and Licensure Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(7): 53-10-201 "Bureau" means the Bureau of Criminal Identification created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(8): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(9): "Conviction" means an adjudication of guilt by a federal, state, or local court resulting from trial or plea, including a plea of no contest, regardless of whether the imposition of sentence was suspended.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(10): "Department" means the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(11): "Direct supervision" means that the agency or employer:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(11)(a): is responsible for, and authorizes, the type and extent of work assigned;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(11)(b): reviews and approves all work produced by the apprentice before it goes to the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(11)(c): closely supervises and provides direction and guidance to the apprentice in the performance of his assigned work; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(11)(d): is immediately available to the apprentice for verbal contact, including by electronic means.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(12): "Emergency action" means a summary suspension of a license pending revocation, suspension, or probation in order to protect the public health, safety, or welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(13): "Employee" means an individual who works for an agency or other employer, is listed on the agency's or employer's payroll records, and is under the agency's or employer's direction and control.  An employee is not an independent contractor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(14): "Identification card" means a card issued by the commissioner to a qualified applicant for an agency, registrant, or apprentice license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(15): "Letter of concern" means an advisory letter to notify a licensee that while there is insufficient evidence to support probation, suspension, or revocation of a license, the department informs the licensee of the need to modify or eliminate certain practices and that continuation of the activities that led to the information being submitted to the department may result in further disciplinary action against the licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(16): "Licensee" means a person to whom an agency, registrant, or apprentice license is issued by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17): 58-26a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a): "Private investigator or private detective" means any person, except collection agencies and credit reporting agencies, who, for consideration, engages in business or accepts employment to conduct any investigation for the purpose of obtaining information with reference to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(i): crime, wrongful acts, or threats against the United States or any state or territory of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(ii): the identity, reputation, character, habits, conduct, business occupation, honesty, integrity, credibility, knowledge, trustworthiness, efficiency, loyalty, activity, movements, whereabouts, affiliations, associations, or transactions of any person or group of persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(iii): the credibility of witnesses or other persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(iv): the whereabouts of missing persons or owners of abandoned property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(v): the causes and origin of, or responsibility for a fire, libel, slander, a loss, an accident, damage, or an injury to real or personal property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(vi): the business of securing evidence to be used before investigating committees or boards of award or arbitration or in the trial of civil or criminal cases and the trial preparation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(vii): the prevention, detection, and removal of installed devices for eavesdropping or observation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(viii): the business of "skip tracing" persons who have become delinquent in their lawful debts, either when hired by an individual, collection agency, or through the direct purchase of the debt from a financial institution or entity owning the debt or judgment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(a)(ix): serving civil process.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(b): 58-26a-102 "Private investigator or private detective" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(b)(i): any person or employee conducting an investigation on the person's or employee's own behalf or on behalf of the employer if the employer is not a private investigator under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(b)(ii): an employee of an attorney licensed to practice law in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(17)(b)(iii): 58-26a-102 a currently licensed certified public accountant or CPA as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(18): "Qualifying party" means the individual meeting the qualifications under this chapter for a private investigator license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(19): "Registrant" means any person who holds a registrant license pursuant to this chapter.  The registrant performs private investigative work either as an employee on an employer's payroll or, on a contract with an agency, part-time, or case-by-case basis, with a minimum amount of direction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(20): "Restructuring" means any change in the legal status of a business.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21): "Unprofessional conduct" means any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21)(a): engaging or offering to engage by fraud or misrepresentation in any activities regulated by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21)(b): aiding or abetting a person who is not licensed pursuant to this chapter in representing that person as a private investigator or registrant in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21)(c): gross negligence in the practice of a private investigator or registrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21)(d): failing or refusing to maintain adequate records and investigative findings on a subject of investigation or a client;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21)(e): committing a felony or a misdemeanor involving any crime that is grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of an agency, registrant, or apprentice license.  In all cases, conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction or a plea of no contest is conclusive evidence of the commission of the crime; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-102(21)(f): making a fraudulent or untrue statement to the bureau, board, department, or its investigators, staff, or consultants.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103 Commissioner of Public Safety to administer -- Bureau to issue licenses -- Records -- Bonds -- Rulemaking.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(1): The commissioner shall administer this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(2)(a): The bureau, acting at the direction of the commissioner, shall issue a private investigator license to an applicant whom the board finds meets the qualifications for licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(2)(b): The bureau shall issue a license to an apprentice applicant who meets the qualifications for licensure under this chapter within five business days of receipt of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(2)(c): The bureau shall notify each licensee under this chapter when a licensee's license is due for renewal in accordance with procedures established by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(3)(a): The bureau shall keep records of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(3)(a)(i): all applications for licenses under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(3)(a)(ii): all bonds and proof of certificates of liability and workers' compensation insurance required to be filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(3)(b): The records shall include statements as to whether a license or renewal license has been issued for each application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(4): If a license is revoked, suspended, canceled, or denied or if a licensee is placed on probation, the date of filing the order for revocation, suspension, cancellation, denial, or probation shall be included in the records.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(5): The bureau shall maintain:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(5)(a): a list of all licensees whose license has been revoked, suspended, placed on probation, or canceled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-103(5)(b): a written record of complaints filed against licensees.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104 Board -- Creation-- Qualifications -- Appointments -- Terms -- Immunity.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(1): There is established a Private Investigator Hearing and Licensure Board consisting of five members appointed by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(2): Each member of the board shall be a citizen of the United States and a resident of this state at the time of appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(2)(a): Two members shall be qualifying parties who are licensed as provided in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(2)(b): One member shall be a supervisory investigator from the commissioner's office.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(2)(c): One member shall be a chief of police or sheriff.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(2)(d): One member shall be a public member who shall not have a financial interest in a private investigative agency and shall not have an immediate family member or a household member or friend who is licensed or registered under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(3)(a): Each member of the board shall serve four-year staggered terms beginning and ending on January 1.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(3)(b): (3)(a) Notwithstanding the term requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(4): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(5): At its first meeting every year, the board shall elect a chair, vice chair, and secretary from its membership.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(6)(a): 63A-3-106 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(6)(b): 63A-3-107 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(6)(c): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 rules made by the Division of Finance pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(7): A member shall not serve more than one term, except that a member appointed to fill a vacancy or appointed for an initial term of less than four years may be reappointed for one full term.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(8): The commissioner, after a board hearing and recommendation, may remove any member of the board for misconduct, incompetency, or neglect of duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-104(9): Members of the board are immune from suit with respect to all acts done and actions taken in good faith in furtherance of the purposes of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-105 Powers and duties of the board.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-105(1): The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-105(1)(a): review applications for licenses and renewals of licenses for private investigators and approve or deny the applications;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-105(1)(b): upon receiving a timely filed petition, review within a reasonable time the denial, suspension, or revocation of a private investigator license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-105(1)(c): review all complaints and make recommendations to the commissioner regarding disciplinary action.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-105(2): The board may take and hear evidence, administer oaths and affirmations, and compel by subpoena the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers, records, documents, and other information relating to a formal complaint against or bureau investigation of a private investigator.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-106 Meetings -- Hearings.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-106(1): The board shall meet quarterly, unless the board has no business to conduct during that quarter, and shall also meet at the call of the chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-106(2): A quorum consists of three members.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-106(3): If a member has three unexcused absences within a 12-month period, the board may hold a hearing to determine if that board member should be released from board duties.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-107(4)(b): A registrant or apprentice whose license has been suspended or revoked shall immediately notify the agency which supervises the registrant or apprentice of the action.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108 Qualifications for licensure.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1): 63G-2-801
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(a): An applicant under this chapter shall be at least:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(a)(i): 21 years old to apply for an agency license or a registrant license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(a)(ii): 18 years old to apply for an apprentice license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b): 63G-2-801 An applicant may not have been:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(i): convicted of a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(ii): convicted of an act involving illegally using, carrying, or possessing a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(iii): convicted of an act of personal violence or force on any person or convicted of threatening to commit an act of personal violence or force against another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(iv): convicted of an act constituting dishonesty or fraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(v): convicted of an act involving moral turpitude within the past 10 years unless the conviction has been expunged under the provisions of Title 77, Chapter 40a, Expungement of Criminal Records;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(vi): placed on probation or parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(vii): named in an outstanding arrest warrant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(b)(viii): 63G-2-801 convicted of illegally obtaining or disclosing private, controlled, or protected records as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(1)(c): If previously or currently licensed in another state or jurisdiction, the applicant shall be in good standing within that state or jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(2): In assessing if an applicant meets the requirements under Subsection (1)(b), the board shall consider mitigating circumstances presented by an applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(a): An applicant for an agency license shall have:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(a)(i): a minimum of 5,000 hours of investigative experience that consists of actual work performed as a licensed private investigator, an investigator in the private sector, an investigator for the federal government, or an investigator for a state, county, or municipal government; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(a)(ii): if the applicant held a registrant license or an apprentice license under this chapter on or before May 1, 2010, a minimum of 2,000 hours of investigative experience that consists of actual work performed as a licensed private investigator, an investigator in the private sector, an investigator for the federal government, or an investigator for a state, county, or municipal government.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(b): An applicant for a registrant license shall have a minimum of 2,000 hours of investigative experience that consists of actual investigative work performed as a licensed private investigator, an investigator in the private sector, an investigator for the federal government, an investigator for a state, county, or municipal government, or a process server.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(c): At least 1,000 hours of the investigative experience required under this Subsection (3) shall have been performed within 10 years immediately prior to the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(d): An applicant shall substantiate investigative work experience required under this Subsection (3) by providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(d)(i): the exact details as to the character and nature of the investigative work on a form prescribed by the bureau and certified by the applicant's employers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(d)(ii): if the applicant is applying for the reinstatement of an agency license, internal records of the applicant that demonstrate the investigative work experience requirement has previously been met.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(e)(i): The applicant shall prove completion of the investigative experience required under this Subsection (3) to the satisfaction of the board and the board may independently verify the certification offered on behalf of the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(3)(e)(ii): The board may independently confirm the claimed investigative experience and the verification of the applicant's employers.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(4): An applicant for an apprentice license, lacking the investigative experience required for a registrant license, shall meet all of the qualification standards in Subsection (1), and shall complete an apprentice application.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(5): An applicant for an agency or registrant license may receive credit toward the hours of investigative experience required under Subsection (3) as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(5)(a): an applicant may receive credit for 2,000 hours of investigative experience if the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(5)(a)(i): has an associate's degree in criminal justice or police science from an accredited college or university; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(5)(a)(ii): is certified as a peace officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(5)(b): an applicant may receive credit for 4,000 hours of investigative experience if the applicant has a bachelor's degree in criminal justice or police science from an accredited college or university.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-108(6): The board shall determine if the applicant may receive credit under Subsection (5) toward the investigative and educational experience requirements under Subsection (3).


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-109 Application for agency license -- Liability insurance -- Workers' compensation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111 License and registration fees -- Deposit in General Fund.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(a): (1) The bureau may renew a license granted under this chapter upon receipt of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(a)(i): a renewal application on forms as prescribed by the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(a)(ii): (1) the fees prescribed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(b)(i): The renewal of a license requires the filing of all certificates of insurance or proof of surety bond as required by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(b)(ii): Renewal of a license may not be granted more than 180 days after expiration.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(2)(c): A licensee may not engage in activity subject to this chapter during the period between the date of expiration of the license and the renewal of the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3)(a): The bureau shall renew a suspended license if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3)(a)(i): the period of suspension has been completed;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3)(a)(ii): the bureau has received a renewal application from the applicant on forms prescribed by the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3)(a)(iii): the applicant has:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3)(a)(iii)(B): paid the fees required by this section for renewal, including a delinquency fee if the application is not received by the bureau within 30 days of the termination of the suspension.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(3)(b): Renewal of the license does not entitle the licensee, while the license remains suspended and until it is reinstated, to engage in activity regulated by this chapter, or in other activity or conduct in violation of the order or judgment by which the license was suspended.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(4): The bureau may not reinstate a revoked license or accept an application for a license from a person whose license has been revoked for at least one year from the date of revocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-111(5): All fees, except the fingerprint processing fee, collected by the bureau under this section shall be deposited in the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112 Issuance of license and identification card to applicant -- License period -- Expiration of application -- Transfer of license prohibited.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(1): The commissioner shall issue a license to an applicant who complies with the provisions of this chapter.  Each license issued under this chapter shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(1)(a): contain the name and address of the licensee and the number of the license, its agency, registrant, or apprentice license designation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(1)(b): be issued for a period of two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(2): On the issuance of a license, an identification card shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(2)(a): be issued without charge to the licensee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(2)(b): state on its face whether the bearer holds an agency, registrant, or apprentice license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(3)(a): A registrant identification card shall state that the licensee is under the direction of a licensed agency and may not do investigative work independently for the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(3)(b): An apprentice identification card shall state that the licensee is under the direct supervision of a licensed agency and may not do investigative work independently for the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(4): Upon request by any person, the licensee shall immediately identify the name, business address, and phone number of the licensed agency for which the licensee is an employee or independent contractor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(5): 53-9-111
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(5)(a): On notification by the commissioner to an applicant that the license is not complete, or is not ready for issuance pending additional information, the applicant shall complete the application process and provide the additional information within 90 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(5)(b): Failure to complete the process shall result in the application being cancelled and all fees forfeited.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(5)(c): 53-9-111 Subsequent application by the same applicant requires the payment of all application and license fees prescribed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(6): 53-9-111 A licensee shall notify the commissioner of any change in the name or address of his business within 60 days of the change and failure to so notify will result in the automatic suspension of the license.  To relieve the suspension, the licensee must apply for reinstatement and pay the fee prescribed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-112(7): A license issued under this chapter is not transferable or assignable.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113 Grounds for denial of a license -- Appeal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(1): The board may deny a license or the renewal of a license if the applicant has:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(1)(a): committed an act that, if committed by a licensee, would be grounds for probation, suspension, or revocation of a license under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(1)(b): employed or contracted with a person who has been refused a license under this chapter or who has had a license revoked;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(1)(c): while not licensed under this chapter, committed, or aided and abetted the commission of, any act for which a license is required by this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(1)(d): knowingly made a material misstatement in connection with an application for a license or renewal of a license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(2)(a): The board's denial of a license under this chapter shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(2)(a)(i): be in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(2)(a)(ii): describe the basis for the denial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(2)(a)(iii): inform the applicant that if the applicant desires a hearing to contest the denial, the applicant shall submit a request in writing to the board within 30 days after the denial has been sent by certified mail to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(2)(b): The board shall schedule a hearing on the denial for the next board meeting after the applicant's request for a hearing has been received by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(3): The decision of the board may be appealed to the commissioner, who may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(3)(a): return the case to the board for reconsideration;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(3)(b): modify the board's decision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(3)(c): reverse the board's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(4): The commissioner shall promptly issue a final order and send the order by mail to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-113(5): 63G-4-402 Decisions of the commissioner are subject to judicial review pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-115(1)(a)(i): Title 42, Chapter 2, Conducting Business Under Assumed Name complying with the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-115(1)(a)(ii): providing a copy of the filed certificate to the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-115(1)(b): (1)(a) Failure to comply with Subsection

The address of this location shall be on file with the commissioner at all times and is not a public record pursuant to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-116 Divulging investigative information -- False reports prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-116(1): Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, a licensee may not divulge or release to anyone other than his client or employer the contents of an investigative file acquired in the course of licensed investigative activity.  However, the board shall have access to investigative files if the client for whom the information was acquired, or his lawful representative, alleges a violation of this chapter by the licensee or if the prior written consent of the client to divulge or release the information has been obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-116(2): A licensee may not willfully make a false statement or report to a client, employer, the board, or any authorized representative of the department, concerning information acquired in the course of activities regulated by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-116(3): The licensee shall submit investigative reports to a client at times and in the manner agreed upon between the licensee and the client.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-116(4): Upon demand by the client, the licensee shall divulge to the client the results of an investigation if payment in full has been tendered for the charges levied.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-116(5): The licensee has full right to withdraw from any case and refund any portion of a retainer for which investigative work has not been completed.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117 Authority to investigate complaint -- Filing of complaints -- Response -- Retention of records -- Appeal -- Penalties collected.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(1): The bureau or board may initiate an investigation of any person advertising services or engaged in performing services that require a license under this chapter and shall investigate if a licensee is engaged in activities that do not comply with or are prohibited by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(2): The bureau shall enforce the provisions of this chapter without regard to the place or location in which a violation may have occurred, and on the complaint of any person, may investigate any alleged violation of this chapter or the business and business methods of any licensee or applicant for licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(3): Complaints against any licensee shall be filed with the bureau in writing on forms prescribed by the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(3)(a): Upon receipt of a complaint, or at the request of the board, the bureau shall assign the complaint to an investigator within the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(3)(b): The bureau will provide a copy of the complaint to the licensee who shall answer the complaint in writing within 15 working days of the date the complaint is sent to the licensee by certified mail.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(4): In any investigation undertaken by the bureau, each licensee on request shall provide records and truthfully respond to questions concerning activities regulated under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(4)(a): These records shall be maintained for five years at the principal place of business of the licensee or at another location approved by the board for a person whose license has been terminated, canceled, or revoked.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(4)(b): On request by the bureau the licensee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(4)(b)(i): during normal business hours or other time acceptable to the parties, make its records available immediately to the bureau unless the bureau determines that an extension may be granted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(4)(b)(ii): provide copies of any business records requested by the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(5): 53-9-118; (8) Upon completion of the investigation, the bureau shall report its findings of fact to the board, and shall make a recommendation as to whether disciplinary action is warranted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(6): (5)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(6)(a): (5) If the bureau recommends disciplinary action, a notice of the recommendations in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(6)(b): The notice shall include the date and time of the meeting where the board will consider the bureau's recommendation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(6)(c): The board shall give the licensee an opportunity at the meeting to present testimony and evidence in response to the bureau's recommendation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(7): 53-9-118 If the board finds, based on the investigation or hearing, that a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8): Based on information the board receives from the investigation or during a hearing, the board may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(a): dismiss the complaint if the board finds it is without merit;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(b): take emergency action;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(c): issue a letter of concern, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(d): impose a civil penalty not to exceed $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(e): place the license on suspension for a period of not more than 12 months;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(f): revoke the license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(8)(g): place all records, evidence findings, and conclusion, and any other information pertinent to the investigation, in a confidential and protected records section of the licensee's file maintained at the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(9): 53-9-118 A letter of concern issued for a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(10)(a): Appeal of the board's decision shall be made in writing to the commissioner within 15 days from the date the board's decision is mailed to the licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(10)(b): The commissioner shall review the board's finding and may affirm, return to the board for reconsideration, reverse, adopt, modify, supplement, amend, or reject the recommendation of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(11): 63G-4-402
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(11)(a): The commissioner shall issue a final written order within 30 days outlining the decision on appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(11)(b): 63G-4-402 The final order is final agency action for purposes of judicial review under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(12)(a): If the board finds, based on the bureau's investigation, that the public health, safety, or welfare requires emergency action, the board may order a summary suspension of a license pending proceedings for revocation or other action.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(12)(b): If the board issues a summary suspension order, the board shall issue to the licensee a written notice of the order and indicate the licensee's right to request a formal hearing before the board.  The notice shall be mailed to the licensee by certified mail, return receipt requested.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(12)(c): The licensee's request for a formal hearing shall be in writing and mailed to the bureau within 30 working days of the date the summary suspension was mailed to the licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-117(13): All penalties collected under this section shall be deposited in the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118 Grounds for disciplinary action.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The board may suspend or revoke a license or registration or deny an application for a license if a person engages in:Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(1): fraud or willful misrepresentation in applying for an original license or renewal of an existing license;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(2): using any letterhead, advertising, or other printed matter in any manner representing that the licensee is an instrumentality of the federal government, a state, or any political subdivision of a state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(3): using a name different from that under which the licensee is currently licensed for any advertising, solicitation, or contract to secure business unless the name is an authorized fictitious name;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(4): impersonating, permitting, or aiding and abetting an employee or independent contractor to impersonate a peace officer or employee of the United States, any state, or a political subdivision of a state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(5): knowingly violating, advising, encouraging, or assisting the violation of any statute, court order, or injunction in the course of a business regulated under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(6): falsifying fingerprints or photographs while operating under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(7): conviction of a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(8): conviction of any act involving illegally using, carrying, or possessing a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(9): conviction of any act involving moral turpitude;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(10): conviction of any act of personal violence or force against any person or conviction of threatening to commit any act of personal violence or force against any person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(11): soliciting business for an attorney in return for compensation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(12): conviction of any act constituting dishonesty or fraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(13): being placed on probation, parole, or named in an outstanding arrest warrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(14): committing or permitting any employee or independent contractor to commit any act during the period when the license is expired or suspended;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(15): willfully neglecting to render to a client services or a report as agreed between the parties and for which compensation has been paid or tendered in accordance with the agreement of the parties unless the licensee chooses to withdraw from the case and returns the funds for work not yet completed;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(16): the unauthorized release of information acquired on behalf of a client by a licensee, or its employee or contract agent as a result of activities regulated under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(17): failing to cooperate with, misrepresenting to, or refusing access to business or investigative records requested by the board or an authorized representative of the bureau engaged in an official investigation pursuant to this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(18): employing or contracting with any unlicensed or improperly licensed person or agency to conduct activities regulated under this chapter if the licensure status was known or could have been ascertained by reasonable inquiry;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(19): permitting, authorizing, aiding, or in any way assisting an employee to conduct services as described in this chapter on an independent contractor basis and not under the authority of the licensed agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(20): failure to maintain in full force and effect liability or workers' compensation insurance, or a surety bond, if applicable;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(21): conducting private investigation services regulated by this chapter on a revoked or suspended license;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(22): accepting employment, contracting, or in any way engaging in employment that has an adverse impact on investigations being conducted on behalf of clients;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(23): advertising in a false, deceptive, or misleading manner;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(24): refusing to display the identification card issued by the bureau to any person having reasonable cause to verify the validity of the license;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(25): committing any act of unprofessional conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(26): 63G-2-801 conviction of any act of illegally obtaining or disseminating private, controlled, or protected records under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-118(27): any other conduct prohibited by this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-119 Violation -- Penalty.
----------------------------------------------------
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
