Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-122 Exemptions from licensure.
---------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided by statute or rule, the following individuals may engage in the practice of an occupation or profession regulated by this chapter, subject to the stated circumstances and limitations, without being licensed under this title:Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-122(1): an individual licensed under the laws of this state, other than under this chapter, to practice or engage in an occupation or profession, while engaged in the lawful, professional, and competent practice of that occupation or profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-122(2): an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States, the United States Public Health Service, the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, or any other federal agency while engaged in activities regulated under this title as a part of employment with that federal agency if the individual holds a valid license to practice the regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-122(3): the spouse of an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States while the individual is stationed within this state, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-122(3)(a): the spouse holds a valid license to practice the regulated occupation or profession issued by any other state or jurisdiction recognized by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-9-122(3)(b): the license is current and the spouse is in good standing in the state or jurisdiction of licensure.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 10 - Criminal Investigations and Technical Services Act
************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-101 Short title.
--------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Criminal Investigations and Technical Services Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(1): "Administration of criminal justice" means performance of any of the following: detection, apprehension, detention, pretrial release, posttrial release, prosecution, adjudication, correctional supervision, or rehabilitation of accused persons or criminal offenders.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(2): 32B-1-102 "Alcoholic beverage" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(3): 32B-1-102 "Alcoholic product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(4): 53-10-201 "Bureau" means the Bureau of Criminal Identification within the department, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(5): "Commission" means the Alcoholic Beverage Services Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(6): "Communications services" means the technology of reception, relay, and transmission of information required by a public safety agency in the performance of the public safety agency's duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(7): "Conviction record" means criminal history information indicating a record of a criminal charge that has led to a declaration of guilt of an offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(8): "Criminal history record information" means information on an individual consisting of identifiable descriptions and notations of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(8)(a): arrests, detentions, indictments, informations, or other formal criminal charges, and any disposition arising from any of them; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(8)(b): sentencing, correctional supervision, and release.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(9): "Criminal justice agency" means a court or a government agency or subdivision of a government agency that administers criminal justice under a statute, executive order, or local ordinance and that allocates greater than 50% of its annual budget to the administration of criminal justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(10): "Criminalist" means the scientific discipline directed to the recognition, identification, individualization, and evaluation of physical evidence by application of the natural sciences in law-science matters.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(11): "Department" means the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(12): 53-10-103 "Director" means the division director appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(13): 53-10-103 "Division" means the Criminal Investigations and Technical Services Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(14): "Executive order" means an order of the president of the United States or the chief executive of a state that has the force of law and that is published in a manner permitting regular public access to the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(15): "Forensic" means dealing with the application of scientific knowledge relating to criminal evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(16): "Mental defective" means an individual who, by a district court, as a result of marked subnormal intelligence, or mental illness, incompetency, condition, or disease, is found:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(16)(a): to be a danger to himself or herself or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(16)(b): to lack the mental capacity to contract or manage the individual's own affairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(16)(c): to be incompetent by a court in a criminal case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(16)(d): to be incompetent to stand trial or found not guilty by reason or lack of mental responsibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(17): "Missing child" means an individual under 18 years old who is missing from the individual's home environment or a temporary placement facility for any reason and whose location cannot be determined by the person responsible for the individual's care.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(18): 26B-8-130 "Missing person" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(19): "Pathogens" means disease-causing agents.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(20): "Physical evidence" means something submitted to the bureau to determine the truth of a matter using scientific methods of analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(21): "Qualifying entity" means a business, organization, or a governmental entity that employs persons or utilizes volunteers who deal with:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(21)(a): national security interests;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(21)(b): fiduciary trust over money; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-102(21)(c): the provision of care, treatment, education, training, instruction, supervision, or recreation to children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-103 Division -- Creation -- Director appointment and qualifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-103(1): There is created within the department the Criminal Investigations and Technical Services Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-103(2): The division shall be administered by a director appointed by the commissioner with the approval of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-103(3): The director is the executive and administrative head of the division and shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-103(4): The director acts under the supervision and control of the commissioner and may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-103(5): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act The director shall receive compensation as provided by


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104 Division duties.
------------------------------------------------
The division shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(1): provide and coordinate the delivery of support services to law enforcement agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(2): maintain and provide access to criminal records for use by law enforcement agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(3): publish law enforcement and statistical data;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(4): maintain dispatch and communications services for public safety communications centers and provide emergency medical, fire suppression, highway maintenance, public works, and law enforcement communications for municipal, county, state, and federal agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(5): analyze evidence from crime scenes and crime-related incidents for criminal prosecution;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(6): Title 26B, Chapter 8, Part 2, Utah Medical Examiner provide criminalistic laboratory services to federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies, prosecuting attorneys and agencies, and public defenders, with the exception of those services provided by the state medical examiner in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(7): establish satellite laboratories as necessary to provide criminalistic services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(8): safeguard the public through licensing and regulation of activities that impact public safety, including concealed weapons, emergency vehicles, and private investigators;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(9): provide investigative assistance to law enforcement and other government agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(10): collect and provide intelligence information to criminal justice agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(11): investigate crimes that jeopardize the safety of the citizens, as well as the interests, of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(12): regulate and investigate laws pertaining to the sale and distribution of liquor;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(13): make rules to implement this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(14): perform the functions specified in this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(15): 11-40-103 comply with the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(16): 72-10-602; 72-10-603 comply with the requirements of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-104(17): 53-10-115 develop and maintain a secure database of cold cases within the Utah Criminal Justice Information System pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105 Assistance to law enforcement agencies -- Investigation of crimes -- Laboratory facilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(1): The commissioner may assist any law enforcement agency in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(1)(a): establishing identification and investigation records systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(1)(b): establishing uniform crime reporting systems;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(1)(c): investigating any crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(1)(d): coordinating the exchange of criminal identification, intelligence, and investigation information among law enforcement agencies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(1)(e): providing the agencies with equipment, technical assistance, and instruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(2)(a): At the governor's direction, the commissioner shall assign division employees to investigate any crime within this state for the purpose of identifying, apprehending, and convicting the perpetrator or perpetrators of that crime even if the commissioner has not received a request from a law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(2)(b): The governor may establish a time period for the commissioner to pursue the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-105(2)(c): To accomplish the purposes of this section, the commissioner may provide, through the division, crime detection laboratory facilities.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-106 Cooperation with agencies of any state or nation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division shall cooperate with appropriate agencies of any state or nation in developing uniform systems of criminal identification, crime reporting, and information exchange.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-107 Admissibility in evidence of certified copies of division files.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A copy of any fingerprint, record, document, or other evidence in the files of the division, certified by the commissioner to be a true copy of the original, is admissible in evidence in the same manner as the original.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-109 Telecommunications systems.
-----------------------------------------------------------
For the purpose of expediting local, state, national, and international efforts in the detection and apprehension of criminals, the division may operate and coordinate telecommunications systems as may be required in the conduct of its duties under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-111 Refusal to provide information -- False information -- Misdemeanor.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a class B misdemeanor for a person to:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-111(1): neglect or refuse to provide, or willfully withhold any information under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-111(2): willfully provide false information;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-111(3): willfully fail to do or perform any act required under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-111(4): hinder or prevent another from doing an act required under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-111(5): willfully remove, destroy, alter, mutilate, or disclose the contents of any file or record created or maintained, or to which access is granted by the division unless authorized by and in compliance with procedures established by the division.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The director and enforcement officers:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-112(1): are vested with the powers of peace officers throughout the several counties of the state, with the exception of the power to serve civil process;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-112(2): Title 32B, Alcoholic Beverage Control Act have the powers and duties of inspectors under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-112(3): may serve criminal process and arrest and prosecute violators of any law of this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-112(4): have the same rights as other peace officers to require aid in executing their duties.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-115 Cold case database.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-115(1): 76-1-301(2)(a); (g) As used in this section, "cold case" means an investigation into any crime listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-115(2): The division shall develop a secure database within the Utah Criminal Justice Information System that contains information related to each cold case that is open in any jurisdiction in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-115(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division shall adopt rules in accordance with

The law enforcement agency shall maintain the physical evidence and investigation file for each case unless otherwise agreed to by the law enforcement agency and the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-115(5): The division shall maintain the information on a cold case indefinitely.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-116 National Crime Prevention and Privacy Compact ratification and implementation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-116(1): To facilitate the interstate exchange of criminal history information for noncriminal justice purposes, including background checks for licensing and screening of employees and volunteers, the National Crime Prevention and Privacy Compact, 42 U.S.C. 14616, is ratified and incorporated by reference as law in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-116(2): The division is the central repository of criminal history records for purposes of the compact and shall do all things necessary or incidental to carrying out the compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-116(3): The director, or director's designee, is the state's compact officer and shall administer the compact within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-116(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may adopt rules in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-116(5): The compact and this section do not affect the duties and responsibilities of the division under other provisions of this chapter regarding the dissemination of criminal history records within the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202 Criminal identification -- Duties of bureau.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The bureau shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(1): procure and file information relating to identification and activities of persons who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(1)(a): are fugitives from justice;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(1)(b): are wanted or missing;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(1)(c): have been arrested for or convicted of a crime under the laws of any state or nation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(1)(d): are believed to be involved in racketeering, organized crime, or a dangerous offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(2): establish a statewide uniform crime reporting system that shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(2)(a): statistics concerning general categories of criminal activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(2)(b): statistics concerning crimes that exhibit evidence of prejudice based on race, religion, ancestry, national origin, ethnicity, or other categories that the division finds appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(2)(c): statistics concerning the use of force by law enforcement officers in accordance with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(2)(d): other statistics required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(3): make a complete and systematic record and index of the information obtained under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(4): subject to the restrictions in this part, establish policy concerning the use and dissemination of data obtained under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(5): publish an annual report concerning the extent, fluctuation, distribution, and nature of crime in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(6): establish a statewide central register for the identification and location of missing persons, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(6)(a): identifying data including fingerprints of each missing person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(6)(b): identifying data of any missing person who is reported as missing to a law enforcement agency having jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(6)(c): dates and circumstances of any persons requesting or receiving information from the register; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(6)(d): any other information, including blood types and photographs found necessary in furthering the purposes of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(7): publish a quarterly directory of missing persons for distribution to persons or entities likely to be instrumental in the identification and location of missing persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(8): list the name of every missing person with the appropriate nationally maintained missing persons lists;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(9): establish and operate a 24-hour communication network for reports of missing persons and reports of sightings of missing persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(10): coordinate with the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children and other agencies to facilitate the identification and location of missing persons and the identification of unidentified persons and bodies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(11): 26B-8-130; 53G-6-602; 41-1a-1401 receive information regarding missing persons as provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(12): adopt systems of identification, including the fingerprint system, to be used by the division to facilitate law enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-202(13): 76-10-520 assign a distinguishing number or mark of identification to any pistol or revolver, as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204 Missing person records -- Confidentiality -- Availability.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Inquiries made regarding missing persons are confidential and are available only to:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204(1): a law enforcement agency investigating a report of a missing person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204(2): an agency having the responsibility or authority to care for, treat, or supervise a person who is the subject of a placement in temporary or substitute care or an adoption proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204(3): a court, upon a finding that access to the records may be necessary for the determination of an issue before it;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204(4): the office of the public prosecutor or its deputies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204(5): any person engaged in bona fide research when approved by the director of the division, excluding names and addresses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-204(6): 53-10-203 entities or persons authorized to receive the information in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-205 Uniform crime reporting system -- Reporting timelines and use of data.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-205(1): The data acquired under the statewide uniform crime reporting system shall be used only for research or statistical purposes and may not contain any information that may reveal the identity of an individual victim of a crime or law enforcement officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-205(2): 53-10-202 A law enforcement agency shall, for the jurisdiction of the law enforcement agency, submit crime reporting and use of force data requested or required by the statewide uniform crime reporting system described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-205(2)(a): to the bureau before the 16th day of the month after the month in which a reported crime occurs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-205(2)(b): in a manner prescribed by the bureau and in compliance with the requirements of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's uniform crime reporting standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-205(3): Upon request of the bureau, a law enforcement agency shall review and verify crime reporting data within 10 business days after the day on which the law enforcement agency receives the request.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-206 Collection of information.
----------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner and persons designated by him may require all peace officers, the warden of the state prison, the keeper of any jail or correctional institution, or superintendent of the state hospital to obtain information that will aid in establishing the records required to be kept.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-207 Peace officers, prosecutors, and magistrates to supply information to state and F.B.I. -- Notification of arrest based on warrant.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-207(1): Every peace officer shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-301(1): There is created within the division the State Bureau of Investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-301(2): The bureau shall be administered by a bureau chief appointed by the division director with the approval of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-301(3): The bureau chief shall be experienced in administration and possess additional qualifications as determined by the division director and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-301(4): The bureau chief acts under the supervision and control of the division director and may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-304(3): have concurrent law enforcement jurisdiction with all local law enforcement agencies and their officers;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-305 Duties of bureau chief.
-------------------------------------------------------
The bureau chief, with the consent of the commissioner, shall do the following:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-305(1): conduct in conjunction with the state boards of education and higher education in state schools, colleges, and universities, an educational program concerning alcoholic beverages and alcoholic products, and work in conjunction with civic organizations, churches, local units of government, and other organizations in the prevention of alcoholic beverage, alcoholic product, and drug violations;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-305(2): Title 32B, Alcoholic Beverage Control Act; 32B-1-102 coordinate law enforcement programs throughout the state and accumulate and disseminate information related to the prevention, detection, and control of violations of this chapter and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-305(3): make inspections and investigations as required by the commission and the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-305(4): perform other acts as may be necessary or appropriate concerning control of the use of an alcoholic beverage or alcoholic product and drugs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-305(5): make reports and recommendations to the Legislature, the governor, the commissioner, the commission, and the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Services as may be required or requested.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-401 Bureau of Forensic Services -- Creation -- Bureau Chief appointment, qualifications, and compensation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-401(1): There is created within the division the Bureau of Forensic Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-401(2): The bureau shall be administered by a bureau chief appointed by the division director with the approval of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-401(3): The bureau chief shall be experienced in administration of criminal justice and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner or division director and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-401(4): The bureau chief acts under the supervision and control of the division director and may be removed from his position at the will of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-401(5): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act The bureau chief shall receive compensation as provided by


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402 Bureau duties.
----------------------------------------------
The bureau shall:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(1): provide quality, timely, and comprehensive analysis of physical evidence from crime scenes and crime-related incidents submitted by federal, state, county, and municipal criminal justice agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(2): provide expert testimony in courts of law regarding the scientific analysis and conclusion of forensic evidence using the most current and advanced analytical techniques and technology;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(3): ensure the safety of all laboratory employees against exposure to blood-borne pathogens, infectious materials, and any other biochemical or toxic hazard which may pose a threat to the safety and well-being of bureau employees;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(4): protect the chain of incoming evidence by ensuring all items are properly packaged, sealed, marked, stored, and delivered back to the submitting agency using established legal guidelines;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(5): adopt systems of identification, including blood and firearms analysis, to be used by the division to facilitate law enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(6): participate in establishing satellite laboratories in designated locations throughout the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(7): provide assistance to the medical community in establishing guidelines for the  proper handling of individuals who are the victims of sexual assault; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-402(8): upon request, provide law enforcement agencies technical and analytical support in the processing of crime scenes.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
As used in this section and SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(1): 80-1-102 "Adjudication" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(2): "Bureau" means the Bureau of Forensic Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(3): "Combined DNA Index System" or "CODIS" means the program operated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to support criminal justice DNA databases and the software used to run the databases.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(4): "Conviction" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(4)(a): a verdict or conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(4)(b): a plea of guilty or guilty with a mental condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(4)(c): a plea of no contest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(4)(d): the acceptance by the court of a plea in abeyance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(5): "DNA" means deoxyribonucleic acid.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(6): "DNA profile" means the patterns of fragments of DNA used to identify an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(7): "DNA specimen" or "specimen" means a biological sample collected from an individual or a crime scene, or that is collected as part of an investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(8): "Final judgment" means a judgment, including any supporting opinion, concerning which all appellate remedies have been exhausted or the time for appeal has expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(9): 80-1-102 "Minor" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(10): "Rapid DNA" means the fully automated process of developing a DNA profile.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.5(11): 76-3-203.5 "Violent felony" means any offense under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6 Use of Rapid DNA.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6(1): 53-10-405 Rapid DNA technology may be used for the purposes of conducting testing of a DNA specimen obtained:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6(1)(a): 53-10-405 at the time of booking in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6(1)(b): for non-CODIS comparison during an investigation, if a second specimen is also obtained and is submitted to the bureau or another laboratory that is a National DNA Index System participating laboratory for testing.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6(2): (1)(b) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6(3): Rapid DNA technology may be used for other purposes only when conducted by the bureau in its capacity as the state's National DNA Index System participating laboratory that follows the Federal Bureau of Investigation Quality Assurance Standards for Forensic DNA Testing Laboratories.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.6(4): If the investigating agency submits a DNA specimen to the bureau in accordance with the provisions of this section, the bureau shall provide the results of the test directly to the local law enforcement agency that submitted the DNA specimen.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7 Investigative genetic genealogy service -- Genetic genealogy database utilization -- Third-party specimens -- Requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(a): "Genetic genealogy company" means a company that provides a genetic genealogy database utilization or an investigative genetic genealogy service.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(b): "Genetic genealogy database utilization" means a utilization of a genetic genealogical database for the purpose of identifying potential biological relatives to a DNA profile.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(c): "Genetic information" means data acquired from an analysis of a DNA specimen.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(d): "Investigative genetic genealogy service" means the processing of an individual's DNA specimen or genetic data file to be used for a genetic genealogy database utilization.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(e): "Prosecuting agency" means the Office of the Attorney General or the office of a county attorney or district attorney, including an attorney on the staff, whether acting in a civil or criminal capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(f): "Qualifying case" means an investigation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(f)(i): a violent felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(f)(ii): the identity of a missing or unknown individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(1)(g): "Third-party DNA specimen" means a DNA specimen obtained from an individual who is not a likely suspect in an investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2): 78B-9-301 A law enforcement agency may request an investigative genetic genealogy service or a genetic genealogy database utilization from the bureau or a genetic genealogy company if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(i): the law enforcement agency, through the law enforcement agency's investigation, has a DNA profile from forensic evidence that the law enforcement agency reasonably believes is attributable to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(i)(A): the perpetrator of a crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(i)(B): the remains of an unidentified individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(i)(C): a missing or unknown individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(ii): the case for which the law enforcement agency requires the information is a qualifying case;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(iii): a routine search of CODIS-eligible profiles, if any, developed in the case revealed no DNA matches to the DNA profile;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(iv): the law enforcement agency, the bureau, and the prosecuting agency consult regarding whether an investigative genetic genealogy service or genetic genealogy database utilization is an appropriate and necessary step in the development of information that may contribute to solving the case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(a)(v): the law enforcement agency and prosecuting agency commit to further investigation of the case if the investigative genetic genealogy service or genetic genealogy database utilization produces information that may contribute to solving the case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(2)(b): 78B-9-301 ordered by a court in accordance with a postconviction relief proceeding under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3): (3)(a)(ii)(B); (3)(a)(ii)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(a): Before a law enforcement agency may collect a third-party DNA specimen for the purpose of obtaining an investigative genetic genealogy service or a genetic genealogy database utilization, the law enforcement agency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(a)(i): consult with the prosecuting agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(a)(ii)(A): obtain informed, voluntary consent from the individual providing the third-party DNA specimen; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(a)(ii)(B): if the law enforcement agency concludes that the case-specific circumstances provide reasonable grounds to believe that a request for informed, voluntary consent would compromise the integrity of the investigation, obtain from the prosecuting agency authorization for a covert collection of the third-party DNA specimen.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(b): (3)(a)(ii)(B) Before obtaining a third-party DNA specimen in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(3)(c): (3)(a)(ii)(B) A law enforcement agency that obtains a DNA specimen in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(4): (3) A law enforcement agency or a prosecuting agency may only use a third-party DNA specimen obtained under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(4)(a): identify a possible suspect;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(4)(b): exonerate a possible suspect; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(4)(c): identify a missing or unknown individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5): (2) When requesting an investigative genetic genealogy service or genetic genealogy database utilization from a genetic genealogy company under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(a): disclose to the genetic genealogy company that the request is from a law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(b): only make a request to a genetic genealogy company that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(b)(i): provides notice to the genetic genealogy company's service users and the public that law enforcement may use the genetic genealogy company's services to investigate crimes or to identify unidentified human remains;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(b)(ii): allows a user to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(b)(ii)(A): opt in or out of having the user's data be accessible in an investigation requested by law enforcement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(b)(ii)(B): access the genetic genealogy company's services even if the user opts out of having the user's data be accessible in an investigation requested by law enforcement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(b)(iii): has a policy that prevents the genetic genealogy company from compiling, selling, licensing, or transferring to a third party any data generated by the genetic genealogy company concerning a victim, crime scene, or suspect;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(c): confirm that the request is permitted under the terms of service for the genetic genealogy company; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(5)(d): if possible, configure or request the genetic genealogy company to configure service site user settings that control access to the DNA submitted by the law enforcement agency and associated account information in a manner that will prevent the information from being viewed by other service users.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6): (2)(a); (6)(b)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(a): (2)(a) Before an individual may be arrested as a suspect in a crime for which an investigative genetic genealogy service or genetic genealogy database utilization has been conducted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b): (6)(b)(ii) After an individual has been charged with an offense after an investigative genetic genealogy service or a genetic genealogy database utilization has been conducted for that offense, the law enforcement agency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b)(i): if applicable, verify with confirmatory genetic testing that the DNA obtained from the crime scene could have originated from the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b)(ii): if applicable, make a prompt, formal request to the genetic genealogy company to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b)(ii)(A): provide the DNA information and any associated account information related to the charged crime directly to the law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b)(ii)(B): remove the DNA information and any associated account information held by the genetic genealogy company;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b)(iii): (6)(b)(ii) if applicable, document the request described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(6)(b)(iv): retain the information received from the genetic genealogy company or the bureau for use during prosecution and subsequent judicial proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(7): 78B-9-301 A law enforcement agency or a prosecuting agency:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(7)(a): may not request an investigative genetic genealogy service or a genetic genealogy database utilization except as provided in this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(7)(b): 78B-9-301 shall ensure that genetic information obtained under this section is used only for law enforcement purposes or postconviction relief purposes under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(7)(c): shall ensure that a DNA specimen and associated genetic information is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(7)(c)(i): retained in conformance with applicable laws; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(7)(c)(ii): destroyed once permitted under applicable laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(8): (8)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(8)(a): A violation of this section does not confer standing to a criminal defendant to request the suppression of evidence unless a court determines that the violation led to a deprivation of the defendant's constitutional rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(8)(b): (8)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(8)(b)(i): If a court in a civil suit finds that an employee or agent of a law enforcement agency knowingly has violated a provision of this section, the court shall order that the employee or agent may not participate in another investigative genetic genealogy service or genetic genealogy database utilization under this section for one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-403.7(8)(b)(ii): (8)(b)(i) A finding or order under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-404(3)(e)(iii): The collection fee is not imposed for a second or subsequent DNA specimen collected under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-404(6)(b)(i): first, to obtain DNA specimens of persons who as of July 1, 2002, are in the custody of or under the supervision of the department before these persons are released from incarceration, parole, or probation, if their release date is prior to that of persons under Subsection (6)(b)(ii), but in no case later than July 1, 2004; and

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-404(6)(d): Implementation of the schedule of priority under Subsection (6)(c) is subject to the priority of Subsection (6)(b)(i), to ensure that the Department of Corrections obtains DNA specimens from persons in the custody of or under the supervision of the Department of Corrections as of July 1, 2002, prior to their release.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406 DNA specimen analysis -- Bureau responsibilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1): 53-10-403 The bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(a): administer and oversee the DNA specimen collection process;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(b): store each DNA specimen and associated records received;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(c): analyze each specimen, or contract with a qualified public or private laboratory to analyze the specimen, to establish the genetic profile of the donor or to otherwise determine the identity of the person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(d): maintain a criminal identification database containing information derived from DNA analysis;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(e): ensure that the DNA identification system does not provide information allowing prediction of genetic disease or predisposition to illness;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(f): ensure that only DNA markers routinely used or accepted in the field of forensic science are used to establish the gender and unique individual identification of the donor;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(g): utilize only those DNA analysis procedures that are consistent with, and do not exceed, procedures established and used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for the forensic analysis of DNA;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(h): 53-10-403 destroy a DNA specimen obtained under this part if criminal charges have not been filed within 90 days after booking for an alleged offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(1)(i): make rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, establishing procedures for obtaining, transmitting, and analyzing DNA specimens and for storing and destroying DNA specimens and associated records, and criminal identification information obtained from the analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(2): Procedures for DNA analysis may include all techniques which the department determines are accurate and reliable in establishing identity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(3): 63G-2-305
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(3)(a): 63G-2-305 In accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(3)(b): The department may not transfer or disclose any DNA specimen, associated record, or criminal identification information obtained, stored, or maintained under this section, except under the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(4): 63G-2-202 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(5): The department shall adopt procedures governing the inspection of records, DNA specimens, and challenges to the accuracy of records.  The procedures shall accommodate the need to preserve the materials from contamination and destruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(6): 53-10-404.5; 53-10-404.5; 53-10-404.5 A person whose DNA specimen is obtained under this part may, personally or through a legal representative, submit:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(6)(a): 53-10-404.5 to the court a motion for a court order requiring the destruction of the person's DNA specimen, associated record, and any criminal identification record created in connection with that specimen, and removal of the person's DNA record from the database described in Subsection (1)(d) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(6)(a)(i): a final judgment reverses the conviction, judgment, or order that created an obligation to provide a DNA specimen; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(6)(a)(ii): 53-10-404.5 all charges arising from the same criminal episode for which the DNA specimen was obtained under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(7): A court order issued under Subsection (6)(a) may be accompanied by a written notice to the person advising that state law provides for expungement of criminal charges if the charge is resolved by a final judgment of dismissal or acquittal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(8): 53-10-403 The department shall destroy the person's DNA specimen, and associated record, and remove the person's DNA record from the database described in Subsection (1)(d), if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(8)(a): the person provides the department with:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(10): A DNA specimen, associated record, or criminal identification record created in connection with that specimen may not be affected by an order to set aside a conviction, except under the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(11): If funding is not available for analysis of any of the DNA specimens collected under this part, the bureau shall store the collected specimens until funding is made available for analysis through state or federal funds.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(a)(i): A person who, due to the person's employment or authority, has possession of or access to individually identifiable DNA information contained in the state criminal identification database or the state DNA specimen repository may not willfully disclose the information in any manner to any individual, agency, or entity that is not entitled under this part to receive the information.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(a)(ii): A person may not willfully obtain individually identifiable DNA information from the state criminal identification database or the state DNA repository other than as authorized by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(a)(iii): A person may not willfully analyze a DNA specimen for any purpose, or to obtain any information other than as required under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(a)(iv): A person may not willfully fail to destroy or fail to ensure the destruction of a DNA specimen when destruction is required by this part or by court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(b)(i): A person who violates Subsection (12)(a)(i), (ii), or (iii) is guilty of a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-406(12)(b)(ii): A person who violates Subsection (12)(a)(iv) is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-501 Bureau of Communications -- Creation -- Bureau Chief appointment, qualifications, and compensation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-501(1): There is created within the division the Bureau of Communications.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-501(2): The bureau shall be managed by a bureau chief selected by the division director, with the approval of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-501(3): The bureau chief should be experienced in communications and administration, and possess additional qualifications as determined by the commissioner or division director and as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-501(4): The bureau chief acts under the supervision and control of the division director.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-502 Bureau duties.
----------------------------------------------
The bureau:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-502(1): maintains dispatch and communications services for regional public safety consolidated communications centers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-502(2): provides facilities and acts as a public safety answering point to answer and respond to 911 calls from a region;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-502(3): provides professional emergency dispatch and communications support for law enforcement, emergency medical, fire suppression, highway maintenance, public works, and public safety agencies representing municipal, county, state, and federal governments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-502(4): coordinates incident response.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-701 Title -- Creation.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-701(1): This part is known as the "Utah Silver Alert Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-701(2): There is created the Utah Silver Alert Notification System (Silver Alert) for missing and endangered adults to be administered by the department.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-702 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-702(1): "Dementia" means a person has a form of cognitive decline that significantly affects the person's ability to make decisions and provide for health, safety, or self care. This term includes Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia marked by the continual loss of memory and awareness of surroundings.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-702(2): "Endangered adult" means a person 60 years of age or older or a person under 60 years of age who has a form of dementia.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-703 Silver Alert Notification System -- Law enforcement and department responsibilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-703(1): The department shall develop a quick response system designed to issue and coordinate alerts following the report of a missing endangered adult. The system shall utilize the same coordination as the Amber Alert System with the following exceptions:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-703(1)(a): the National Emergency Broadcast System may not be activated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-703(1)(b): notification to the Department of Transportation for the activation of highway signage shall indicate the specific area in which the person was last seen so that signs only in that geographical area will be activated.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-703(2): Upon receiving a report of a missing adult, the law enforcement officer shall determine whether the missing adult meets the criteria to be designated as an endangered adult.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-703(3): If it is determined that the missing adult is an endangered adult, the officer investigating the person's disappearance shall request the department activate the Silver Alert Notification System.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-704 Rulemaking authority.
-----------------------------------------------------
The department shall make rules in accordance withUtah Code Annotated § 53-10-704(1): request for a Silver Alert by a law enforcement officer or agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-704(2): activation of the Silver Alert Notification System;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-704(3): duration of the Silver Alert; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-704(4): cancellation of a Silver Alert.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
For purposes of this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(1): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses "Alleged sexual offender" means an individual or a minor regarding whom an indictment, petition, or an information has been filed or an arrest has been made alleging the commission of a sexual offense or an attempted sexual offense under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(1)(a): a judge has signed an accompanying arrest warrant, pickup order, or any other order based upon probable cause regarding the alleged offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(1)(b): the judge has found probable cause to believe that the alleged victim has been exposed to conduct or activities that may result in an HIV infection as a result of the alleged offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(2): 26B-1-201 "Department of Health and Human Services" means the Department of Health and Human Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(3): "HIV infection" means an indication of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection determined by current medical standards and detected by any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(3)(a): presence of antibodies to HIV, verified by a positive "confirmatory" test, such as Western blot or other method approved by the Utah State Health Laboratory.  Western blot interpretation will be based on criteria currently recommended by the Association of State and Territorial Public Health Laboratory Directors;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(3)(b): presence of HIV antigen;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(3)(c): isolation of HIV; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(3)(d): demonstration of HIV proviral DNA.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(4): "HIV positive individual" means an individual who is HIV positive as determined by the State Health Laboratory.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(5): 26A-1-102 "Local department of health" means a local health department as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(6): "Minor" means an individual younger than 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(7): (3) "Positive" means an indication of the HIV infection as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-801(8): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses "Sexual offense" means a violation of any offense under

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803 Voluntary testing -- Victim to request -- Costs paid by Utah Office for Victims of Crime.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803(1): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses A victim or minor victim of a sexual offense as provided under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803(2)(a): The local health department shall obtain the blood specimen from the victim and forward the specimen to the Department of Health.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803(2)(b): The Department of Health shall analyze the specimen of the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803(3): The testing shall consist of a base-line test of the victim at the time immediately or as soon as possible after the alleged occurrence of the sexual offense.  If the base-line test result is not positive, follow-up testing shall occur at three months and six months after the alleged occurrence of the sexual offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-803(4): The Crime Victim Reparations Fund shall pay for the costs of the victim testing if the victim provides a substantiated claim of the sexual offense, does not test HIV positive at the base-line testing phase, and complies with eligibility criteria established by the Utah Office for Victims of Crime.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-901 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Sexual Assault Kit Processing Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(1): "Collecting facility" means a hospital, health care facility, or other facility that performs sexual assault examinations.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(2): "Department" means the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(3): "Restricted kit" means a sexual assault kit:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(3)(a): that is collected by a collecting facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(3)(b): for which a victim who is 18 years old or older at the time of the sexual assault kit evidence collection declines:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(3)(b)(i): to have his or her sexual assault kit processed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(3)(b)(ii): to have the sexual assault examination form shared with any entity outside of the collection facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(4): "Sexual assault kit" means a package of items that is used by medical personnel to gather and preserve biological and physical evidence following an allegation of a sexual offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(5): 77-37-2 "Sexual offense" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(6): "Trauma-informed, victim-centered" means policies, procedures, programs, and practices that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(6)(a): have demonstrated an ability to minimize retraumatization associated with the criminal justice process by recognizing the presence of trauma symptoms and acknowledging the role that trauma has played in the life of a victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(6)(b): encourage law enforcement officers to interact with victims with compassion and sensitivity in a nonjudgmental manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-902(7): "Victim" means an individual against whom a sexual offense has been committed or allegedly been committed.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903 All sexual assault kits to be submitted.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(1): 53-10-904(5) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(2): The Utah Bureau of Forensic Services shall test all sexual assault kits that the bureau receives with the goal of developing autosomal DNA profiles that are eligible for entry into the Combined DNA Index System.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3)(a): The testing of all sexual assault kits shall be completed within a specified amount of time, as determined by administrative rule consistent with the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3)(b): The ability of the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services to meet the established time frames may be dependent upon the following factors:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3)(b)(i): the number of sexual assault kits that the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services receives;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3)(b)(ii): the technology available and improved testing methods;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3)(b)(iii): fully trained and dedicated staff to meet the full workload needs of the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-903(3)(b)(iv): the number of lab requests received relating to other crime categories.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904 Sexual assault kit processing -- Restricted kits.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(1): 53-10-907 Unless the health care provider designates a sexual assault kit as a restricted kit, the collecting facility shall enter the required victim information into the statewide sexual assault kit tracking system, defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(2): A restricted kit may only be designated as a restricted kit:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(2)(a): by a health care provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(2)(b): at the time of collection.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(3): Each sexual assault kit collected by medical personnel shall be taken into custody by a law enforcement agency as soon as possible and within one business day of notice from the collecting facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(4): 53-10-907 The law enforcement agency that receives a sexual assault kit shall enter the required information into the statewide sexual assault kit tracking system, provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(5): Each sexual assault kit received by a law enforcement agency from a collecting facility that relates to an incident that occurred outside of the jurisdiction of the law enforcement agency shall be transferred to the law enforcement agency with jurisdiction over the incident within 10 days of learning that another law enforcement agency has jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6)(a): Except for restricted kits, each sexual assault kit shall be submitted to the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services as soon as possible, but no later than 30 days after receipt by a law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6)(b): Restricted kits may not be submitted to the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6)(c): Restricted kits shall be maintained by the law enforcement agency with jurisdiction, in accordance with the provisions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6)(d): A restricted kit may be changed to an unrestricted kit if the victim informs the designated law enforcement agency that he or she wants to have the sexual assault kit processed and agrees to release of the sexual assault examination form with the sexual assault kit. Once a victim indicates that he or she wants the sexual assault kit processed:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6)(d)(i): the kit may no longer be classified as restricted; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(6)(d)(ii): the kit shall be transmitted to the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services as soon as possible, but no later than 30 days after the victim chooses to unrestrict his or her kit with law enforcement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(7): If available, a suspect standard or a consensual partner elimination standard shall be submitted to the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(7)(a): with the sexual assault kit, if available, at the time the sexual assault kit is submitted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(7)(b): as soon as possible, but no later than 30 days from the date the kit was obtained by the law enforcement agency, if not obtained until after the sexual assault kit is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-904(8): Failure to meet a deadline established in this part or as part of any rules established by the department is not a basis for dismissal of a criminal action or a bar to the admissibility of the evidence in a criminal action.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905 Sexual assault kit retention and disposal -- Notification.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(1): 77-11a-101; 77-11c-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(1)(a): 77-11a-101 "Agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(1)(b): 77-11c-101 "Agency" includes an evidence collecting or retaining entity as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(2): An agency with custody of a sexual assault kit shall preserve the sexual assault kit in accordance with Title 77, Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(3): 77-11c-201; 77-11c-301; 77-11c-401 An agency shall send a notice to a victim that the agency intends to dispose of a sexual assault kit if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(3)(a): 77-11c-201; 77-11c-301; 77-11c-401 the agency intends to dispose of the sexual assault kit before the applicable time period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(3)(b): the victim provided a written request to the agency investigating the sexual offense that the victim receive notice of when the agency intends to dispose of the sexual assault kit.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(4): An agency shall send a notice of intent to dispose of a sexual assault kit to the victim:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(4)(a): at least 180 days before the day on which the agency intends to dispose of the sexual assault kit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(4)(b): by certified mail, return receipt requested, or a delivery service that provides proof of delivery.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(5): If a victim receives a notice of intent to dispose of a sexual assault kit, the victim may submit a written request, within the 180-day period described in Subsection (4)(a), that the agency retain the sexual assault kit.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(6): A notice of intent to dispose of a sexual assault kit shall provide the victim with information on how to submit a written request described in Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-905(7): 77-11c-201; 77-11c-301; 77-11c-401 If an agency receives a written request to retain the sexual assault kit from the victim within the 180-day period described in Subsection (4)(a), the agency shall retain the sexual assault kit for the applicable time period described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906 Victim notification of rights -- Notification of law enforcement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1): 77-37-3 Collecting facility personnel who conduct sexual assault examinations shall inform each victim of a sexual assault of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(a): available services for treatment of sexually transmitted infections, pregnancy, and other medical and psychiatric conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(b): available crisis intervention or other mental health services provided;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(c): the option to receive prophylactic medication to prevent sexually transmitted infections and pregnancy;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(d): the right to determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(d)(i): whether to provide a personal statement about the sexual assault to law enforcement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(d)(ii): if law enforcement should have access to any paperwork from the forensic examination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(1)(e): 77-37-3 the victim's rights as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(2): The collecting facility shall notify law enforcement as soon as practicable if the victim of a sexual assault decides to interview and discuss the assault with law enforcement.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(3): If a victim of a sexual assault declines to provide a personal statement about the sexual assault to law enforcement, the collecting facility shall provide a written notice to the victim that contains the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(3)(a): where the sexual assault kit will be stored;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(3)(b): notice that the victim may choose to contact law enforcement any time after declining to provide a personal statement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(3)(c): the name, phone number, and email address of the law enforcement agency having jurisdiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-906(3)(d): the name and phone number of a local rape crisis and services center.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907 Statewide sexual assault kit tracking system.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(1): The department shall develop and implement a statewide tracking system that contains the following information for all sexual assault kits collected by law enforcement:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(1)(a): the submission status of sexual assault kits by law enforcement to the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(1)(b): notification by the Utah Bureau of Forensic Services to law enforcement of DNA analysis findings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(1)(c): the storage location of sexual assault kits.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(2): The tracking system shall include a secure electronic access that allows the submitting agency, collecting facility, department, and a victim, or his or her designee, to access or receive information, provided that the disclosure does not impede or compromise an active investigation, about the:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(2)(a): lab submission status;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(2)(b): DNA analysis findings provided to law enforcement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-907(2)(c): storage location of a sexual assault kit that was gathered from that victim.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1001(1): "Abduction of a child" means the taking, concealing, or detaining of a child without permission from an individual entitled to custody of the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1001(2): "Amber Alert" means an alert issued in accordance with America's Missing: Broadcast Emergency Response run by the bureau to assist a law enforcement agency in the recovery of an abducted child.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1001(3): "Child" means an individual under 18 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1001(4): 80-1-102 "Runaway" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002 Amber Alert criteria.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(1)(a): the investigating law enforcement agency confirms that an abduction of the child has occurred;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(1)(b): the investigating law enforcement agency believes there is a credible threat of imminent danger of serious bodily injury or death to the child; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(1)(c): there is sufficient descriptive information about the child, alleged abductor, or the circumstances surrounding the abduction to indicate that issuing an Amber Alert will assist in the safe recovery of the child or the apprehension of the abductor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(2): A law enforcement agency may not issue an Amber Alert:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(2)(a): for a reported runaway; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(2)(b): for the taking, concealing, or detaining of a child by the child's parent during a child custody dispute regarding the child, unless there is a credible threat of imminent danger of serious bodily injury or death to the child.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-10-1002(3): The investigating law enforcement agency may use relevant law enforcement technology, including an automatic license plate reader system, to locate a vehicle that is being sought in connection with an issued Amber Alert.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 11 - Bail Bond Recovery Act
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Bail Bond Recovery Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(1): "Applicant" means a person who has submitted to the department a completed application and all required application and processing fees.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(2): "Bail bond agency" means a bail enforcement agent licensed under this chapter who operates a business to carry out the functions of a bail enforcement agent, and to conduct this business:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(2)(a): employs one or more persons licensed under this chapter for wages or salary, and withholds all legally required deductions and contributions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(2)(b): contracts with a bail recovery agent or bail recovery apprentice on a part-time or case-by-case basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(3): "Bail enforcement agent" means an individual licensed under this chapter as a bail enforcement agent to enforce the terms and conditions of a defendant's release on bail in a civil or criminal proceeding, to apprehend a defendant or surrender a defendant to custody, or both, as is appropriate, and who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(3)(a): is appointed by a bail bond surety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(3)(b): receives or is promised money or other things of value for this service.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(4): "Bail recovery agent" means an individual employed by a bail enforcement agent to assist the bail enforcement agent regarding civil or criminal defendants released on bail by:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(4)(a): presenting a defendant for required court appearances;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(4)(b): apprehending or surrendering a defendant to a court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(4)(c): keeping the defendant under necessary surveillance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(5): "Bail recovery apprentice" means any individual licensed under this chapter as a bail recovery apprentice, and who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(5)(a): has not met the requirements for licensure as a bail recovery agent or bail enforcement agent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(5)(b): is employed by a bail enforcement agent, and works under the direct supervision of a bail enforcement agent or bail recovery agent employed also by the bail enforcement agent, unless the bail recovery apprentice is conducting activities at the direction of the employing bail enforcement agent that under this chapter do not require direct supervision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(6): 53-11-104 "Board" means the Bail Bond Recovery Licensure Board created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(7): 53-10-201 "Bureau" means the Bureau of Criminal Identification created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(8): 53-1-107 "Commissioner" means the commissioner of public safety as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(9): "Contract employee" or "independent contractor" means a person who works for an agency as an independent contractor.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(10): "Conviction" means an adjudication of guilt by a federal, state, or local court resulting from a trial or plea, including a plea of no contest or nolo contendere, regardless of whether the imposition of sentence was suspended.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(11): "Department" means the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(12): "Direct supervision" means a bail enforcement agent employing or contracting with a bail recovery apprentice, or a bail recovery agent employed by or contracting with that bail enforcement agent who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(12)(a): takes responsibility for and assigns the work a bail recovery apprentice may conduct; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(12)(b): closely supervises, within close physical proximity, and provides direction and guidance to the bail recovery apprentice regarding the assigned work.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(13): "Emergency action" means a summary suspension of a license issued under this chapter pending revocation, suspension, or probation, in order to protect the public health, safety, or welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(14): "Identification card" means a card issued by the commissioner to an applicant qualified for licensure under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(15): "Letter of concern" means an advisory letter to notify a licensee that while there is insufficient evidence to support probation, suspension, or revocation of a license, the department believes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(15)(a): the licensee should modify or eliminate certain practices; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(15)(b): continuation of the activities that led to the information being submitted to the department may result in further disciplinary action against the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(16): "Occupied structure" means any edifice, including residential and public buildings, vehicles, or any other structure that could reasonably be expected to house or shelter persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(17): "Supervision" means the employing bail enforcement agent is responsible for and authorizes the type and extent of work assigned to a bail recovery agent who is his employee or contract employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(18): "Unprofessional conduct" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(18)(a): engaging or offering to engage by fraud or misrepresentation in any activities regulated by this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(18)(b): aiding or abetting a person who is not licensed pursuant to this chapter in representing that person as a bail recovery agent in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(18)(c): gross negligence in the practice of a bail recovery agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(18)(d): committing a felony or a misdemeanor involving any crime that is grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of a bail recovery license, and conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction or a plea of no contest is conclusive evidence of the commission; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-102(18)(e): making a fraudulent or untrue statement to the board, department, its investigators, or staff.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-103 Commissioner of Public Safety administers -- Licensure -- Rulemaking.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104 Board.
--------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(1): There is established under the Department of Public Safety a Bail Bond Recovery and Private Investigator Licensure Board consisting of eight members appointed by the commissioner.
