Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(a): one member shall be a person who is qualified for and is licensed under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(b): one member shall be a person who is qualified for and is licensed under Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(c): one member shall be a an attorney licensed to practice in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(d): one member shall be a chief of police or sheriff;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(e): one member shall be a supervisory investigator from the commissioner's office;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(f): one member shall be an owner of a bail bond surety company;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(g): one member shall be an owner of a private investigator agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(h): one member shall be a public member who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(h)(i): does not have a financial interest in a bail bond surety or bail bond recovery business;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(h)(ii): does not have a financial interest in a private investigative agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(2)(h)(iii): does not have an immediate family member or a household member, or a personal or professional acquaintance who is licensed or registered under this chapter or Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(3)(a): As terms of current board members expire, the commissioner shall appoint each new member or reappointed member to a four-year term, except as required by Subsection (3)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(3)(b): The commissioner shall, at the time of appointment or reappointment, adjust the length of terms to ensure that the terms of board members are staggered so that approximately half of the board is appointed every two years.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(4): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(5): At its first meeting every year, the board shall elect a chair and vice chair from its membership.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(6): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(7): A member may not serve more than one term, except that a member appointed to fill a vacancy or appointed for an initial term of less than four years under Subsection (3) may be reappointed for one additional full term.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(8): The commissioner, after a board hearing and recommendation, may remove any member of the board for misconduct, incompetency, or neglect of duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-104(9): Members of the board are immune from suit with respect to all acts done and actions taken in good faith in carrying out the purposes of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105 Powers and duties of board.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1): The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(a): review all applications for licensing and renewals of licenses submitted by the bureau under this chapter and approve or disapprove these applications;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(b): review all complaints and take disciplinary action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(c): establish standards for and approve providers of courses required for licensure under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(2): The board may take and hear evidence, administer oaths and affirmations, and compel by subpoena the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers, records, documents, and other information relating to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(2)(a): investigation of an applicant for licensure under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(2)(b): a formal complaint against or department investigation of a bail enforcement agent, bail recovery agent, or bail recovery apprentice.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105 Powers and duties of board.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1): The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(a)(i): review all applications for licensing and renewals of licenses submitted by the bureau under this chapter and Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(a)(ii): approve or disapprove the applications;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(b): review all complaints and take disciplinary action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(1)(c): establish standards for and approve providers of courses required for licensure under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(2)(a): investigation of an applicant for licensure under this chapter or Title 53, Chapter 9, Private Investigator Regulation Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-105(2)(b): a formal complaint against or department investigation of a bail enforcement agent, bail recovery agent, bail recovery apprentice, or a private investigator.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106 Board meetings and hearings -- Quorum.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(1): The board shall meet at the call of the chair, but not less often than once each quarter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(2): A quorum consists of three members.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(3): If a member has three or more unexcused absences within a 12-month period, the commissioner shall determine if that board member should be released from board duties.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106 Board meetings and hearings -- Quorum.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(1): The board shall meet at the call of the chair, but not less often than once each quarter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(2)(a): A quorum consists of five members.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(2)(b): The action of a majority of a quorum constitutes an action of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-106(3): If a member has three or more unexcused absences within a 12-month period, the commissioner shall determine if that board member should be released from board duties.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107 Licenses -- Classifications -- Prohibited acts.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(1): Licenses under this chapter are issued in the classifications of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(1)(a): bail enforcement agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(1)(b): bail recovery agent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(1)(c): bail recovery apprentice.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(2): A person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(2)(a): act or assume to act as, or represent himself to be, a licensee unless he is licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(2)(b): falsely represent that he is employed by a licensee.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(3): The commissioner shall issue licenses to applicants who qualify for them under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-107(4): A license issued under this chapter is not transferable or assignable.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108 Licensure -- Basic qualifications.
------------------------------------------------------------------
An applicant for licensure under this chapter shall meet the following qualifications:Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(1): An applicant shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(1)(a): at least 21 years of age;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(1)(b): a citizen or legal resident of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(1)(c): of good moral character.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2): An applicant may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a): have been convicted of:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a)(i): a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a)(ii): any act involving illegally using, carrying, or possessing a dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a)(iii): any act of personal violence or force on any person or convicted of threatening to commit any act of personal violence or force against another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a)(iv): any act constituting dishonesty or fraud;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a)(v): impersonating a peace officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(a)(vi): any act involving moral turpitude;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(b): be on probation, parole, community supervision, or named in an outstanding arrest warrant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(2)(c): be employed as a peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(3): If previously or currently licensed in another state or jurisdiction, the applicant shall be in good standing within that state or jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a): The applicant shall also have completed a training program of not less than 16 hours that is approved by the board and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(i): instruction on the duties and responsibilities of a licensee under this chapter, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(i)(A): search, seizure, and arrest procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(i)(B): pursuit, arrest, detainment, and transportation of a bail bond suspect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(i)(C): specific duties and responsibilities regarding entering an occupied structure to carry out functions under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(ii): the laws and rules relating to the bail bond business;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(iii): the rights of the accused; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(a)(iv): ethics.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(4)(b): The program may be completed after the licensure application is submitted, but shall be completed before a license may be issued under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5): 53-10-103; 53-5-704 If the applicant desires to carry a firearm as a licensee, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(a): 53-10-103 successfully complete a course regarding the specified types of weapons he plans to carry.  The course shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(a)(i): be not less than 16 hours;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(a)(ii): 53-10-103 be conducted by any national, state, or local firearms training organization approved by the Criminal Investigations and Technical Services Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(a)(iii): provide training regarding general familiarity with the types of firearms to be carried, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(a)(iii)(A): the safe loading, unloading, storage, and carrying of the types of firearms to be concealed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(a)(iii)(B): current laws defining lawful use of a firearm by a private citizen, including lawful self-defense, use of deadly force, transportation, and concealment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-108(5)(b): 53-5-704 shall hold a valid license to carry a concealed weapon, issued under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111 Licensure -- Bail recovery agent -- Requirements and limitations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1): 53-11-108; 53-11-113; 53-11-109; 53-11-109(1)(a); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1)(a): 53-11-108; 53-11-113; 53-11-109; 53-11-109(1)(a) In addition to the requirements in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1)(b): (1) The applicant shall substantiate the experience claimed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1)(b)(i): the exact details as to the character and nature of the experience on a form prescribed by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1)(b)(ii): certification by the applicant's employers, which is subject to independent verification by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1)(c): If an applicant is unable to supply written certification of experience from an employer in whole or in part, an applicant may offer written certification from persons other than an employer covering the same subject matter for consideration by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(1)(d): The burden of proving completion of the required experience is on the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(2): An applicant for license renewal shall have completed not less than eight hours of continuing classroom instruction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(3): A bail recovery agent may work as a licensee under this chapter only as an employee of or as an independent contractor with a bail bond agency.  A bail recovery agent may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(3)(a): advertise his services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(3)(b): provide services as a licensee under this chapter directly for members of the public; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-111(3)(c): employ or hire as independent contractors bail enforcement agents, bail recovery agents, or bail recovery apprentices.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112 Licensure -- Bail recovery apprentices -- Requirements and limitations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(1): 53-11-108; 53-11-113; 53-11-109; 53-11-109(1)(a) In addition to the requirements in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(2): A bail recovery apprentice may work as a licensee only:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(2)(a): as an employee or contract employee of a bail bond agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(2)(b): under the direct supervision of a bail enforcement agent or bail recovery agent employed also by the bail enforcement agent, unless the bail recovery apprentice is conducting activities at the direction of the employing bail enforcement agent that under this chapter do not require direct supervision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(3): A bail recovery apprentice may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(3)(a): advertise the apprentice's bail recovery services;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(3)(b): provide services as a licensee under this chapter directly for members of the public; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(3)(c): employ or hire as independent contractors bail enforcement agents, bail recovery agents, or bail recovery apprentices.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-112(4): A bail recovery apprentice may wear an article of clothing that conspicuously displays on the chest and the back of the article of clothing lettering that clearly identifies the licensee as a bail enforcement or recovery agent.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115 License fees -- Deposit in General Fund.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(1): 63J-1-504 Fees for individual and agency licensure, registration, and renewal shall be set in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(2)(a): The bureau may renew a license granted under this chapter upon receipt of an application on forms as prescribed by the board and upon receipt of the applicable fees if the licensee's application meets all the requirements for renewal.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(2)(b): If the bureau determines the license renewal application does not meet all the requirements for renewal, the bureau shall submit the renewal application to the board for review and action.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(2)(c): A license may not be renewed more than 90 days after its expiration.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(2)(d): A licensee may not engage in any activity subject to this chapter during any period between the date of expiration of the license and the renewal of the license.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(3)(a): The board may reinstate a suspended license upon completion of the term of suspension.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(3)(b): Renewal of the license does not entitle the licensee, while the license remains suspended and until it is reinstated, to engage in any activity regulated by this chapter, or in any other activity or conduct in violation of the order or judgment by which the license was suspended.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(4): The board may not reinstate a revoked license or accept an application for a license from a person whose license has been revoked for at least one year after the date of revocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-115(5): All fees, except the fingerprint processing fee, collected by the department under this section shall be deposited in the General Fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118 Grounds for denial of license -- Appeal.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(1): The board may deny a license application or a license renewal if the applicant has:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(1)(a): committed an act that, if committed by a licensee, would be grounds for probation, suspension, or revocation of a license under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(1)(b): employed as a bail recovery agent or bail recovery apprentice employee or contract employee a person who has been refused a license under this chapter or who has had a license revoked in any state;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(1)(c): committed, or aided and abetted the commission of, any act for which a license is required by this chapter, while not licensed under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(1)(d): knowingly made a material misstatement in connection with an application for a license or renewal of a license under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(2): The issuance of an identification card shall be denied to an applicant if the applicant fails to meet the required licensure qualifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(3)(a): The denial of the issuance of a license under this chapter shall be in writing and describe the basis for the denial.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(3)(b): The board's denial shall inform the applicant in writing that if the applicant desires a hearing to contest the denial, the applicant shall submit a request in writing to the commissioner within 30 days after the issuance of the denial.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(3)(c): The hearing shall be scheduled not later than 60 days after receipt of the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(4): The commissioner shall hear the appeal, and may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(4)(a): return the case to the board for reconsideration;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(4)(b): modify the board's decision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(4)(c): reverse the board's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-118(5): 63G-4-402 Decisions of the commissioner are subject to judicial review pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-120 Requirement to identify employing agency.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Upon request, a licensee shall immediately identify the name, business address, and telephone number of the bail bond agency for which the licensee is an employee or an independent contractor.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-123 Notification of local law enforcement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-123(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-123(1)(a): A bail enforcement agent or bail recovery agent who is searching for or planning to apprehend a person shall notify the local law enforcement agency if the search or apprehension will be conducted in an occupied structure within that law enforcement agency's jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-123(1)(b): When possible, notification shall be provided before taking action, but always within 24 hours of taking action.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-123(1)(c): When a bail enforcement agent or bail recovery agent is preparing to enter an occupied structure to carry out an arrest, he shall verbally advise the local law enforcement agency of his location and intended action prior to acting.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-11-123(2): A bail enforcement agent, bail recovery agent, and bail recovery apprentice shall each carry with him a written document providing proof and cause for the actions he is taking as a licensee, and shall make the document available to local law enforcement agencies upon request.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 13 - Peace Officer Classifications
***************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(1): 53-13-112 "Auxiliary officer" means a sworn, certified, and supervised special function officer, as described by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(2): "Certified" means recognized and accepted by the division as having successfully met and maintained the standards and training requirements set and approved by the director of the division with the advice and consent of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(3): "Collateral duty" means a duty to corroborate and support a peace officer function that is secondary and supplemental to the primary duty of the position.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(4): 53-6-106 "Council" means the Peace Officer Standards and Training Council created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(5): 53-6-104 "Director" means the director of the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division appointed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(6): 53-6-103 "Division" means the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(7): "Local law enforcement agency" means a law enforcement agency of any political subdivision of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(8): "Primary duties" means those duties which come first in degree of effort and importance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(9): "Principal duties" means those duties which are the highest and foremost in responsibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(10): "Reserve officer" means a sworn and certified peace officer, whether paid or voluntary, who:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(10)(a): is serving in a reserve capacity for a law enforcement agency that is part of or administered by the state or any of its political subdivisions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(10)(b): meets the basic and in-service training requirements of the peace officer classification in which the officer will function.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(11): "Spectrum" means that which encompasses the scope of authority.  "Full spectrum" encompasses total 24-hour authority; while anything less than full authority is contained or restricted within certain limits as set forth by statute, ordinance, policy, or rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(12): "Sworn" means having taken the oath of office set forth in Utah Constitution Article IV, Section 10, administered by the law enforcement agency for whom a peace officer works.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(13): "Volunteer" means an officer who donates service without pay or other compensation except expenses actually and reasonably incurred as approved by the supervising agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(14): (14)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(14)(a): "While on duty" means while an officer is actually performing the job duties and work activities assigned by the employing agency and for which the officer is trained and certified, and may include time spent outside those duties and activities if that additional time involves an activity that is an integral and necessary part of the job, and is spent for the benefit, and under the direction of, the employing agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-101(14)(b): (14)(a) "While on duty" does not include the time an officer spends commuting between the officer's home and place of employment unless that time involves an activity in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103 Law enforcement officer.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(2): Law enforcement officers may serve criminal process and arrest violators of any law of this state and have the right to require aid in executing their lawful duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(3)(a): A law enforcement officer has statewide full-spectrum peace officer authority, but the authority extends to other counties, cities, or towns only when the officer is acting under Title 77, Chapter 9, Uniform Act on Fresh Pursuit, unless the law enforcement officer is employed by the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(3)(b)(i): A local law enforcement agency may limit the jurisdiction in which its law enforcement officers may exercise their peace officer authority to a certain geographic area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(3)(b)(ii): Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(b)(i), a law enforcement officer may exercise authority outside of the limited geographic area, pursuant to Title 77, Chapter 9, Uniform Act on Fresh Pursuit, if the officer is pursuing an offender for an offense that occurred within the limited geographic area.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(3)(c): The authority of law enforcement officers employed by the Department of Corrections is regulated by Title 64, Chapter 13, Department of Corrections - State Prison.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-103(4): 53-6-205; 53-6-206 A law enforcement officer shall, prior to exercising peace officer authority:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104 Correctional officer.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1)(a): "Correctional officer" means a sworn and certified officer employed by the Department of Corrections, any political subdivision of the state, or any private entity which contracts with the state or its political subdivisions to incarcerate inmates who is charged with the primary duty of providing community protection.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1)(b): "Correctional officer" includes an individual assigned to carry out any of the following types of functions:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1)(b)(i): controlling, transporting, supervising, and taking into custody of persons arrested or convicted of crimes;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1)(b)(ii): supervising and preventing the escape of persons in state and local incarceration facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1)(b)(iii): guarding and managing inmates and providing security and enforcement services at a correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(1)(b)(iv): employees of the Board of Pardons and Parole serving on or before September 1, 1993, whose primary responsibility is to prevent and detect crime, enforce criminal statutes, and provide security to the Board of Pardons and Parole, and who are designated by the Board of Pardons and Parole, approved by the commissioner of public safety, and certified by the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(2): Title 64, Chapter 13, Department of Corrections - State Prison
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(2)(a): Title 64, Chapter 13, Department of Corrections - State Prison Correctional officers have peace officer authority only while on duty. The authority of correctional officers employed by the Department of Corrections is regulated by
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(2)(b): Correctional officers may carry firearms only if authorized by and under conditions specified by the director of the Department of Corrections or the chief law enforcement officer of the employing agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(3)(a): An individual may not exercise the authority of an adult correctional officer until the individual has satisfactorily completed a basic training program for correctional officers and the director of the Department of Corrections has certified the completion of training to the director of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(3)(b): An individual may not exercise the authority of a county correctional officer until:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(3)(b)(i): the individual has satisfactorily completed a basic training program for correctional officers and any other specialized training required by the local law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(3)(b)(ii): the chief administrator of the local law enforcement agency has certified the completion of training to the director of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(4)(a): The Department of Corrections of the state shall establish and maintain a correctional officer basic course and in-service training programs as approved by the director of the division with the advice and consent of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(4)(b): The in-service training shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(4)(b)(i): consist of no fewer than 40 hours per year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(4)(b)(ii): be conducted by the agency's own staff or other agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(5): The local law enforcement agencies may establish correctional officer basic, advanced, or in-service training programs as approved by the director of the division with the advice and consent of the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-104(6): An individual shall be 19 years old or older before being certified or employed as a correctional officer under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1 State and local law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Definitions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this section and in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(1): "Exercise law enforcement authority" and "exercise of law enforcement authority" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(1)(a): to take any action on private land, state-owned land, or federally managed land, to investigate, stop, serve process, search, arrest, cite, book, or incarcerate a person for a federal, state, or local criminal violation when the action is based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(1)(a)(i): a federal statute, regulation, or rule;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(1)(a)(ii): a state or local statute, ordinance, regulation, or rule; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(1)(a)(iii): a state or local statute, ordinance, regulation, or rule that is being enforced by a federal agency pursuant to the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(1)(b): to gain access to or use the correctional or communication facilities and equipment of any state or local law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2): "Federal agency" means a federal agency that manages federally managed land or regulates activities on that land, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(a): the United States Bureau of Land Management;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(b): the United States Forest Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(c): the National Park Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(d): the United States Fish and Wildlife Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(e): the United States Bureau of Reclamation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(f): the United States Environmental Protection Agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(g): the United States Army Corps of Engineers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(2)(h): the Department of Veterans Affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3): "Federal employee" means an employee or other agent of a federal agency, but does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(a): a special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(b): a special agent of the United States Secret Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(c): a special agent of the United States Department of Homeland Security, unless the employee is a customs inspector or detention removal officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(d): a special agent of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(e): a special agent of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(f): a United States marshal, deputy marshal, or special deputy United States marshal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(g): a United States postal inspector of the United States Postal Inspection Service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(3)(h): a police officer of the Department of Veterans Affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4): "Federally managed land" means land managed by the following federal agencies:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4)(a): the United States Bureau of Land Management;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4)(b): the United States Forest Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4)(c): the National Park Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4)(d): the United States Fish and Wildlife Service;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4)(e): the United States Bureau of Reclamation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(4)(f): the Department of Veterans Affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(5): "Proprietary jurisdiction federally managed land" means all federally managed land as defined in this section except:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(5)(a): buildings, installations, and other structures under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Congress of the United States pursuant to the United States Constitution, Article I, Section 8, Clause 17; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.1(5)(b): parcels that constitute federal enclaves subject to the concurrent jurisdiction of the United States and the state of Utah.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2 State and local law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Exercise of federal law enforcement authority when based on a federal enactment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2(1): State and local law enforcement officers may recognize a federal employee's exercise of law enforcement authority, either on or off federally managed land, when the exercise is consistent with the Constitution of the United States and based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2(1)(a): a federal statute other than the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2(1)(b): a federal regulation that is authorized by a federal statute other than the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2(2): 53-13-106.2(1) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2(2)(a): a federal statute, including the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.2(2)(b): a federal regulation that is authorized by a federal statute including the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13.

Secs. 1701-1736 and Secs. 1737-1782, Federal Land Policy Management Act, after the state law enforcement agency or a county sheriff has entered into an agreement authorized by Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.6 State and local law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Exercise of federal law enforcement authority to enforce the Federal Land Policy Management Act.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding SectionUtah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.6(1): a federal statute other than the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.6(2): a federal regulation that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.6(2)(a): authorized by a federal statute other than the Assimilative Crimes Act, 18 U.S.C. Sec. 13; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.6(2)(b): necessary to implement the provisions of the Federal Land Policy Management Act with respect to the management, use, and protection of the public lands, including the property located on those lands, as provided in 43 U.S.C. Sec. 1733(a).


Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.7 State and local law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Exercise of federal law enforcement authority based on state law during emergency.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding SectionUtah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.7(1): the offense is an emergency and poses an immediate risk of bodily injury or damage to property;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.7(2): a state, county, or municipal law enforcement officer is not reasonably available to take action;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.7(3): the action is within the scope of the employee's or official's law enforcement power; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.7(4): the federal employee turns the matter, as well as the custody of any detained citizen, over to the state, county, or municipal law enforcement officer for further action as soon as the officer becomes available.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.8 State and local law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Use of correctional and communication facilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
State and local government agencies may not allow any federal agency access to or use of the correctional and communication facilities and equipment of any state or local law enforcement agency without the express written consent of the appropriate responsible official of the state or local law enforcement agency.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.9 State and county sheriff law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Interagency agreements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding SectionUtah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.9(1): County sheriffs may enter into agreements with federal agencies granting limited authority to specific federal employees to exercise law enforcement powers to enforce federal state and local laws, provided the agreements are limited to a term not to exceed two years and the officers granted authority have completed a 20-hour course focusing on Utah law and process approved by the director of the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.9(2): (1) State law enforcement agencies may, with the consent of the local county sheriff, enter into agreements as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.9(3): Local county sheriffs may enter into agreements with federal agencies requiring fair compensation for assisting a federal agency or federal employee to enforce federal statutes and regulations managed pursuant to 43 U.S.C. Secs. 1701-1736 and 43 U.S.C. Secs. 1737-1782, Federal Land Policy Management Act.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.10 State and local law enforcement officers and federal employees -- Review by county sheriffs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
County sheriffs shall regularly review the duties and activities of federal agencies that have law enforcement responsibilities and that are acting within the jurisdictional area of the county to determine if the federal agencies are acting consistently with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11 Agreement for local law enforcement to enforce federal law -- Legal recourse to enforce.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11(1)(a): "Bureau" means the Bureau of Land Management, within the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11(1)(b): "Department" means the United States Department of the Interior.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11(2): (3); 53-13-106.9(3) The chief executive officer of a political subdivision or a county sheriff may, in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11(3): (3)(b)(i); (3)(b); (3)(b) In evaluating whether a violation of 43 U.S.C. Sec. 1733(c)(1) has occurred, the chief executive officer of a political subdivision or a county sheriff may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.11(3)(a): whether the bureau or the department has, by the words or actions of an employee or agent of the bureau or department, effectively determined that assistance is necessary in enforcing federal laws and regulations relating to public lands or the resources of public lands;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13 Notification requirement for federal officers before the release of an alien within the state.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1): 63G-12-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(a): 63G-12-102
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(a)(i): "Alien" means an individual who is illegally present in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(a)(ii): 63G-12-102 "Alien" does not include a permit holder as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(b): "Custody" means in the physical and legal custody of a federal law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(c): "Federal law enforcement agency" means an entity or division of the federal government that exists primarily to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(c)(i): prevent and detect crime and enforce criminal laws, statutes, and ordinances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(c)(ii): enforce federal immigration laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(d): "Federal officer" means an individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(d)(i): who works for a federal law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(1)(d)(ii): whose duties consist of the investigation and enforcement of federal laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(2): A federal officer may not release an alien from custody within the state unless the federal officer provides written notice three business days before the release to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(2)(a): the attorney general or the attorney general's designee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(2)(b): the county sheriff or the county sheriff's designee of the county in which the release is to take place.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(3): In providing the written notice under Subsection (2)(b), the federal officer shall also provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(3)(a): the specific address or location where the alien will be released;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(3)(b): the date and time at which the alien will be released; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-106.13(3)(c): whether the federal officer is aware of any outstanding criminal warrants concerning the alien who will be released.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107 Basic training requirements for position -- Peace officers temporarily in the state.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107(1)(a): Any person who has satisfactorily completed, before the effective date of this chapter, an approved basic training program required of the person's position may act in a certified capacity without completion of an additional basic training program.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107(1)(b): Any person hired, appointed, or elected to any position designated in this chapter, except federal officer, shall satisfactorily complete the required basic training required of that position before the person is authorized to exercise peace officer powers under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107(2): Any peace officer employed by a law enforcement agency of another state and functioning in that capacity within Utah on a temporary basis is considered certified under Utah law:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107(2)(a): while functioning as a peace officer within the state at the request of a Utah law enforcement agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-107(2)(b): when conducting business as a representative of a law enforcement agency from another state.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-109 References in other provisions.
---------------------------------------------------------------
When the term peace officer is used in any other provision of law, the term includes anyone authorized to exercise authority as provided in this chapter, except federal officers.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-111(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-111(1)(a): Nothing in this chapter shall preclude any law enforcement agency of the state or any of its political subdivisions from utilizing a sworn and certified peace officer in a reserve or auxiliary capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-111(1)(b): A reserve or auxiliary officer has peace officer authority only while engaged in the reserve or auxiliary activities authorized by the chief or administrator of the agency the officer serves and shall only exercise that spectrum of peace officer authority:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-111(1)(b)(i): that the supervising agency is empowered to delegate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-111(1)(b)(ii): for which the officer has been trained and certified.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-111(3): The agency the reserve or auxiliary officer serves shall ensure that the officer meets the basic and in-service training requirements of the peace officer classification in which the officer will function.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115 Peace officer restraint prohibition.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115(1): A peace officer may not restrain a person by the application of a knee applying pressure to the neck or throat of a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115(2): A violation of this section shall be referred separately to the county or district attorney for review, and to the Peace Officer Standards and Training Council for investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115(3): A violation of this section is a third degree felony.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115(4): If the violation results in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115(4)(a): serious bodily injury or loss of consciousness, it is a second degree felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-13-115(4)(b): death, it is a first degree felony.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 15 - Mcgruff Safe House Act
********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "McGruff Safe House Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-102 Purpose.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-102(1): The Legislature recognizes that children are often in dangerous situations that may be threatening or frightening to them and that there is a need for "safe homes" in our neighborhoods where a child may go for help.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-102(2): The Legislature also recognizes that along with the need for "safe homes" that children can recognize easily, there is needed a method by which these homes can be identified.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-102(3): The purpose of this chapter is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-102(3)(a): provide and designate a recognizable symbol for those "safe homes" that children can readily identify; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-102(3)(b): establish a method by which local law enforcement agencies can identify and train volunteers who are willing to make their homes "safe homes".


Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-201 Designation -- Administration.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-201(1): The National McGruff House Network Program is hereby designated as the officially recognized statewide "safe house" program for Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-201(2): The program shall be administered through the Department of Public Safety by the Utah Council for Crime Prevention.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202 Program requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(1): The statewide program administrator shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(1)(a): provide support and training upon request to local law enforcement agencies interested in implementing the program in their area;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(1)(b): provide local programs with signs for display in approved "safe homes"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(1)(c): maintain a register of all "safe homes" that includes, at a minimum, the address of the home and the names of all persons living in the home.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2): The local program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(a): recruit volunteer "safe homes" in neighborhoods with the help of local community groups;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(b): provide training and education to volunteers regarding the program and its use;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(c): provide for an application process for volunteers;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(d): conduct criminal history background checks on volunteers and members of their households;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(e): approve or disapprove applications for "safe homes";
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(f): provide education through community programs for parents and children on the program and the proper use of "safe homes";
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(g): provide approved "safe homes" with signs for display;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(h): provide procedures by which a "safe home" may be removed from the register; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-15-202(2)(i): provide for a method of renewal of the "safe home" designation in order to keep the registry current and provide for the periodic review of the "safe home", the volunteer, and all members of the household.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-17-401(4): The trust fund shall earn interest.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-17-401(7): Money deposited into the trust fund is irrevocable and is expended only for the purposes described in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-17-401(8): Assets of the trust fund are dedicated for the purposes established by statute and administrative rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-17-401(9): Creditors of the board of trustees and of employers liable for the benefits paid under this chapter may not seize, attach, or otherwise obtain assets of the trust fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-17-501 Death benefit assistance.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-17-501(1): An employer shall notify the governor's office of the line-of-duty death of an active member.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-18-104 Protection of constitutional rights.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not affect, limit, or apply to, any conduct or activities that are protected by the constitution or laws of the state or by the constitution or laws of the United States.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 53 - Chapter 19 - Certification of Private Law Enforcement Agency
*********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Certification of Private Law Enforcement Agency."

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(1): 53-6-103 "Division" means the Peace Officer Standards and Training Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(2): "Formal action" against a private law enforcement agency includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(2)(a): placing a private law enforcement agency on probation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(2)(b): extending the probation of a private law enforcement agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(2)(c): revoking the certification of a private law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(3): "Informal action" against a private law enforcement agency includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(3)(a): an oral or written warning;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(3)(b): a written reprimand; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(3)(c): a written order to remedy noncompliance with a provision of this chapter, which may include a deadline for compliance and verification of compliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-102(4): "Private law enforcement agency" means a law enforcement agency operated by, and at, a private institution of higher education.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103 Rulemaking authority.
-----------------------------------------------------
The commissioner shall make rules, in accordance withUtah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(1): the forms and process to apply for certification of a private law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(2): methods for the commissioner, the department, or the division to obtain, review, use, and protect, any and all records of, or directly related to, a private law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(3): Part 3, Enforcement requirements for the conduct of a formal hearing under
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(4): requirements for verifying compliance with the terms of probation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(5): audit procedures;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(6): requirements for the contents of a policies and procedures manual of a private law enforcement agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-103(7): requirements for the operation of a private law enforcement agency.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-201 Certification of private law enforcement agency.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-201(1): A private institution of higher education may operate a private law enforcement agency if the private law enforcement agency is certified by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-201(2): (4) A private law enforcement agency certified before May 5, 2021:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-201(2)(a): (4) is not required to apply for an initial certification under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-201(3): (4) A private law enforcement agency that is not certified before May 5, 2021:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-201(6)(a)(i): the application is complete;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-203(1)(b): review, and revise and update as needed, the policies and procedures manual on at least an annual basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-203(1)(c): maintain, and uniformly apply and enforce, the policies and procedures contained in the manual.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-204 Audits.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-204(1): The commissioner or the commissioner's designee may conduct periodic audits of a private law enforcement agency to ensure compliance with the requirements of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-204(2): The legislative auditor general or the state auditor may conduct an audit of a private law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-204(3): A private law enforcement agency shall fully cooperate with an audit conducted under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301 Violation by private law enforcement agency -- Action by commissioner.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1): (2); (1)(c)(iii)(A); (2) If a private law enforcement agency is in violation of, or has violated, a provision of this chapter, the commissioner may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(a): take informal action to remedy the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(b): place the private law enforcement agency on probation if the violation is a material violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c): (2); (1)(c)(iii)(A); (2) revoke the certification of the private law enforcement agency if:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c)(i): the violation is so egregious that it constitutes a violation of public trust;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c)(ii)(A): the violation is a material violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c)(ii)(B): the private law enforcement agency has committed the same violation on a previous occasion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c)(ii)(C): the private law enforcement agency was placed probation or had the certification of the private law enforcement agency revoked for the same violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(1)(c)(iii): (2); (1)(c)(iii)(A); (2) after committing a material violation:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(2)(a): a detailed description of the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(2)(b): a statement that the violation constitutes a material violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(2)(c): a detailed description of the action the private law enforcement agency is required to take to remedy the violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(2)(d): a specified, reasonable deadline for taking the action required to remedy the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(3): If a private law enforcement agency on probation is in violation of, or has violated, a material provision of probation, the commissioner may:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(3)(a): take informal action to remedy the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(3)(b): extend an existing period of probation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(3)(c): revoke the certification of the private law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(4): If the commissioner takes action to revoke the certification of a private law enforcement agency, the certification remains in effect until all timely challenges or appeals are concluded and the action of the commissioner becomes final.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-301(5): The certification of a private law enforcement agency remains in effect while the private law enforcement agency is on probation, unless the certification is revoked in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-302 Formal action against a private law enforcement agency.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-302(1): If the commissioner determines that a private law enforcement agency violated a provision of this chapter or a requirement of probation, the commissioner may take formal action against the private law enforcement agency in accordance with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-19-302(2)(f): information regarding the process and deadline for requesting a hearing.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(1): "Crime scene investigator technician" means an individual employed by a law enforcement agency to collect and analyze evidence from crime scenes and crime-related incidents.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(2): "Designated mental health resources liaison" means a non-leadership human resources or other administrative employee designated by a first responder agency who receives and processes a request for mental health resources on behalf of the first responder agency under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3): 53-13-103; 53-2e-101; 53-2e-101; 53-2e-101; 34A-3-113; 53-6-102; 53-13-104; 53-13-105; 67-5b-102; 77-38-403 "First responder" means:

Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(e): 34A-3-113 a firefighter, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(f): 53-6-102 a dispatcher, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(g): 53-13-104 a correctional officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(h): 53-13-105 a special function officer, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(i): a search and rescue worker under the supervision of a local sheriff;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(j): 67-5b-102 a forensic interviewer or victim advocate employed by a children's justice center established in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(3)(o): a civilian employee of a first responder agency who has been authorized to view or otherwise access information concerning crimes, accidents, or other traumatic events.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(4): 53-19-102 "First responder agency" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(4)(a): a special district, municipality, interlocal entity, or other political subdivision that employs a first responder to provide fire protection, paramedic, law enforcement, or emergency services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(4)(b): 53-19-102 a certified private law enforcement agency as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5): 26B-5-102
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(a): 26B-5-102 "Mental health resources" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(a)(i): an assessment to determine appropriate mental health treatment that is performed by a mental health therapist;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(a)(ii): outpatient mental health treatment provided by a mental health therapist; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(a)(iii): 26B-5-102 peer support services provided by a peer support specialist who is qualified to provide peer support services under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(b): "Mental health resources" includes, at a minimum, the following services:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(b)(i): regular periodic screenings for all employees within the first responder agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(b)(ii): assessments and availability to mental health services for personnel directly involved in a critical incident within 48 hours of the incident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(b)(iii): regular and continuing access to the mental health program for:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(b)(iii)(A): spouses and children of first responders;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(5)(b)(iii)(C): spouses of first responders who have retired or separated from the agency.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(8): "Retired" means the status of an individual who has become eligible, applies for, and may receive an allowance under Title 49, Utah State Retirement and Insurance Benefit Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(9): "Separated" means the status of an individual who has separated from employment as a first responder from a first responder agency as a result of a critical incident involving the first responder.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10): "Small first responder agency" means a first responder agency that:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10)(a): has 10 or fewer employees;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10)(b): is primarily staffed by volunteers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10)(c): is located in:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10)(c)(i): a county of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10)(c)(ii): a city of the third, fourth, fifth, or sixth class; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-101(10)(c)(iii): a town.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102 Mental health services -- Requirement to provide  -- Eligibility -- Confidentiality -- Requests -- Reporting noncompliance -- Designation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(1): Every first responder agency within the state shall provide or make available mental health resources to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(1)(a): all first responders;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(1)(b): the spouse and children of first responders;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(1)(c): surviving spouses of first responders whose death is classified as a line-of-duty death under Title 49, Utah State Retirement and Insurance Benefit Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(1)(d): retired or separated first responders for at least three years from the date that the retired or separated first responder requests mental health resources, regardless of any subsequent employment as a non-first responder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(1)(e): spouses of retired or separated first responders for at least three years from the date that the spouse of the retired or separated first responder requests mental health resources, regardless of any subsequent employment as a non-first responder.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(2): All access by first responders and their families to mental health resources shall be kept confidential.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3): 53-21-104.3 A first responder agency shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(a): 53-21-104.3 annually provide information to all employed first responders regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(a)(i): the availability of mental health resources under this section, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(a)(i)(A): for individuals in addition to the first responders as described in Subsection (1); and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(a)(i)(B): subsequent to a separation or retirement;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(a)(ii): how to access the mental health resources under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(a)(iii): 53-21-104.3 directions on how to appeal a denial of mental health resources under this section to the department, as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(b)(i): assign a designated mental health resources liaison;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(b)(ii): inform the department of the identity of the designated mental health resources liaison; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-102(3)(b)(iii): update the department as to the identity of the designated mental health resources liaison when a new individual is assigned.


Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103 Grants to first responder agencies -- Rulemaking.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(1): The department may award grants to first responder agencies to provide mental health resources in response to a:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(1)(a): request for proposal;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(1)(b): request for qualifications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(1)(c): program description that meets the criteria in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(2): The request for proposal, request for qualifications, or program description received by the department shall require mental health providers contracted or employed by the first responder agency to have training and experience in working with first responders and provide mental health resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(3): An application from a first responder agency for a grant under this chapter shall provide the following details:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(3)(a): a proposed plan to provide mental health resources to first responders in the first responder agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(3)(b): the number of first responders to be served by the proposed plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(3)(c): how the proposed plan will ensure timely and effective provision of mental health resources to first responders in the first responder agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(3)(d): the cost of the proposed plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(3)(e): the sustainability of the proposed plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(4): In evaluating a project proposal for a grant under this section, the department shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(4)(a): the extent to which the first responders that will be served by the proposed plan are likely to benefit from the proposed plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(4)(b): the cost of the proposed plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(4)(c): the viability of the proposed plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(5): A first responder agency may not apply for a grant to fund a program already in place. However, a request for proposal to fund an expansion of an already existing program shall, in addition to the requirements of Subsection (4), provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(5)(a): the scope and cost of the agency's current program;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(5)(b): the number of additional first responders the expansion will serve; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(5)(c): whether the expansion will provide mental health resources that the current program does not provide.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(6): 53-21-104.1 The department shall prioritize grant funding for small first responder agencies, and may also take into account whether the small first responder agency is or will participate in the department-provided services described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(7): The department may adopt rules in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, to administer this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(8): The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(8)(a): notify entities that may be eligible for a grant under this section about the grant program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(8)(b): on or before October 1, 2024, and October 1, 2025, provide a report to the Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice Interim Committee that describes:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(8)(b)(i): the number of entities that have been notified by the department about the grant program under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(8)(b)(ii): the number of grant applications that the department has received.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(9): The department may assist a first responder agency in drafting a grant application under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-103(10): 53-21-104.1 The department may use up to 25% of the remaining grant funds under this section to provide the mental health resources described in Section

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-104.1(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-104.1(1)(a): In accordance with Subsection (4), the department may, at the department's discretion, provide certain mental health resources to a small first responder agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-104.1(1)(b): The mental health resources described in Subsection (1)(a) may include an assessment and availability to mental health services for personnel directly involved in a critical incident within 48 hours of the incident.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-104.1(2): The department may use a contracted provider to provide the services described in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 53-21-104.1(3): If a small first responder agency elects to receive mental health services as provided under this section, the small first responder agency shall designate a representative of the small first responder agency who is responsible for providing a timely notification to the department or the department's designee if a critical incident occurs as described in Subsection (1)(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102 State security chief -- Creation -- Appointment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(1): There is created within the department a state security chief.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2): The state security chief:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(a): is appointed by the commissioner with the approval of the governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(b): is subject to the supervision and control of the commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(c): may be removed at the will of the commissioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(d): shall be qualified by experience and education to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(d)(i): enforce the laws of this state relating to school safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(d)(ii): perform duties prescribed by the commissioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-102(2)(d)(iii): enforce rules made under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.1 School Security Task Force -- Membership -- Duties -- Per diem -- Report -- Expiration.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.1(1): There is created a School Security Task Force composed of the following members:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.1(1)(a): the House chair and vice chair of the House Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice Standing Committee during the 2024 General Session, with the House chair serving as the co-chair of the task force;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.1(1)(b): two members from the Senate, whom the president of the Senate selects and one of whom the president of the Senate appoints as co-chair of the task force;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.1(1)(c): the state security chief;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.1(1)(d): one member of the State Board of Education, whom the chair of State Board of Education selects;

Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2 The School Security Task Force -- Education Advisory Board.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(1): There is created an advisory board to the task force called the Education Advisory Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2): The advisory board shall consist of the following members:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(a): the state security chief, who acts as chair of the advisory board;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(b): the construction and facility specialist at the State Board of Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(c): a superintendent from a county of the fourth, fifth, or sixth class, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(d): a superintendent from a county of the first, second, or third class, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(e): a charter school director from a county of the fourth, fifth, or sixth class, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(f): a charter school director from a county of the first, second, or third class, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(g): the president of the Utah School Boards Association or the president's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(h): a parent representative from a school community council or parent teacher organization, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(i): a facilities manager from an LEA in a county of the fourth, fifth, or sixth class, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(j): a facilities manager from an LEA in county of the first, second, or third class, whom the state security chief selects;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(k): a representative of private schools, whom the state security chief selects; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(2)(l): a member of the Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health, whom the state security chief selects.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(3): The advisory board's purpose is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(3)(a): review and provide input on official business of the task force;
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(3)(b): provide recommendations and suggestions for the task force's consideration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(3)(c): study and evaluate the policies, procedures, and programs implemented for school safety and provide proactive information regarding the implementation.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(4)(a): A majority of the members of the advisory board constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(4)(b): The action of a majority of a quorum constitutes an action of the advisory board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(5)(a): The advisory board shall select two members to serve as co-chairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(5)(b): The co-chairs are responsible for the call and conduct of meetings.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(6): The staff of the state security chief shall provide staff for the advisory board.
Utah Code Annotated § 53-22-104.2(7): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member of the advisory board who is not a legislator may not receive compensation for the member's work associated with the task force but may receive per diem and reimbursement for travel expenses incurred as a member of the task force at the rates established by the Division of Finance under:
